name: Der Präsident. –
text: I would like to inform my fellow Members that interpreters from Ireland are only available to a limited extent because of the travel restrictions and that, therefore, this morning, from 9 a.m. to 10.30 a.m., interpretation from and to the Gaelic language cannot be guaranteed. We try to do our best.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: Mr President, let me inform the House of the negative developments that are currently taking place in my home country of Cyprus. Turkey, repeatedly demonstrating provocation and aggression, is carrying out new criminal acts against the Republic of Cyprus, in violation of the principles of the United Nations, the resolutions of the Security Council and the European Parliament, and opens up the closed area of Famagusta. Turkey's president Erdogan and the pseudo-prime minister announced that tomorrow Thursday they are opening the closed famagusta area.  I call on the European Parliament and the High Representative of the European Union to condemn criminal, aggressive, expansionist Turkey immediately, but also to take action against it. Turkey which does not stop at all, even in violation of the conclusions of the European Council, according to which it must respect the resolutions of the United Nations.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr President, I think it was important to draw attention to this incident, which has already been picked up by the media this morning. Perhaps the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Mr Borrell, will be able to comment briefly on this during the debate.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the resumption of hostilities between Armenia and Azerbaijan in connection with the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict (2020/2809 (RSP)).

name: Josep Borrell Fontelles
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, I am going to make reference to the issue of the debate on the Nagorno-Karabakh region, and if you allow me at the end I will say some words about the issue raised by our Cypriot colleague.  The current military confrontation along the line of contact in the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict zone is of our utmost concern. It is the largest confrontation since 1993-1994. We have been very engaged on this issue. On the day that fighting erupted, I released a statement as High Representative calling for an immediate cessation of hostilities, de-escalation and a strict observance of the cease-fire. During those days I had several phone calls separately with Armenian and Azerbaijani Foreign Ministers urging both sides to stop hostilities and return to the negotiation table.  Our position is clear: the fighting must stop. Both sides need to re-engage in meaningful negotiation, which, by the way, has not been very fruitful over the last 30 years, without preconditions under the auspices of the OSCE Minsk Group Co-Chairs. There cannot be a military solution to the conflict no less an external interference. This position was reinforced by the European Council held on 1 and 2 October.  We have seen extremely worrying reports of a surge in attacks on populated areas which is taking a deadly toll on civilians. We strongly urge the sides to fully observe their international obligations to protect civilian populations, and with the resources we have, we have urgently allocated a small amount of money in humanitarian aid for the affected populations. In fact, we don’t have a lot of information about how the conflict is developing. Detailed information is scarce and there is a lot of fake news.  We see monitoring underground remains suspended, so we don’t have that service. But what we observed is an increasing amount of information which is aimed at mobilising the domestic audiences in both countries and could be used to pull regional actors into the conflict. Media reports need therefore to be examined with great caution because some of the news that has been disseminated, we don’t have confirmation about it.  At this a stage further escalation of the conflict and involvement of regional actors unhappily cannot be excluded. This would seriously threaten the stability of the whole region.  On 30 September I discussed the situation with the Russian Foreign Minister. I also spoke with the Turkish Foreign Minister, the two regional actors which are closer to the conflict. I emphasised the importance of de-escalating, the importance that regional actors refrain from any activity and rhetoric that could inflame things even further. I spoke to the Foreign Ministers of Armenia and Azerbaijan during the weekend. I stressed that the increase in civilian casualties is unacceptable. I knew from both sides the actions taken by the other side. Each one of them blames the other for starting and for attacking civilian population from the territory, not from Nagorno-Karabakh itself, the region in dispute, but from Armenia to Azerbaijan and Azerbaijan to Armenia.  The fighting should stop. The Minsk Co-Chairs are going to have meetings this week with the Foreign Affairs Ministers of two countries and the only way of getting out of this situation is that the Minsk Group Co-Chairs pushes for immediate negotiations as soon as possible.  We will continue working with the key partners and try to help stop hostilities because the only solution is to go back to the negotiating table, but this negotiating table has been open for the last 30 years – 30 – without any kind of advance. The war is not an alternative. We have to push both parties to stop fighting and negotiating without preconditioning, but this is for the time being not the case. I’m sorry I cannot inform you more about that because I accept that information is very scarce, and we have to take much care in disseminating news which has not been confirmed. About the situation in Cyprus, I share the concern of the honourable Member who took the floor a moment ago. For sure, this issue of Famagusta was taken into consideration and the European Council also. The opening of this area, which is a closed area according to the cease-fire agreements under the auspices of the United Nations, is a serious violation of this agreement. Yesterday we issued a statement and today the 27 will issue another one asking Turkey to stop doing this activity.  You know that the European Council issued a statement about the situation in the Eastern Mediterranean, and for sure this is not going to help. On the contrary, it is going to increase tension and make it more difficult to reach an agreement on an especially difficult situation for all of us in the Eastern Mediterranean.

name: Andrey Kovatchev
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, it is indeed very painful and sad to see killings and people suffering as part of this conflict which has been going on for decades while we, as observers in the international community, do very little, despite the statements we put out. Since the fighting broke out again, more than 200 people have been killed. My deepest condolences and sympathy to the victims and their families on both sides. Reports vary, but so do – as the High Representative himself said – the claims made by the fake news media, disinformation campaigns, propaganda and by both sides with the aim of mobilising their own people and confusing the international community. I can tell you that lies cannot be hidden forever and sooner or later the truth will come out. I would also like to repeat that the violence, the hostilities and the killing of people must stop immediately. The conflict has been surrounded by various claims – as you mentioned, according to Amnesty International even cluster bombs have been used. This needs to be clarified and investigated, as does the involvement of third parties and even Syrian fighters going through Turkey to the conflict area. All violence must stop immediately. The two sides should return to the negotiating table under the umbrella of the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) Minsk Group to find a mutually acceptable solution, based on agreed principles, and refrain from the threat of the use of force, which – sadly – has clearly been violated now, territorial integrity and the equal rights of the self-determination of people. The involvement of any other parties needs to stop as soon as possible. Unfortunately, we saw at one point in time that they were very close to a mutually acceptable situation and compromise but now this is far away.

name: Tonino Picula
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, High Representative, firstly, let me express our utmost concern about the eruption of renewed military hostilities between Armenia and Azerbaijan both in the Nagorno-Karabakh region and along the line of conflict. The fighting must stop immediately and all sides of the conflict must return to respecting the cease-fire agreement without any delay and without any preconditions. As the S&D, we have repeatedly appealed to refrain from any actions and also from any rhetoric that may fuel tensions between the two countries.  Today we urge to stop the fighting and return to negotiations. There is no other path to solving the conflict other than to return to the negotiating table under the chairmanship of the OSCE Minsk Group. The principles of the UN Charter, the OSCE Helsinki Final Act and the 2009 Basic Principles continue to be the guiding principles for the solution to this conflict. With the role of Russia as mediator diminishing, we must expect other partners to contribute to the same goal. This is especially important given the reports about the presence of mercenaries sent by Turkey. It seems that many, if not most, of our foreign policy challenges at external borders have Turkey as the common denominator and cause. The latest actions are yet another clear sign of Ankara’s depart from EU values and international law standards.

name: Urmas Paet
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, it is not acceptable to use violence and killings in international affairs, also between Armenia and Azerbaijan. You can try to force things and make changes when you have power, but it is clear that such changes do not last. The only lasting solution can be a mutually agreed and mutually accepted solution. This means negotiations. It means talking to each other. It means diplomacy.  Right now, the only result of the actions of the political leaders is the suffering of ordinary people, killings and people losing their homes. Violence creates violence and this will have long-lasting consequences. If some other interested parties, like Turkey or Russia, really and truly want to invest in ending this conflict, then there is a way, but it’s not by sending fighters to fight in the conflict or by assisting in some other military forum. They can help through diplomacy or by facilitating negotiations.  If you take a look at history, including recent history, the people of South Caucasus, including the people of Armenia and Azerbaijan, have suffered enormously under this political violence. The spiral of violence must be stopped. The EU has also tried to contribute to the well-being and growth of these societies through, for example, the Eastern Partnership programme, trying to demonstrate that the only way to bring prosperity to societies is through peace. Violent choices tend to throw societies into long and agonising misery, poverty and aggression. The EU must continue to help Armenia and Azerbaijan find a way to alleviate this long-term hatred and reach a solution, but this cannot be done at a time of war.

name: Jérôme Rivière
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, the small mountainous territory of Nagorno-Karabakh has flared up in recent weeks, reigniting an ancient conflict. As in Syria, Libya and the eastern Mediterranean, it is Erdogan who has just reopened a conflict on the border of Europe. Erdogan's desire to establish himself as the leader of a political Islam, to rebuild the Ottoman Empire, is obvious. It deploys its expansionist policy without any shame. The Erdogan regime must be sanctioned and isolated, but the initiative must also be taken back. At the origin of this nagorno-Karabakh conflict, there is of course the configuration of the internal borders of the former USSR, cleverly organized in such a way as to entangle peoples, to multiply infinitely the references of identity to better establish the overwhelming totalitarianism of communism.  From this situation, the Union, which is concerned in the first place, has not been able to seize on the question of proposing solutions that are realistic, fair and peaceful. Today, Azerbaijan has chosen, by taking the initiative of the offensive to revive this conflict, because its leaders have received strong pledges of support from the Turkish president. Even today, by pushing Azerbaijan to confrontation, Erdogan still chooses to launch a major challenge to European countries by attacking Armenia more directly, with which so many historical and human ties unite us. Erdogan, like a criminal returning to the scene of his crime, shows how little he does about the genocide of the 1.5 million Armenians perpetrated by those who preceded him in power. Words are insufficient, Mr. Borrell. What is the European Union waiting for to put a definitive end to Turkey's accession process to the Eu? Our colleague reminded us at the moment that he is still challenging us in Cyprus. As Thucydides said, men are thus made that they despise those who spare them and respect those who do not grant them anything.

name: Viola Von Cramon-Taubadel
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the In the current war for Nagorno-Karabakh, two principles are diametrically opposed: on the one hand, the principle of territorial integrity, and on the other, the principle of self-determination of peoples. The great failure of the international community is, above all, that, after 28 years of negotiations, it has not been able to resolve this fundamental conflict. Worse still, instead of confidence-building measures, the region has been upgraded. Thus, both warring parties – Armenia and Azerbaijan alike – were armed to the teeth, especially by Russia and Serbia.  In this sense, there are basically only losers in the conflict: firstly, the OSCE Minsk Group as negotiator, secondly, the civilian population in Armenia, Nagorno-Karabakh and, of course, Azerbaijan itself. The only group that seems to benefit from the war at the moment is that of the international military observers, as they are currently looking with great interest to Nagorno-Karabakh, where various high-tech weapons are sometimes in use for the first time. This new form of warfare – with the help of armed drones and other precision weapons – is said to be just the beginning of technologically advanced warfare. What can the EU do wisely? Firstly, in the negotiations, it must influence France, Russia and the United States to ensure that they do not continue to side unilaterally with the Armenians. Secondly, it must ensure that NATO partner Turkey does not continue to pour oil on the fire. Thirdly, it must ensure that humanitarian supplies are provided to civilian victims of war. I do not think we should be naive, but that our role should be precisely in acting realistically, clearly and purposefully on our partners.

name: Anna Fotyga
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the recent flare-up of the conflict is very serious and broader than just Nagorno-Karabakh. We call for an immediate ceasefire and engagement of parties of the Minsk Group, but also other important players like the EU. Armenia enjoys Russian security guarantees that do not include Nagorno-Karabakh, as it is an internationally recognised part of Azerbaijani territory. Azerbaijan has Turkish backing. The problem is that the conflict concerns this time a different part of the southern Caucasus, with key routes of oil pipelines, gas pipelines, roads, rail and fibre optics leading outside of Russian influence to Europe, among others. So we have to have a look at this and we have to see the whole broad picture.

name: Idoia Villanueva Ruiz
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the conflict in the South Caucasus has been unresolved for more than three decades, one more conflict in the vicinity of the European Union: both Armenia and Azerbaijan, two of the most militarized countries in the world; Nagorno-Karabakh, an enclave of political dispute, a corridor for pipelines to reach from the Caspian Sea to world markets; Russia, the region's largest arms exporter; Turkey, which, meanwhile, seeks to relocate itself as a key player in the Caucasus by destabilizing the region, something that must end.  This escalation of conflict and aggression has the potential to create thousands of refugees and internally displaced persons. We clearly joined the request of the UN and the high representative and called for an immediate ceasefire, an end to hostilities, the return to the negotiating table within the framework of the Minsk Group without pre-conditions, as Armenia has already stated that it is ready to do. The European Union should be involved, in a coordinated manner in collaboration with regional bodies, civil society and neighbouring countries. After seventeen years of neighborhood policy we have more conflicts at our borders. European countries are divided into their foreign policy. The European Union, abroad, is becoming increasingly irrelevant. We need a new policy of neighbourliness, cooperative and non-competitive, based on the principles of human security, populations, culture of peace and disarmament, with economic development always for mutual benefit. If not, we will continue to suffer its consequences.

name: Κώστας Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Mr President, the deep capitalist crisis brings fierce competition between the urban classes of the two countries with a resurgence of nationalisms, wars and refugees. The European Union, the US and NATO have great responsibilities for the conflict in Ngorno Karabakh and are involved in their competition with Russia and China. They redistribute the land, redistribute the energy roads, with the people's blood the borders carve. An expert is the role of Turkey's bourgeoisie on the side of Azerbaijan, which was not at all accidentally taken up by the recent European Council communiqué. And now they are opening up the coastal front of Varossia, which we denounce.  Finally, the course of events shows that in the territories that for decades during the Soviet Union lived peacefully Armenians and Azeris, now killing each other in the wreckage of the overthrow of socialism. This is another proof of the superiority of socialism and of today's capitalist barbarism. The two peoples, learning from their own history, must fight against monopolies and create conditions, based on their own interests, for a break with the capitalist system.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE).
text: – Mr President, since the first day of this military confrontation, we in the European Parliament urged both sides to come to a cease-fire. We called for a balanced approach, based on the principles both sides agreed on. The most important and invaluable stake to take into account are the lives of the citizens. The continued fighting does not contribute to anything. It puts the stability of the region in danger. No country should add fuel to the fire by providing mercenaries, weapons or inflammatory speeches. I express my condolences to the victims of the conflict and to all the refugees of the past –now and in the future – of this clash, where no one will gain and everyone will lose. No empire will be built in the 21st century, regardless of the insane dreams. So my message goes to those who are adding fuel to this fire, and I’m asking them to stop – especially Mr Erdoğan. The European Union is ready to help, to mediate and to support the Minsk Group that already addressed its strong engagement based on the agreed principles. The European Union does not export mercenaries and sorrow. The EU exports values for decent lives for all citizens.

name: Marina Kaljurand (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the High Representative for his remarks and comments. I would like to share some thoughts as the Chair of the South Caucasus delegation after I spoke to my counterparts, Mr Arman Yeghoyan and Mr Javanshir Feyziyev. The EU does not have a formal role in the Minsk Group negotiations, but that does not mean that we should not be active, vocal and crystal clear about our messages. We are talking about our Eastern Partnership and we are talking about our eastern partners. First, we should convince the political leaderships of both sides to establish a ceasefire and protect civilians. Reports, if they are true, about the use of cluster bombs are very worrisome and, High Representative, I agree that we need clear facts and information from the region. Second, we should convince both sides to return to the negotiations without preconditions and with good faith and commitment so that this time there will be a solution based on UN resolutions, Minsk Group basic principles and international law. Third, we should urge other regional powers, especially Russia and Turkey, to stay out of the military conflict. The interference of any outside elements will expand the conflict and make the escalation more difficult. War is never a solution. The people of Nagorno—Karabakh deserve long—lasting peace and prosperity.

name: Hilde Vautmans (Renew).
text: Mr President, Mr High Representative, the situation in Nagorno-Karabakh is of great concern to me, as do you, like all my colleagues. That is why we are debating this today. And when you entered Brussels today, you saw the flags in the streets: people are worried about the lives that are dying in the region. Mr High Representative, the European Council last week instructed you to consider further EU support in the peace process. You were very clear today: you are going for a ceasefire, you are talking to all parties. But what surprised me is that you have not actually talked about the use of cluster bombs. You did not actually mention the foreign partner who intervenes there, namely Turkey. You have not spoken about the foreign fighters being sent there. No, you are talking about a positive agenda with Turkey for the conflict that my Cypriot colleague cited, which I understand. But with Turkey, we are going to have to put all the cards on the table to make it clear that this cannot continue.  Thank you, you have our support to resolve this conflict.

name: Lars Patrick Berg (ID).
text: Mr President, High Representative, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work First of all, I would like to praise the friends of Azerbaijan for their highly professional media and lobbying campaign. Any criticism of Azerbaijan's actions immediately triggers an avalanche of social media posts and personal insults. The Azerbaijani side is obviously very well organised here. We should not be surprised by the Azerbaijani approach. For weeks now, increasingly belligerent tones have been heard with constant threats against Nagorno-Karabakh and Armenia from Baku. In August, Azerbaijan held joint military exercises with Turkey, during which Turkey pledged its government's support for an Azerbaijani invasion of Nagorno-Karabakh. Cluster bombs are already in use, and credible reports indicate that Ankara has sent Syrian militias to support the Azerbaijani army. This is exactly what Turkey is doing in Libya: it is bringing further instability and even more violence to a region already facing unrest. I am particularly concerned about the Turkish strategy of using Syrian mercenaries. If Turkey's Libya strategy is repeated here, these mercenaries will not be paid and will eventually be left to their own devices. The risk from disaffected extremists is hard to imagine. And this risk does not only affect Armenia, it affects us all.

name: Markéta Gregorová (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, High Representative, dear colleagues, for me as a member of the Euronest Bureau it is incredibly saddening to witness such acrimony and outspoken hostility between two participating countries. The objective to increase cooperation between the EU and our Eastern neighbours, which we are carrying out through the Eastern Partnership, obliges us to pay full attention to the ongoing conflict and to play a proactive role in its peaceful resolution. I call on you, Mr Borrell, to start negotiating the conflict resolution with both parties. Some may explicitly take sides and support one country or the other, but this House should stick to two simple but fundamental points. Firstly, hostilities should cease immediately. Above all, it is imperative that Armenia and Azerbaijan must stop targeting civilians. At least four journalists were severely injured a few days back, while civilian casualties are being reported daily by both sides as a consequence of heavy fighting and bombings of inhabited centres. Secondly, neighbouring powers should refrain from fanning the flames of war through military statements and military support of any kind. Whoever engages in these acts puts the stability of the region further at risk and hinders any attempt to bring the warring parties to the negotiating table. In this regard, Erdoğan’s Turkey is displaying very irresponsible behaviour, which must be firmly condemned by all political forces.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by From here I would like to address our friends from Azerbaijan, to our friends from Armenia: there is a land called the Arches and there for seventeen centuries armenians live, and they will live there regardless of these wars, unless you use the Aushungerung method.  Remember dear friends the year 1812, the year 1828, remember the twenties of the last century, and then you will know who imposed on you those borders which today are the beginning of this war. Step away from what Russia has offered you, then you can sit down and only then can you get along. Your northern neighbor today looks and rubs his hands.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, why are we concerned and concerned? Because the population of Nagorno-Karabakh is 95% Armenian, and if the fighting continues, it is obviously the assurance of a bloodbath or a mass exodus.  But it is also because the Caucasus is a land of lust, of confrontation, which has already experienced two serious wars since the fall of the USSR, in Chechnya and Georgia, and that the region can ignite.  And finally, it is because behind the belligerents there are two great powers: Russia, which is supposed to be in solidarity with Armenia, and Turkey, which participates in many armed operations, Libya, Syria, the eastern Mediterranean and, today, this conflict. I think that Europe cannot just deplore it, it can take the initiative. Of course, we must demand an immediate ceasefire, we must work together with the Minsk group, but we must also put pressure on Ankara because we will appear as mediators, that is good, but I fear that at some point we will have to choose our side.

name: Márton Gyöngyösi (NI).
text: – Mr President, the Nagorno—Karabakh conflict is a frozen conflict and frozen conflicts have the nature of erupting every now and again. So who started this conflict now, this time round, is completely irrelevant.  If we want to be responsible concerning the worrying escalation of the Nagorno—Karabakh conflict, and find a long—term solution, we have to remember the source of the conflict. Thirty years ago, at the time of the break—up of the Soviet Union, Armenian forces, together with Russian forces, invaded Nagorno—Karabakh and seven adjacent territories, territories of Azerbaijan, leaving many dead on both sides and over one million internally displaced people.  Since then, a dozen resolutions issued by the UN Security Council, NATO, the European Parliament and the OSCE have all been adopted with an overwhelming majority, if not unanimously. They all say the same: Armenia must withdraw unilaterally, restore the territorial integrity of Azerbaijan, and the Armenian minority must be granted autonomy on the territory of Azerbaijan. So international law provides clear guidance. The real question is how we enforce and implement our resolutions.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: – Mr President, High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, as colleagues have previously mentioned, the renewed escalation of violence in and around Nagorno-Karabakh puts at risk the fragile stability in the whole South Caucasus region. Of all territorial disputes of the post-Soviet states, this one is the most dangerous. As the European Parliament has repeatedly stated – and to be very clear once again – there is no, and there cannot be, a military solution to this conflict. Instead, a political settlement is necessary, in accordance with international law: for example, the principles enshrined in the United Nations Charter, the 1975 OSCE Helsinki Final Act, as well as the OSCE Minsk Group’s 2009 Basic Principles. Therefore, we all call for an immediate halt to any military activity in the region. Both sides need to return to diplomatic dialogue without preconditions and in good faith. As many colleagues have already pointed out, third parties in the region should refrain from any action which can fuel the conflict and undermine the desire of the people from both countries for a peaceful future.

name: Isabel Santos (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Mr High Representative, yes, there is no solution to the conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh that does not go through the path of dialogue and negotiation, and thus, as has been repeated, there is a need for an immediate ceasefire, without conditions, the resumption of mediated dialogue and the conduct of the parties to the strictest respect for the principles set out in the Helsinki Final Act and the 6 basic principles agreed within the framework of the OSCE Minsk Group.  Bellicose speeches or appeals to the use of force and actions of confrontation cannot be tolerated and an attack on civilian targets can never go blank, and the use of cluster bombs should be investigated. Destabilising interference by third parties cannot be tolerated, as turkey has been witnessing, an absolutely unacceptable attitude in a candidate country and which is constantly making a permanent call for confrontation and destabilisation at various border points in the European Union. Having said that, Mr High Representative, I can only appeal to the most active involvement of the European Union, not only in this conflict, but also in other protracted conflicts, which are always potential hotbed of destabilisation.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (Renew).
text: – Mr President, High Representative, it is indeed extremely concerning to see the outbreak of hostilities in Nagorno—Karabakh between Armenia and Azerbaijan. These countries have been involved for decades in territorial conflict, and the use of force against territorial integrity and the loss of life, including among the civilian population recently, runs the risk of escalating into a larger regional conflict. Indeed, despite the fact that the UN Security Council, in its four resolutions, underscored the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Azerbaijan within its internationally-recognised borders, as also the European Parliament confirmed numerous times in its resolutions, and the OSCE and the Minsk Group have promoted the peace process for many years, today a lasting peaceful settlement of this conflict is possible only in substantive and meaningful negotiations. War is not a solution. The violence must stop. But it’s also time for the European Union to act.

name: Roman Haider (ID).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In the Caucasus, around 50 ethnic groups live side by side in a very narrow space, and the roots of many conflicts often date back centuries. At the same time, the Caucasus has been a pawn of the adjacent powers since ancient times. 2 000 years ago it was the Persian and Roman Empires, and now it is mainly Russia and Turkey, but also other powers that have their fingers in the game. If you are looking for a culprit in this confusion, you will find either many culprits or none at all. Of course, Armenia will always see itself on the one hand as the protector of the Armenian ethnic group in the enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh. On the other hand, Azerbaijan cannot, of course, see how, in breach of international law, 20% of its territory is occupied militarily by a foreign power beyond this enclave. In addition to Russia, which must also be criticised in this proxy war, Turkey, under its Sultan Erdogan, is also fomenting this conflict. I therefore ask you, and above all the Members, colleagues from the People's Party and the Social Democrats: how long do you want to tolerate Turkey as a candidate for EU membership? What else needs to happen before you realise that Turkey cannot be a partner for Europe?

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, nearly three decades of diplomatic efforts haven’t been able to end a conflict that again is taking a big toll in human lives. Now we are confronted with a risk of a fully-fledged war in the South Caucasus with the dangerous involvement of external actors.  We have to call on all sides for an immediate ceasefire and for de-escalation. All sides have to resume talks under the auspices of the OSCE Minsk Group without preconditions, and everyone in the region and beyond should be working to foster peace instead of escalating the situation.  However, I also call for the need to recognise and respect the right to self-determination of the people of Nagorno-Karabakh. For the need to uphold their democratic will and choices, already made several times. This is not only a territorial issue. Disregard for the right to self-determination is at the root of too many conflicts. Without respecting the democratic will of the people of Artsakh, I am afraid there will hardly be a viable and fair way out of this conflict.

name: Charlie Weimers (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I would say to High Representative Borrell that we all lament the casualties in Nagorno—Karabakh. We all support a non—military solution.  But should we pretend Armenia and Azerbaijan are tarred with the same brush? No! This is a war of aggression by the Azeri dictator Aliyev, supported by President Erdoğan’s Jihadist allies from Turkey to enforce the injustice of Joseph Stalin’s separation of Nagorno—Karabakh from Armenia. Sanction Aliyev, the aggressor. Expel Turkey from the OSCE Minsk Group. Have the courtesy not to portray the suffering people of Artsakh as equally belligerent as President Aliyev. In the words of Andrei Sakharov, for Azerbaijan the issue of Armenia is a matter of ambition, for the Armenians of Karabakh it is a matter of life and death.

name: Martina Michels (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has We have been talking all the time about the countries in conflict. If there is one thing, Azerbaijan's left-wing youth recently wrote what our underfunded educational institutions have done well, it is to sow hatred and spread nationalist propaganda. Meanwhile, outlawed cluster bombs fall on the unofficial capital of Nagorno-Karabakh, fight Erdogan's mercenaries for Azerbaijan, and continue to supply Russia with weapons to Armenia and Azerbaijan. Let us not deceive ourselves: the European Council, with its policy on Turkey, is making a diabolical contribution to the destabilisation of the South Caucasus. This will put a brake on the efforts of the OSCE Minsk Group at the end of the day.  But let us talk about our own responsibility: Euronest, for example, should take immediate action, because we must finally give a voice to those who, like the young people of Azerbaijan, say that the enemy is not an Armenian – our enemy is the people in power.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (NI).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Solana, amnesty international's accusation that cluster bombs are being used in the town of Stepanakert is extremely serious, in all probability by Azerbaijani forces: an atrocious and flagrant violation of international humanitarian law. The EU can no longer remain silent or simply repeat the usual mantras: the time has come for action to protect civilians in this battered region, starting with the review of the negotiating framework with the direct inclusion of the European Union. We must not be afraid to put on the table targeted, substantial and dissuasive sanctions against those actors who will not agree to suspend hostilities and negotiate, but even more so towards those third parties that intervene in the conflict, further exacerbating it for their own interests. Good Canada promptly suspended arms exports to Turkey following complaints about their use in Nagorno-Karabakh. I say this quite clearly: I strongly condemn Turkey's role in the conflict. How many times do we have to repeat that Ankara, a candidate for accession and a NATO ally, has a geopolitical agenda that is different from our own? No more words, we need action! If not now, when?

name: Andrius Kubilius (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Vice-President, as a co-chair of Euronest, I would like to make just two comments. First of all, I would like to appeal to our friends, the Armenians and the Azerbaijanis: you are fighting and killing not only children, you are killing your own future, the future of your children and grandchildren. The war is a sign of weakness of leadership, not of their strength. Compromise and peace demand much more political courage.  And second, I would like to appeal to colleagues inside this House and inside of the EU. In this House we like to talk about EU strategic autonomy but our strategic autonomy starts from our strategic responsibility and the EU till now was failing, from that point of view, especially on this conflict. For almost 30 years, the conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh is here and in the EU we have only our permanent statements of our concern. That is not working.  My rhetorical question, first of all to the Vice-President: can we learn from the recent actions of the US administration on how to implement strategic responsibility? Recently, the US administration managed to resolve longstanding conflicts between Serbia and Kosovo on the European continent and between Israel and several Arab countries in the Middle East. The American model is very simple: agreement on peace brings huge economic benefits. Mr Vice-President, let’s start to be really strategically responsible.

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, war broke out in Nagorno-Karabakh. Civilians were also dying, and children and women are also dying. The fighting has even spread beyond the borders of this territory of a state that no one recognises and which has long belonged to Azerbaijan but is predominantly inhabited by armenians, and which has always been a source of unrest between armenians and Azerbaijanis. The heaviest fighting since the 1990s has also raised concerns about the fate of the Azerbaijani oil and gas pipeline, which is also going to Europe. Although this is a conflict over The Karabakh Plateau, which both Armenia and Azerbaijan want to control, it is dodging that Turkey is also actively involved. As the only NATO Member State and candidate to join the European Union, it is openly supporting one of the warring parties, namely Azerbaijan. And if numerous reports from the region are to be believed, Turkey not only supplies Azerbaijan with weapons and ammunition, but even mediates the arrival of paid mercenaries and jihadists from Syria to fight in Nagorno-Karabakh. I therefore believe that it is not enough for us to just discuss here. But we should do more. I am all the more disappointed that there has also been no will to adopt a resolution calling for an immediate break in the fighting and a return to the negotiating table, in which we would also call on all regional powers to refrain from any open support from one of the warring parties. So how Russia, meanwhile, despite the agreement with Armenia on military aid, is quite rational, and I would say, almost neutral, Turkey must also stop its open support for Azerbaijan. Therefore, Mr Borrell, head of European diplomacy, I ask you, at least, on behalf of the European Union, to take an active and tough stance in this regard.

name: Nathalie Loiseau (Renew).
text: Mr President, Mr High Representative, there are many ways of looking at the resumption of the conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh. The first, the most diplomatic, is to support the Minsk Group and its co-chairs, the United States, Russia and France, which is what we all do. The second, the most realistic, requires looking the world in the face. The conflict is on fire as America looks elsewhere. But he got caught up, because Russia has moved to leave open wounds in the four corners of its former empire. That does not bode well. The third is an emotional and very emotional and worrying thing that I see Turkey getting involved militarily against Armenian people. Mr High Representative, you are a diplomat and preach neutrality, of course, but let me say here my anger and sorrow at seeing Turkey, a country that continues to refuse to recognize the Armenian genocide, take militaryly from the Armenian people. It is time for peace to return, it is also time to acknowledge the wounds of history.

name: Alessandro Panza (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased to note that there is a transversal condemnation of the Erdoğan regime today, by the same groups that then vote in favour of pre-accession funds. But that's fine. Last September, hostilities resumed in the troubled Caucasus region of Nagorno-Karabakh, a situation that has reignited a long-running conflict. It is still unclear who started the conflict, although there are doubts. But in addition to concern about the involvement of civilians who have come under bombardment, there is concern that foreign powers, such as Russia and Turkey, could intervene directly in the area, starting an escalation from the far from obvious outcome. We know very well how Azerbaijan is an important economic partner for Europe, including Italy. But at the same time we know that small and proud Armenia is the first Christian nation in the world and the first to suffer genocide in modern times by the Ottoman Empire which, despite this, some still deny. We therefore call on the High Representative, and with it the whole of the European Union, to take root in torpor, taking a clear stand in favour of the process of self-determination of peoples and by strongly supporting fundamental rights and peace.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, there is obviously a sweeping consensus in this House that the fighting should be stopped without preconditions. But what then? And just pretending that sending the parties back to the negotiating table would bring them anywhere closer to a solution would be foolhardy because it hasn’t happened in 30 years. So what are we doing to show our own responsibility? It’s not just tensions as usual in the South Caucasus. There are two factors that are changing. First, the United States are dialling down their engagement in the region, even though they are one of the three co-chairs, and, second, Turkey is not de—escalating – on the contrary. We are presently in a situation where two European neighbours – Russia and Turkey – are squaring off against each other in three distinct arenas. Both neighbours have withdrawn from the international rule of law as a principle they adhere to.  The EU does not have a formal role in this conflict, but if the EU doesn’t take more responsibility on itself, who will help in solving the issue? That’s why I subscribe to the term that Mr Kubilius has used, the strategic responsibility of the EU.

name: Assita Kanko (ECR).
text: Mr President, the Nagorno-Karabakh region is at breaking point. My heart bleeds when I see it. The lives of ordinary citizens are being lost. This escalating violence is a road to nowhere. No military solution will bring peace, only dialogue. As the Armenian prime minister said, "a ceasefire can only be instituted if Turkey is removed from the South Caucasus."  We can all say here that Turkey is an important ally of the EU and a valuable NATO member, but how many conflicts, urgency and tensions have not been exacerbated by Erdoğan's actions? How long will it be before the EU finds the courage to speak frankly and show Turkey that its actions have consequences? Turkey had a choice. It could have used its considerable influence to calm tensions. Instead, it is sending fighters from Syria to further fan the flames of the conflict.  The EU may think that it is pragmatising Turkey. Instead, she only shows weakness.

name: Martin Sonneborn (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I do not want to distract from the Corona virus, but health seems more dangerous to me to invade a peace-loving, democratic community and to shell its residential areas with cluster munitions. This is exactly what the madmen of the Bosphorus and Baku in Nagorno-Karabakh are currently practising. They kill the risk group of Armenians, regardless of age, weight and pre-existing conditions.  I do not want to dwell on Azerbaijan. The Kaputtnik state is linked to European values solely through oil pipelines. Whatever Baku breaks there, it breaks, thanks to Erdogan, who is determined to complete a genocide that began 100 years ago. It is unbelievable that the EU, that we still see him as a partner, while spreading terror with jihadist mercenaries – in the Caucasus, Iraq, Syria, Libya, and the Mediterranean. As an unofficial spokesman for the non-attached Members, I hereby officially recognise the Republic of Arzach. May others follow suit and give it the protection of the international community, which has been denied it for far too long. But the EU should return the Nobel Peace Prize and apply for the Neville Chamberlain Memorial Medal as a reward (the president interrupts the speaker).

name: Michael Gahler (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the A seemingly frozen conflict over Nagorno-Karabakh has suddenly become hot again. All call for a halt to the fighting and a return to the agreed Minsk format. The principles of territorial integrity and self-determination are opposed here. The Minsk process was supposed to bring about a solution. I hope that we will learn from this that the other allegedly frozen conflicts will not simply be left to their own devices, but will take preventive action.  What has changed since Karabakh declared itself independent in the early 1990s and Armenia, by occupying Azerbaijani territory, created a territorial gap with the enclave? The difference today is that Turkey unilaterally changes the fragile balance through unconditional military and political solidarity with the Aliyev regime and, arguably, the transfer of Islamist fighters from Syria to Azerbaijan.  I think THAT NATO member Turkey is also dangerously close to Russia. In view of the tragic history, Turkey has every reason to avoid even appearing to take action against Armenians here. I call on the EU to find allies in the world community to jointly force a ceasefire and negotiations. Perhaps we must strive for internationalisation in the form of UN Blue Helmets or an OSCE peacekeeping force to ensure that both sides remain separate, that the people of Nagorno-Karabakh remain there in a self-determined manner, and that Aeris can return to their homeland safely.

name: Nacho Sánchez Amor (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Mr Borrell referred to the enormous amount of propaganda around the conflict and the difficulty in determining the facts. Therefore, doing a good analysis is surely appropriate. Of course, this is not a war of religion, as has sometimes been intended to be made to believe, creating a crusade, nor do I think it is particularly useful to talk again about the mass ethnic murders of a century ago. It is a conflict arising from the Soviet Union and its dissolution, and it is a demonstration that what we call frozen conflicts, in this climate of global geopolitical warming, can be thawed and create conflicts immediately. Turkey's participation. A first effect — seen in this debate – is that no one is talking almost about Azerbaijan, Baku, or Aliyev; it seems to be a conflict between Turkey and Armenia and we leave one of the main players aside. The main issue of Turkey's participation, even if participation with military shipment could not be confirmed, is belicist rhetoric. Turkey is the only country in the world that has joined the war rhetoric and not the universal chorus of voices it is calling for a ceasefire, a de-scalding and resuming negotiations. That is our role, Mr Borrell: in this new climate with Turkey, demand that Turkey be united with the international community in this position... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Malik Azmani (Renew).
text: – Mr President, firstly on behalf of Renew Europe, I want to express my deepest sorrow for all civilians in Nagorno-Karabakh. Secondly, I call on those who are responsible to end all violence, and let me be clear – an immediate ceasefire is paramount.  There are even indications that cluster ammunition has been used, and this is an absolute red line. There are also indications that Turkey is playing a growing role backing Azerbaijan. These are signs that Turkey has sent Syrian mercenaries and weapons, including offensive drones. I would like to ask Mr Borrell why this has not yet been confirmed, as the EU so many intelligence services with vast resources. I don’t understand. The European Council conclusions last week were very clear, Mr Borrell. You are responsible for finding a strong European response. Therefore, I would like to know: will we stay quiet or will we act to bring this violence to an immediate end?  There is no time to lose.

name: Jordan Bardella (ID).
text: Mr President, for more than ten days now, Azerbaijani forces have been carrying out an offensive against Nagorno-Karabakh. In addition to the military losses, many civilians were forced to seek refuge in neighbouring Armenia as a victim of rocket fire, shelling or suicide bombers. Behind this localized conflict, one must be blind not to see the hand of Sultan Erdogan. At the risk of shocking, I say here that you, the leaders of the European Union, are constantly seeking to avoid opposition, you are trembling with fear at the idea of taking real sanctions against Turkey. You talk about a powerful Europe when it comes to wind turbines or trade agreements, but you let an Islamist autocrat act with impunity in an imperial space. You give moral lessons and the rule of law at all times, but you provide subsidies to a country, Turkey of Erdogan, which today refuses to recognize the Armenian genocide, which should make you think in view of the religious and ethnic dimension of the ongoing clashes. Sanction and finally bend Sultan Erdogan and you will see that Nagorno-Karabakh, Libya and the eastern Mediterranean will be more appeased.

name: François Alfonsi (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, the aggression carried out by the Azerbaijani army and its Turkish ally against the Armenian people of Nagorno-Karabakh must alert us and mobilise us. The Armenian people experienced the worst with the genocide perpetrated by Turkey in 1915. It has suffered half a century of Soviet rule and, since the fall of the Berlin Wall, it aspires to freedom and democracy. Nagorno-Karabakh is an example of democracy in this part of the world, which is that of a people whose millennia-old culture is threatened by the will of its neighbours to hegemony. Europe is directly concerned because the rise of dictatorial and liberticidal regimes on its doorstep will eventually threaten it itself. It has the means to push back the aggressors by taking heavy economic sanctions, this is how it acts to preserve the interests of Cyprus and Greece in the Mediterranean, that is how it must act vis-à-vis Baku and Ankara to help the Armenian people now under attack.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, Mr. High Representative, nearly a century ago, a great warrior of VMRO and a Bulgarian poet, Peyo Kracholov Yavorov, wrote about the Armenians as follows: " debris null and void than ever brave martyr people, children of mother slave anxious and victims of a feat heard quite great...". This is part of the poem dedicated to the Armenian genocide – one of the biggest crimes against the Armenian people, not yet recognized and committed by Turkey.  Today we see again the brutal intervention of Sultan Erdogan. We see him, with his rhetoric, with his mercenaries he transfers, with the weapons he transfers, with the way he speaks, again makes the world laugh and is again at the heart of aggression. And here it is high time that you, as High Representative, and this Parliament finally stop with the two-faced and dual attitude towards President Erdogan, this candidate sultan, this dictator. Because when you have to quarrel with some banana dictator, everyone unites, they read big declarations, but when we talk about Erdogan, everyone here or with few exceptions is silent, ashamed, dare not say it. Of course, our sympathies and our hearts will always be with the people of Armenia, and I also confidently believe that the symbol of Armenia Ararat should return to Armenia again.

name: Clara Ponsatí Obiols (NI).
text: – Mr President, the attack launched by Azerbaijan with the support of Turkey threatens the stability of the whole Caucasus. The Commission must increase its pressure on Azerbaijan and Turkey to halt the military aggressions against the Armenian people and reject the use of violence to change the status quo in the region. But the Commission must also call on the Member States that are selling weapons to Turkey that go to this conflict. Spain is the main Member State selling weapons to Turkey. This must be stopped by the Commission, Mr Borrell. The conflict can and will be solved through constructive negotiation between the parties, but to reach a peaceful solution that must respect the self—determination right of the citizens in the Republic of Artsakh.

name: Traian Băsescu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Armenia and Azerbaijan cannot reach a compromise on their own, but they will certainly reach a devastating war. The Minsk group is divided and therefore ineffective. The Russian Federation supports the principle of self-determination with which it would justify all interventions in the region: Transnistria, eastern Ukraine, Crimea, Nagorno-Karabakh. That is why I believe that the right solution for the European Union is a strong intervention with France and the United States for Russia to accept a Security Council resolution within the meaning of the six principles agreed in Madrid.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D).
text: – There is no war zone in the wider region, in which Turkey does not participate: Libya, Syria, Iraq and now Nagorno Karabakh. Not only have they not reconciled with the historical truth, not accepting one of the worst tragedies in human history, the Armenian genocide, but today they are actively involved, transporting jihadists from Syria to the war zone of Nagorno Karabakh, to fight alongside Azerbaijan. Mr Erdogan's decisions undermine the achievement of a ceasefire and lead to the expulsion of populations from their ancestral territories.  Mr Borrell, anyone who thinks they can win the war does not stop to make peace. That's why we need to intervene vigorously now. You must take initiatives to make the parties concerned understand that sanctions are not a la carte for those who violate international law, even those where some European countries have a special economic interest. We must achieve an end to hostilities and the resumption of negotiations under the auspices of the Minsk Group.

name: Klemen Grošelj (Renew).
text: – Mr President! Dear High Representative! Once again, the EU is facing a crisis in its immediate neighbourhood. This time it is boiling in the increasingly unstable South Caucasus, where the conflict for Nagorno-Karabakh has thaw with Turkey's help. I believe that the time has come for the European Union to finally show the various regional players who want to renew such and different imperial dreams, which for everyone else are a common nightmare, where are the limits of our patience. I therefore expect the EU to demand uniformly, both from the warring parties and their regional sponsors, to end the armed conflict and to start negotiations for a peaceful solution to the crisis. At the same time, we must make it very clear to them that otherwise, large-scale economic sanctions follow. If anything, the EU has enormous economic power, especially in regions in the immediate neighbourhood, and the time has come to use it.  Recent experience in the Eastern Mediterranean shows that a unified and decisive european Union is having an effect.

name: Marco Dreosto (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are horrified and dismayed at the escalation of violence that is taking place in Nagorno-Karabakh these days. We agree with mr Borrel's words and his demands for a ceasefire and dialogue between Armenia and Azerbaijan. However, we are very concerned about Turkey sending Syrian jihadists to fight alongside Azerbaijan: hundreds, according to some sources as many as thousands, of Syrian rebels close to islamist movements sent to fight in turkey that continues to destabilise entire geographical areas, ranging from Libya to Syria. Precisely in order to demand a firm position from the European Union, I co-signed, together with 48 other Members from all sides of the political spectrum, a letter calling on the Eu ropean Union to take a firm stand on Turkish interference in this conflict. It has already been mentioned that Armenia is the first Christian nation in history and its population was the first to suffer genocide in modern times, precisely by the Ottoman Empire at the beginning of the twentieth century. Ladies and gentlemen, let us not leave our Armenian brothers alone, once again victims of Sultan Erdoğan's neo-Ottoman dream.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In fact, this conflict could be expected to erupt, because it was only a matter of time before one of the parties attacked if it considered it to have a military advantage. Nevertheless, the Union, as usual, seems surprised and helpless.  I would therefore like to ask the President what means, in addition to the resolution condemning the use of force, in addition to the ritual calls for a peace and the peace and our parliamentary speeches, do the European Union have at its disposal to significantly influence the resolution of this conflict? As the main economic partner of both Armenia and Azerbaijan, does it have any significant soft power, and am I no longer talking about hard power to positively influence developments in the region? Have we used this soft power sufficiently so far? Or do we not have it at all, which should lead us to a slightly more realistic assessment of our Union.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Before we proceed with the debate, I will open the first round of voting today in time at 10.30 a.m. The dossiers on which we are now voting can be found on the agenda. The voting round will take place from 10.30 a.m. to 11.45 a.m. The same voting procedure will apply as in the previous voting rounds; it is well known to all Members. Votes on the approval of the allocation of new responsibilities by Executive Vice-President of the Commission Valdis Dombrovskis and the approval of the appointment of Mairead McGuinness as a member of the European Commission will take place by secret ballot.  Members cast their ballots in the traditional way, but the ballot paper they must receive and sign does not show how they voted, only that they voted – in these two cases.  All other votes are roll-call votes. I declare the first round of voting open. As I said, you can vote by 11.45 a.m. The results of this round of voting will be announced at 2.15 p.m.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: We are now continuing the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the resumption of hostilities between Armenia and Azerbaijan in connection with the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict (2020/2809(RSP)).

name: Ιωάννης Λαγός (NI).
text: Mr President, what is taking place at the time in Naghorno Karabakh is the continuation of the Armenian genocide by the bloodthirsty Turks. The question I have to ask the European Parliament and Mr Borrell is this: when will the European Parliament tolerate this unacceptable attitude by Turkey? He's done it all the time, he keeps doing it all the time. And as long as I am at least an MEP, for 16 months now, I have only heard words about Turkey and I have not seen a single act.  We see, therefore, that they want to send an illegal army and weapons to Azerbaijan at the moment in order to hit a civilian population and strike the Armenians, who are right on their side. And here we must clarify who are the attackers and who are the ones who are defending themselves, because we cannot emulate them. Others are unnecessarily attacking and others are trying to live and defend themselves.  We therefore need to look at the situation. I have to propose to the European Parliament that it immediately impose harsh sanctions on Turkey and Azerbaijan and that direct assistance from the European Union and the European Parliament be granted to the people of Armenia, both with military hardware and financial assistance.  Finally, I would like to say that I have stated in practice that I wish to participate in the effort of the Armenian army and to volunteer to fight the enemy, the Turk.

name: Rasa Juknevičienė (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we need effective leadership to solve conflict. There are two ways to achieving peace over Nagorno Karabakh. There are two ways to achieving peace over Nagorno Karabakh: The first way, leaders of Azerbaijan and Armenia stop being hostages to this problem and find compromise themselves. However, there are very little chances this may happen unfortunately.  The second path, the democratic powers USA and EU both take over this responsibility. They bring both parties to the negotiating table by proposing clear, tailor-made political and economic plan for the future. If normalisation agreements were possible with Serbia and Kosovo, it is also possible with Armenia and Azerbaijan. We often speak about EU strategic autonomy, I support colleagues. This term will become meaningful only if it comes with EU strategic responsibility. So my question today, is the EU ready to take responsibility for peace in its neighbourhood, be it south or east?

name: Andreas Schieder (S&D).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for his work The conflict over Nagorno-Karabakh is a long-standing and also a very complicated conflict. Of course, we condemn the fighting that is currently taking place and we also call for an immediate ceasefire. Because war claims many civilian, innocent victims, war is above all not a solution to this conflict. What is needed is a solution that makes it possible for the different ethnic groups in the region to live together in a sustainable way. For Nagorno-Karabakh, there is only one diplomatic and a political solution based on international law. The Minsk Group is the international platform for these international negotiations and must therefore be used. Everyone – Armenia, Azerbaijan, Russia, and especially aggressive Turkey – must de-escalate. An immediate ceasefire and a "back to the negotiating table" are needed.

name: Bernard Guetta (Renew).
text: Mr President, we hear Armenia, war, Nagorno-Karabakh, and we are obviously thinking of this genocide, which is still denied by the State that perpetrated it. In the face of these struggles, it is the memory of the Armenian pain that comes back to us, but beware, Stalin had drawn the internal borders of the USSR, so that each Republic would have one or more minorities and that the Kremlin could divide to rule. If we were to accept today the questioning of these borders that have become international, the whole of the former Soviet era would soon be in flames. So it is not a question of taking sides, but of bringing the belligerents back to the negotiating table. It's going to be hard. Yes, it will be. But all the more reason for us Europeans to go with the United States and with Russia, which needs us because from Minsk to Bishkek, via Stepanakert, the fact is that Mr Putin is losing more and more hands.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mr High Representative, i would like to thank you for your comments. The traditional question can be asked in the context of this conflict: qui bono. Whose interest is there? It is not in the interest of armenians, not in the interests of the Azeri people, it is in Russia's interest. It is Putin who occasionally invites the presidents of both countries and is such a judge, arbitrator, educator and prosecutor. I think it must be made clear that this conflict is – apart from obviously different interests, apart from history – also a matter of simply the Kremlin's interest.  I think that the European Union should be more active, not only in terms of our Parliament's resolution (that's a good thing) and the voice of the European Commission, but perhaps sending a peacekeeping mission, a peacekeeping mission, so that not only Russia is a playmaker in the region.

name: Peter van Dalen (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr Borrell, please, keep your ears and eyes open. What's going on here? Despot Erdoğan wants to restore the ancient Ottoman Empire. His aggression is widely visible in and outside Turkey. Latest victims: Armenia and Nagorno-Karabakh. Erdoğan's violence cannot stop talking. It is time for the European Union to draw a line in the sand. That means sanctions against the regime in Ankara. Not words, but deeds. The time for talking, statements, Minsk meetings is over. I stand next to the Armenian people. That has been beaten by the hard Turkish fist for a long time. Think of 1915, the genocide. We must act now against Turkey, and that is my question to you.

name: Evin Incir (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the conflict in, and over, Nagorno-Karabakh has, both historically and now in the current escalation of the conflict, deprived many people of their lives and children of the possibility to grow up in peace and security. It is vital that the hostility ends and the two parties to the conflict, Armenia and Azerbaijan, meet at the negotiation table rather than on the battlefield. There is no way other than a peaceful solution out of this long ongoing conflict. International peace needs to be an international endeavour. It is therefore absolutely unacceptable that countries such as Turkey, for example, contribute with mercenaries, among other things, to worsen the situation even more. The EU is a region built on the idea that dialogue is the only way forward for long-lasting peace. It is our duty at the same time to take leadership for those ideas in our neighbouring countries. I am glad that the international community is ready to assist and the EU needs to support the ongoing process in the OSCE. My questions to the High Representative are: first, what is the Commission doing to end the conflict, and, second, how are the discussions going with Erdoğan in Turkey, who has already caused too many conflicts in other regions?

name: Carlo Fidanza (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, nagorno-karabakh is a troubled story. In 1921 the region, inhabited mainly by Christian Armenians, was annexed to Azerbaijan by the Soviets. After the collapse of the USSR in 1991, Armenians in the region voted for independence; Azerbaijan's non-recognition of the outcome of that referendum has led to a long conflict which is currently escalating and which we absolutely must stop. We must achieve a ceasefire, an end to Azerbaijani military aggression, a resumption of the peace process coordinated by the Minsk group, and in order to do so, we must reduce the role of Erdoğan's Turkey, which wants to make this region another piece of its neo-Ottoman project, unscrupulously involving even jihadists from Syria in the conflict. Let it be a NATO country, it is bitter and makes us think; That it is even a candidate country for pre-accession to the European Union should instead lead us, once and for all, to close this page and withdraw turkey's status as a candidate country.

name: Vladimír Bilčík (PPE).
text: – Mr President, let me first express my sincere condolences to all of those who have lost their loved ones and friends in this conflict since it erupted in the Caucasus again. People are dying in the region and we must therefore do our utmost to seek peace – peace through international dialogue, diplomatic channels and ultimately a lasting solution to the conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan.  Many speakers today have mentioned problems with Turkey. But the conflict in Nagorno—Karabakh has its true origins in Soviet times and in Moscow. What we in the EU once saw as a ring of European friends in our neighbourhood is turning into a ring of fire and enemies.  We cannot stand by and look at neighbourhood policy through the lenses of the last decade. If we do not change our approach to external relations, we shall remain spectators not just in Nagorno—Karabakh. It is high time to commit more resources to political and economic engagement on the ground, to our active communication, to debunking of disinformation about this conflict as well as strategic foresight. It is high time for true European foreign policy action.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D).
text: Mr President, it has become tiresome to talk about the international agitator, Turkey. Behind all the unrest is turkey's regime, in the Southeastern Mediterranean, Greece, Cyprus, Syria, Libya and now Armenia. Unfortunately, some in Europe want to reward Turkey, which has contributed to the destruction of Syria, and for hosting the refugees it has created. How hypocritical! Now a very big issue has been created in the Caucasus, in Nagorno Karabakh, again led by Turkey. The one who suffers is the Armenian people. Of course, other players are involved in this game behind the scenes: Russia, Iran, China. What role does the European Union really play? What role can it play?

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict, in the first place, obliges us to send our deepest condolences to all the victims of this conflict, which are not only those of the moment, but also those of the past. But if it demonstrates something I would say that we can sum it up in two fundamental ideas: the first is that the European Union must act more and more strongly with Turkey. We cannot have a conflict with Greece and Cyprus, we cannot have Turkey in Libya, Turkey in Syria, Turkey in Kurdistan and now Turkey in the southern Caucasus. This is unacceptable! And the second conclusion, Mr Borrell, we need the European Union in this conflict. This is one of those conflicts in which we can play an active role and develop what is European foreign policy and it is a pity that we are referring the solution of this conflict to other bodies when we have the full capacity to be credible mediators with Armenia and Azerbaijan.

name: Петър Витанов (S&D).
text: – Mr President, High Representative, this morning, as I was on my way to the Chamber, I saw young Armenians with the national flag. On the other side, azerbaijanis probably gather. I hope these people help us understand all those dangers that arise from this conflict, because I believe that there are several types of risks. First, for the transformation of this regional conflict, I would say, into an interstate one – there are already indications that it has overstepped the area of Noorni Karabakh. To turn it into a regional war, given Turkey's belligerent rhetoric, mercenaries, jihadists already there, and Russia's presence in Armenia. And, of course, become an element of global opposition.  How serious the situation is, we see from the common position of the UNITED States, Russia and France. An unconditional and immediate ceasefire is also needed here. It is the responsibility of THE UNITED STATES, which together in dialogue with Russia, through the reconciliation of Turkey and with the participation of the European Union through France, as co-chair of the Ming Group, to find solutions to restore the negotiation process.

name: Λουκάς Φουρλάς (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr Borrell, the images arriving from the international agencies near us are harsh and relentless. Dead Azerbaijani civilians and forces backed by Turkish military, military helicopters, drones and mercenary jihadists are celebrating the occupation of territory. I'm really wondering how much longer we're going to equate the abuser with the victim. Azerbaijan and Turkey are attacking and the Armenians in Ngorno Karabakh are defending themselves. Reaches! No tolerance! Let everyone who backs Erdogan and Aliyev understand that they are rearing a monster that we will one day find in front of us.  Yesterday, Mr Erdogan spat in Europe's face and opened Up Varoshi, the occupied Varoshi, unpunished by the European Union, and the responsibilities here for some are unsying. We stand next to the Armenian people. 105 years after the genocide, Turkey and its ally Aliyev are once again on the path of the Armenian people. But this time they're going to find us all in front of them.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D).
text: Mr President, since 27 September a war has been raging at the gates of the European Union. The Azerbaijani army attacked Nagorno-Karabakh as it had attacked Armenia last July. I will first have an emotional thought for the civilian populations, terrified, wounded, killed by the raids. After long days of astonishment, the international community has finally begun to move. The ECHR has ruled as a matter of urgency, and the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe has been very clear about Turkey's interference in the conflict. Our message must therefore be perfectly clear: an immediate cessation of fighting, because the escalation of hostilities endangers the security of the entire region, and total firmness towards Turkey, which is stoking and exploiting the conflict, including by paying Syrian mercenaries. And finally, for many years, the OSCE Minsk Group has been talking about creating a path to peace. Its efforts will need to be much more determined to prevent the history of the Armenian genocide from being repeated. The European Union must be at the forefront for a peaceful settlement to emerge.

name: Geoffroy Didier (PPE).
text: Mr President, after Syria, Libya and the eastern Mediterranean, the Turkish Government is methodically pursuing its political and cultural expansionism, this time in the Nagorno-Karabakh region. The Turkish leader is stoking already high regional tensions and, a century after a genocide, is causing new victims, especially Armenian ones.  In the face of these actions, I ask the European Parliament: where is Europe, Commissioner? What are the effective, firm responses to this nationalist and conquering leader who, at the gates of Europe, is flouting our values and principles?  With many parliamentarians at my side, including the French EPP delegation, I have said and I repeat it here, it is not permissible that Europe has still not definitively abandoned the process of Turkey's accession to the European Union. This abandonment, and not just the suspension, is now a requirement for a simple reason: Europe is not a toy and our values, our principles, what underpins our civilization and our cultural heritage, are not negotiated.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (PPE).
text: Mr President, I consider Mr Borrell to be a leading and experienced politician and before he is happy for my kind words, I will tell him that top and experienced politicians are for the hard, the very difficult. In my view, therefore, it must take the initiative to impose a European embargo on the sale of weapons systems to Turkey, because we see Turkey's role in The North Karabakh, and we see it more generally in Syria, Libya, the Eastern Mediterranean.  My proposal is not particularly original, because already Canada, which has supplied the technology for Turkish drones used in the war between Azeri and Armenians, has imposed an export freeze, albeit belatedly. You will ask me what will happen to jobs, for example in Spain, where a Turkish aircraft carrier is being built. I think the solution to these issues is a common European defence policy.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Azerbaijan, in violation of the ceasefire agreement and international law, suddenly and unselfingly, attacked the Armenians of Nagorno Karabakh, assisted by Syrian terrorists and with the firm, visible support and support of Turkey. History, ladies and gentlemen, is relentless and penniless towards us. Humanity a century ago was indifferent to the criminal actions of the Neo-Turks, and these led to the Armenian genocide and the genocide of the Pontus Greeks. History has listed us in the black pages of the genocide, but at the same time it has also registered those who were criminally indifferent when they took place. It is a historic duty of the European Union, but also a supreme duty, to stop the criminal activities of the Turks and the Azeri against our Armenian brothers.  What is the European Union doing, dear Mr Borrell, today? The wonderful and proud Armenian people, with their long historical presence and their enormous contribution to culture and humanity, deserve and deserve our firm support. That is why today, from the European Parliament, from the heart of Europe, freedom and democracy, I call on you to send a strong message. All of us, with one voice, today, are spreading and claiming that we are all Armenians! We stand next to Armenia and next to the struggling, tested Armenian people, against the Azeri and the Turks.

name: Anna-Michelle Asimakopoulou (PPE).
text: Mr President, just a few minutes ago a historic decision by the Greek judiciary on the neo-Nazi Golden Dawn party was announced. Condemning the fascist form of Golden Dawn as a criminal organisation is a victory for democracy itself. At the crucial moment, my party, the New Democracy, with the former Prime Minister of Greece, Antonis Samaras, had the courage and found a way to face Golden Dawn, paving the way for justice to do its duty today. Europe in the past has been slow to find the courage and the way to deal with Hitler, and the result has been the Holocaust of the Jews.
