And now, while the international community is calling for a ceasefire in Nagorno Karabakh, only Erdogan says he will support the Azeris against the Armenians in every possible way. And I ask, Mr Borrell, what does he say 'in every possible way' when the President of a country that does not even recognise the atrocity and horrific crime against humanity posed by the Armenian genocide says so? So let us not repeat the mistakes of the past, let us finally find the courage and the way to deal with Erdogan before it is too late.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Mr President, Vice-President Borrell, the conflict in Nagorno Karabakh is being encouraged carelessly by Turkey and costs tens, hundreds of civilian lives, because in Nagorno Karabakh there is an attempt to exterminate the Armenian population, that many people who have stood up to history and are working peacefully, who have taken root there, while Turkey does not recognise genocide.  Mr Vice-President, there are cluster bombs in Nagorno Karabakh, there are civilians killed in Nagorno Karabakh, there are fighters funded by Turkey who came from Syria to Nagorno Karabakh, and if we have the first impression that Turkey is opposed to Russia in the region, ultimately Turkey and Russia serve the same objective: to limit the diversification of the European Union's energy sources. So our findings and calls for de-escalation are not enough. We, as the European Union, must be actively involved in the Caucasus region, in the light of our principles, and defend our interests. Someone said here it was time to close the wounds of history. Above all, it is time for the Armenian people to be granted what is theirs in the post-Soviet era: their rights.

name: Josep Borrell Fontelles
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their interesting and engaging remarks. I think your message is clear. It has been repeated 65 times, with different voices, but expressing the same concern and the same request to act. Next Monday, I will bring your voice to the Foreign Affairs Council in Luxembourg, where we will have to follow up on the situation and see what we can decide about it.  But the European Council has made it very clear that they consider that the frame in which to mediate and to act on this conflict is the OSCE Minsk Group Co—Chairs. This was clearly what the European Council said. They asked me to support the work of the OSCE Minsk Group Co—Chairs. That’s what we are doing. But we have to allow this group of people to work because it is the only group that is being recognised by the two sides. I think that Mr Bütikofer is right when he says that there are some new things in this conflict. One is that the Americans are withdrawing and Turkey is taking a stronger, much more assertive, position. The European Council also discussed the relationship with Turkey – and I invite you to listen to the conclusions of the European Council – and said that, in December, we will take stock of the evolution of the situation in the Eastern Mediterranean and all the conflicts in which Turkey is more or less involved in order to take decisions on how we continue our relationship with the country. We are going to continue calling for a ceasefire and I will bring your voice to the Foreign Affairs Council of Ministers. We will remind both sides of the obligation to protect civilians under international humanitarian law and keep working with Turkey in order to build a constructive contribution to the conflict settlement and help the efforts to stop the hostilities.  We have a Special Representative for the South Caucasus, who is there and who is in touch with both sides. Yesterday, the Turkish Minister was in Baku and I was really concerned when I saw that he was expressing full support for Azerbaijan. My last talk with the Azerbaijan Minister was also very worrying because he was clearly saying that the fight will continue until Armenia accepts a concrete schedule for withdrawing from Nagorno—Karabakh, which is a precondition for talks. It is very difficult. The situation is becoming worse and worse. All of you have been asking us to act, but I’ve been hearing very few concrete versions of the verb ‘act’. What do you mean by ‘act’? We can do what we can do, but this is the way that we have to take this situation. We’ll do whatever we can do in order, as I said, to support the OSCE Minsk Group Co-Chairs, which is the frame that the European Council decided to support in order to look for a negotiated solution, pushing both sides to end the fighting, and especially putting pressure on Turkey not to continue intervening.  But by act if you mean take military action, that is completely out of the question. We are going to do what we can do as the European Union with the resources that we have on the diplomatic arena, and wait for December, as decided by the European Council, and see what happens from now until December to review our relationship with Turkey. This is what the European Council decided after a long discussion on Turkey and our relations with Turkey and I have to stick to that. I will obey, and I will try to implement, the mandate of the European Council in order to support the OSCE Minsk Group Co-Chairs that I hope this week will have meetings with the Foreign Affairs Minister of Azerbaijan and I hope also with Armenia.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. – The safety of our citizens is a priority for all of us in Europe. To do this, it is important to maintain stability, security and peace in the region in our neighbourhood. The number one goal must be to stop the fighting. The parties must conclude a ceasefire and return to the negotiating table, the violence can lead nowhere, only through peaceful negotiations can the situation be resolved. The EU must support steps towards peace. Our shared responsibility is to guard stability, especially when the conflict unfolds in a region close to us, which, in addition to human lives, can trigger new waves of migration.

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE)
text: in writing. – I am genuinely concerned about the rapid development of the armed conflict over Nagorno-Karabakh and believe that the only way to end the escalation is to end hostilities and begin to seek the resolve of the conflict by diplomatic means. The conflict claims lives of innocent people, hampers the development of the whole region and threatens European energy stability. I would like to emphasise that the armed conflict can only be resolved peacefully and in accordance with the principles of international law and the Basic Principles of the OSCE Minsk Group. It is important that both parties to the conflict, Armenia and Azerbaijan, enter into negotiations for a peaceful solution to the conflict at the highest level.

name: Gheorghe-Vlad Nistor (PPE)
text: in writing. – The state of conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan in Nagorno Karabakh is escalating with every passing day. I cannot stress the importance of the South Caucasus for the European Union enough, as we have managed to construct partnerships with most countries from that region. Its volatility should be of greatest concern to the EU; we must be an active part of the process that will secure a ceasefire and a lasting peace between those two countries. This future agreement must also settle the status of Nagorno Karabakh, with highest regard to both international law and the realities on the ground. Far too many unresolved disputes and frozen conflicts are scattered in the European Union’s neighbourhood. These can easily turn violent and can fall under the influence of countries with unfriendly attitudes towards our Union. The main causes behind most frozen conflicts in the region are the actions of Russia, under all its historical avatars. We are also concerned about Turkey’s implication in this long-lasting dispute. Its support for one of the sides has the capacity to prolong and intensify this conflict. Today we are witnessing the legacies generated by painful historical abuse and a continuum of poisonous interference.

name: Janina Ochojska (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh, which we are witnessing, is in fact the result of a frozen conflict which has not been resolved for many years and that no proper negotiations have been undertaken leading to the conclusion of the dispute. As a result, civilians are killed before our eyes, their homes are destroyed, and many of them become refugees who, in search of safe haven outside their place of residence, abandon their belongings all their lives. We all want an end to the escalation of the conflict and the start of negotiations, and the prospect of war is of particular concern to us.  It is clear that the issue of Nagorno-Karabakh requires immediate action. I would like to draw attention to the fact that the issues of so-called 'frozen' conflicts are only hotly discussed when there is an increase in action, including military action. I would therefore like to propose that we pay more attention to such conflicts, especially as some of them are in the immediate vicinity of the EU. I propose that we already support negotiations between the parties to the disputes before further conflicts escalate.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – The Azerbaijani invasion of Dohoná Karabakh has already claimed several hundred lives, including the civilian population. Churches and cultural monuments are being destroyed. The international community, including the European Union, should not stand by, but must actively push for an end to the fighting and an investigation into possible crimes. Violence is never the solution, it can only be found at the negotiating table.

name: Bettina Vollath (S&D)
text: Writing. – For more than a week, europe's forecourt has been under new old war – and hardly anyone talks about it. Armed clashes between Armenia and Azerbaijan have been going on for ten days. The subject of the conflict: the Nagorno-Karabakh region. More than 286 people have been killed in the fighting there so far, at least 46 of them civilians. The population of Nagorno-Karabakh has been suffering from this conflict for decades, which is now reaching a sad climax once again. It is estimated that more than half of the approximately 75,000 inhabitants of Nagorno-Karabakh have already had to flee the fighting. If these continue, even more people will probably be forced to leave their homes. So that this horrible statistic does not contain ever higher figures, people need a ceasefire immediately! Both sides must cease hostilities and respect the 1994 ceasefire agreement. We also call on all foreign parties to immediately end their interference in the conflict. Foreign aggressors such as Turkey must not send mercenary troops from Syria to the combat zone and continue to pour oil on the fire. Instead, both parties must support the project of the Minsk Group of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) to resume negotiations as soon as possible. The aim is therefore clear: to end fighting, to protect human lives and to resume negotiations.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the EU diplomatic mission in Venezuela with a view to possible elections (2020/2810(RSP)). The approach to blue cards and spontaneous speeches is the same as in the other debates.

name: Josep Borrell Fontelles
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I think I can speak in Spanish because I believe that the majority of members who are going to follow this debate speak Spanish very well. So, if you don't mind, I will use the Spanish language, which, after all, is the second most spoken language in the world. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this House has already dealt many times with the various crises which hit Venezuela. And the gradual collapse of what was once one of the richest countries in the Western world, in the Western Hemisphere, is today one of the great tragedies of our time, so I can only share your interest and concern about the situation in which the people of Venezuela are located. And not only Venezuela, but the entire region, which is affected by the extraordinary number of people who have left that country. We know the situation in Venezuela: how Venezuelan society is deeply fractured, also politically. Even the opposition itself does not have the necessary unity to deal with this dramatic situation; a situation that has been well described to us by the recent reports of the investigative mission and, above all, by the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights. And it is obvious to say ⸺ we have said many times⸺ that we condemn the violation of human rights in Venezuela and for this reason it is why we have been working with the civil society of that country for a long time and in particular during this summer.  I am not going to dwell on explaining the political situation in Venezuela — you know it well — but I want to focus my speech on the title of the appeal and explain to you the developments since last July, when we started a task, in coordination with the Member States of the European Union and with the support of the Latin American partners of the International Contact Group, to try to help find a democratic and peaceful solution to the situation that Venezuela is going through. And the first step in trying to ⸺intent, I say right⸺ to try⸺ to get out of the political strimate in which Venezuela is located was to promote the framework for credible legislative elections, if such a thing were possible. But believe me, I haven't thrown myself into the ring like a spontaneous one, armed with my simple little mule. I started doing so because this was requested by the G4, led by President Guaidó, to transfer to the regime the minimum conditions that the opposition deemed necessary to be able to participate in a credible electoral process. So I did and, throughout the month of August, throughout the summer, I have maintained contacts by videoconference, telephones, both with the G4 and with other opposition leaders, such as, of course, with Mr Maduro's Government, and I have made public statements, both in formal for a and at the ministerial meeting of the International Contact Group, which took place on the return of summer on 17 September, and at the Foreign Affairs Council on 21 September. During The month of August, I issued statements explaining that the conditions were not given so that the elections called for 6 December could be regarded as free and participatory, but at the same time I insisted both on the Government and the opposition that they should try to find an approximation of their positions in order to make possible an election in which the European Union could participate as an observer. All this information is public and has always been public. On the return of summer, one of the opposition leaders, Mr. Capriles, He expressed his intention to participate in the elections if the conditions for this were met, at the same time as others, starting with President Guaidó himself, already considered it impossible that this could happen, but they were not against an attempt to extend the electoral deadline in order to be able to continue negotiating and to be able to continue to consider the possibility of an electoral observation on our part, which could only happen, as you know very well, if the conditions for this were previously met.  At the contact group meeting and in the Foreign Affairs Council I had the greatest support to continue contacts with the Government to see if it was possible to agree on an extension of the electoral deadline, as an essential condition for anything else, because, as you know, an election observation mission first goes on to send an election exploration mission, which returns with a report on whether or not the conditions necessary to be able to send an observation mission are met. The decision to send the observation mission is preceded by an exploration mission that analyses the situation on the ground, and that takes a minimum of five or six months and therefore any attempt was inconsistent with the date of December 6. It was therefore necessary to explore the possibility, with which everyone agreed, that these elections should be postponed. And, to speed up contacts, which I ⸺insisto⸺ have been developing by phone and videoconference for three months, I decided to send two officials from our External Action Service to contact all political actors on the ground and see what the state of the situation was. This has created a certain strangeness in some of the honourable Members, as if it were something new. But this is a totally common diplomatic practice. During the past year there were three missions of the International Contact Group with various formats, all led by a senior official of the European Union and with the same objective as the latter. The Norwegian Government, with which we have collaborated, has also sent several missions to try to unlock political stagnation, the latter also over the past summer. This mission, before leaving, informed the Member States of the European Union in writing, so that the thing about calling it clandestine..., come on, that I know the clandestine activities are not communicated in writing to all Member States before they take place. And in Venezuela these two senior officials met with a wide range of representatives from sectors. They spoke and listened to more than seventy people. To be secret, there has been no problem spreading its activity as much as has been necessary. Of course, they met with the President of the National Assembly, Mr. Guaidó, president in charge of the country, who supported efforts to help achieve, to try to achieve, an electoral postponement, being very skeptical about it. They met with all opposition forces, starting with the G4. The representatives of this group insisted on the necessary conditions for democratic and transparent elections, which I was brought forward with and which I myself conveyed to the Government during my contacts in July and August. And they also held talks with Mr. Guaidó's former chief of staff, Mr Roberto Marrero, recently released from prison and who unfortunately has not been allowed to come to Spain, as was his wish. They also met with Don Henrique Capriles and two of his colleagues. They urged the European Union to keep all channels of communication open and to take this opportunity to avoid, try to avoid, for Venezuela to move even further into political and social chaos that plagues it. They had the opportunity to meet with two representatives of the Maduro regime, Minister Rodriguez and Miranda State Governor Hector Rodriguez, in response to the regime's invitation to the European Union to observe the December elections. Yes, we had a specific request; this is the first time the European Union has been asked to observe the elections. First, they called for an election accompanying mission. We explain that such a thing did not exist, that the European Union has a rules of procedure, established, which does not accompany it, which it observes. And that, as I have told you, goes through a very careful process of, first, an exploration and then, where appropriate, observation. We explained that if they wanted to study the possibilities of an election observation mission, we had to go through this process and that this inevitably led to a delay, because otherwise we had nothing to talk about.  The officials posted there were not there to negotiate, but simply to convey this important message to all political sectors and receive their response. Contacts were also maintained with representatives of the so-called National Dialogue Table and henri Falcón. It was the only group against the postponement of the election. They held meetings with the Venezuelan Episcopal Conference, which plays a key role in society, and which they already know has called for the opposition to participate in the electoral process and in providing assistance to the Venezuelan people in the face of the current humanitarian crisis. The representatives of the Episcopal Conference, as they had stated by letter published a few weeks ago, warned that, if the opportunity to run for this election were to pass, the vacant political space and full control of all institutions would be left to the Maduro regime. They met with partners in civil society, academia and the business world. And I believe that in Caracas there was broad support for the work of this mission and the european Union's efforts to help achieve the space needed for dialogue, which remains our objective. Because the European Union is regarded by all or most partners as the only actor who can talk to all factions and who can do it with credibility. And that is what we are trying to do is to defend a Union with a geopolitical dimension. The other clear message we received is that the vast majority of the opposition would support a postponement of elections to allow time to improve the conditions under which elections could be held, which might have allowed us to send an election observation mission. But the predominant view is that while clearly the decision to postpone elections alone is not a solution, it would be a way to keep the door open to political negotiation. However, as you know, the Government, after that mission, has responded in a clear and resounding manner, saying that in no way will the elections be postponed because the Venezuelan Constitution prevents it, as there is a very clear mandate that they must be done on a certain date, before the end of this year, which , obviously, it closes any possibility for the dialogue to continue in the perspective I have explained to you before. We believe that the only way out of the impasse Venezuela is in will be through dialogue and political negotiation between Venezuelan forces. There will not be a single cathartic event that will make the many crises that hit the country disappear. And our role, our will, is to help find a way that responds to the needs and demands of the Venezuelan people. And, after what has happened and I have listened to each other, and in particular, having received, not in response to our letters, which responded to theirs, but as public statements, the message that the elections will not be postponed, the European Union will obviously not even be able to consider, or even consider, the sending of the election observation mission. This would require not only respect for democratic standards, which, as I have stated on several occasions, are not given or continue to be given, since it has not been possible to change them, but also, as I have explained, a realistic timetable. I believe that the press release of the Maduro regime, which refuses to postpone the elections on the grounds that it cannot do so by constitutional mandate, only serves to make the political situation in Venezuela worse. We will continue to support all efforts to make a political, peaceful and democratic exit from the crisis that the Venezuelan people are suffering, so that they can overcome it as they deserve.

name: Dolors Montserrat
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Mr Borrell, we are concerned to know that you, as Vice-President and High Representative — by the way, both positions cannot be dissociate — on 23 September sent a Semi-Island mission to negotiate with the Maduro dictatorship the postponement of elections. Seven days earlier, the devastating United Nations report accusing Maduro's regime of human rights violations and crimes against humanity was published, which you have hardly mentioned. Six days earlier, you met with the Contact Group, which gives you the mandate to explore the delay of fraudulent elections in Venezuela. Three days earlier, you met with eu foreign ministers, to which you explained this mandate, but in both meetings you avoided mentioning any mission. So I ask you: when did you organize the clandestine mission? Perhaps when the regime conveys concern about this devastating United Nations report? Did the regime ask you for a political gesture? The exchange was: you send them a diplomatic mission and the regime delays elections and you guarantee them an exploratory mission for those future elections? And all this without a single condition; doesn't require a presidential election. Without presidential, we didn't leave the regime. It does not even require them to immediately release all political prisoners, nor the return of forced exiles, nor the cessation of repression.  We are very concerned that you have not informed the clandestine mission or the ministers of the twenty-seven, the Commission, or this Parliament, but even more serious is that you have ignored the Venezuelan Democrats represented by President Juan Guaidó, recognised by this Parliament and 25 Member States.  A chain of lies and half-truths do not make a truth, but confirmation that it hides deeply undemocratic contacts. Don't offer us disguises today, tell us the whole truth. The mission has been the means, the instrument to whiten the regime, weaken and divide those who oppose Maduro, and the end result will be a new hoax by Maduro, which will prolong the suffering of the Venezuelan people with more violence, more poverty and less freedom. The EU cannot contribute in any way to this, ever.

name: Javi López
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, first of all, what I would like to do is, on behalf of myself and on behalf of my group, to defend and celebrate all the efforts that the high representative and European diplomacy can make to find a peaceful, democratic way out of the serious situation in the country, Venezuela, which, at the same time, , has terrible humanitarian and regional derivatives. Because it is the only way out and because it is the European position, and for that, of course, diplomacy and dialogue to find a way out with democratic conditions — which, as has been explained today, are not the only way out.  Secondly, I would like to reflect with you on the fact that, very often, in this House, we make crosses and regret the irrelevance we have in the conflicts in our neighbourhood, to find a way out—we say this very often. As it turns out that we have a conflict like Venezuela's, a very serious situation like Venezuela's, where we are given the capacity to dialogue to play a constructive role, and there, where we can act and when we act, we find false prefabricated controversies. That's the reality.  Thirdly, this Parliament cares a lot about Venezuela. We have made six debates as far as we have been in the legislature, thirteen Resolutions in five years; there's been nothing we've debated so much: that indicates he cares. But not only that: I want to say that many times there is a spurio use, as a political battering ram, but more thinking about national, Spanish politics — you only need to see the list of participants — and not thinking about the prestige of this house, nor, obviously, venezuelans and Venezuelans and their pain.

name: Jordi Cañas
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, Mr Borrell, we asked for your appearance before this House to give us explanations, we expected excuses. But he hasn't told the truth, too. And that's key. Do you know why? Because he did not send or ask the opposition to stand before the regime to call an election or postpone them; it was at your request, guaidó and the G4 did not ask for it, you proposed it. And if you start by making an argument missing the truth, we have a problem, because everything else falls.  Everything else falls: it was you who proposed, after having conversations with the regime, that the opposition give you minimum conditions to participate in fraudulent elections, because Mr Maduro's government does not have the capacity to call them, because remember that it is an illegitimate government. The opposition— as you systematically call it, confronting that government — is what this House recognizes as a legitimate government, and the National Assembly as Venezuela's only democratic body.  So, after receiving the umpteenth not from the regime in August, you propose a mission in September — without knowledge, until they are flying, from the opposition — so that it is not known what to offer the regime again. Yes: defer fraudulent elections without having the minimum conditions to be held. What do you get out of that? To send a very bad message to the whole of Venezuela: that it is intended to reach an agreement with the one who has no legitimacy to call an election.  Finally, Mr Borrell, look, as you know, on 5 January the mandate of the House expires. That's what maduro's government expects because it's going to be hands-free. So the question is: will you, since the elections of 6 December will not be democratic and your results will not be recognized, will support the constitutional continuity of the mandate of the present Assembly until true free and democratic elections can be held in Venezuela? That should be the European Union's strategy: to guarantee the Assembly as the only democratic body in force until true free and democratic elections can be held in Venezuela.

name: Thierry Mariani
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, Venezuela is a subject that comes up in this Chamber as frequently as the rain in Brussels or the compromises between the EPP and the Socialists. I said in December 2019 that the policy of Nicols Maduro was not mine, and the policy of American sanctions that impoverishes the Venezuelan population either. The European Union should have a different, calm voice that does not plunge into utilitarianism or collectivism. In the debate last July, I thus justify my vote on the amendments concerning Venezuelan migrants: I abstained because the text lacked balance and supported Juan Guaid as the European Union's candidate for the leadership of Venezuela, while it is up to the people of that country to find the political compromises necessary to return to calm. And in January 2019, I insisted: "Are U.S. sanctions helping the Venezuelan people? On the contrary, do they not prove that behind humanitarian displays lies a political will to exercise cultural and economic hegemony in this part of the world?" Since then, nothing has changed! Six debates. 13 resolutions. Today, Parliament has simply added a debate that will not change anything, that will not progress to anything and that will bring no new elements.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I have the impression that, once again, we are discussing Venezuela thinking more about the strategies of opposition to the Government of Spain than in a serious debate about what the European Union has to do in this case.  And, look, I hear you, actually, and my problem is, I don't know what they're proposing. Practically in January two years ago Mr Guaidó's reconnaissance operation , which, by the way, I would remind you that he has not been recognised by the European Union , and where did that take them? What are they proposing? The only solution I say to you: that is what the high representative is trying to do, which is to sit at a table in opposition and government to hold a free election and recognized by both sides. It's the only solution. By the way, with a mission that is a mechanism — as the high representative has rightly explained - usual of European diplomacy, and we need more missions like these to be carried out.  And one last thing, let me, to the Spanish delegations of the People's Party and Renew: it seems to me a somewhat strange way to defend democracy in the world by signing letters addressed to our institutions together with the Spanish far right; the bad way to defend democracy in the world is to do initiatives here with those who attack democracy within our borders.

name: Hermann Tertsch
text: ECR Group. – Mr President, here the only ones who attack democracy, because they defend a dictatorship, a narcocomunistic dictatorship, murderous and crimes against humanity, as the un suspicious Bachelet has just referred to in the United Nations, are you, are the parties of the Government in Spain. And that's a disgrace, and that's also the source of suspicion. It is the source of the suspicion that exists and alarms venezuela, and that alarms all Democrats who want to change Venezuela and want Maduro's criminal regime to fall.  Because Maduro's criminal regime can't be perpetuated. We can't let it be perpetuated by elections that are going to be a sham, because there can't be a right choice with Maduro in power. And yet, here it has been organized, on the part of the Government of Spain and, unfortunately, many suspect that with Mr Borrell's help, a farce to seek an election that perpetuates Maduro, because with Maduro in power there can be no free elections in Venezuela. And whoever intends to do so is scamming Europe, is ripping off Venezuelans and is ripping off the world.

name: Manu Pineda
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Mr Borrell, here we are again talking about Venezuela, as almost every House, although you and I know that this debate in substance is not about Venezuela, it is about the distorted view of democracy in the Spanish right and far right, and about the role that the European Union wants to play in foreign relations. They organise this debate not because the European Union has sent a mission to continue dialogue with Venezuela, but because they do not recognize democracy, rights, diplomacy, or dialogue. And what's the alternative they're asking us? That of the Member who preceded me in the debate that called for military intervention against the Spanish Government because he does not recognize the results of the elections in Spain? Is that the alternative they're asking us? Only violence is raised as a method. Given that many of those who have promoted this debate have declared the Spanish Government illegitimate, what might be next? May a recognition of Mr Married as President-in-Charge of Spain be brought here because last week he met with a number of ambassadors from the European Union? Mr Borrell, beware of feeding the beast, go ahead with the dialogue, although it will cost you criticism and some other absurd debate in this Parliament. Keep in mind that here the most undemocratic positions are gaining ground every day. I tell you one thing: there will be elections, not that there is possibly going to be elections, there will be elections on December 6th in Venezuela, democratic and clean elections, as for more than twenty years. And there is no confessable motive... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Presidente. –
text: You're done with your time. Let's get on with the debate. You've long exceeded your time.

name: Hermann Tertsch (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I have been charged with nothing less than promoting a coup d'am in Spain. I don't think it's ballad. That's strictly a lie. I have always called for strict compliance in our country with the Constitution by all institutions. I defend the Constitution in Spain. Not that gentleman. That man is an ally of terrorists, coup plotters and so on... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Presidente. –
text: The honourable colleague had the opportunity to speak at the end of the debate if he understood on that occasion to make the defence of honour. I believe that it has done so now and, therefore, we continue with the speeches.

name: Antonio Tajani (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we must be consistent, we cannot defend the rule of law within our Union and in Belarus, and then we cannot defend it in Venezuela. Maduro's regime has been found guilty by the UN of crimes against humanity. And you, Mr Vice-President, authorised a mission to deal with this dictator: but that mission was resolved by a farce that served in fact to support Maduro, since the trip was organized together with the regime. ¿Sabe usted lo que es La Carlota? La Carlota es una base aérea militar en el centro de Caracas, que solo utilizan como pista de aterrizaje los aviones del régimen y los aviones privados que el régimen autoriza.  ¿Cómo es posible que una misión de la Unión Europea haya podido utilizar ese aeropuerto militar? ¿Existe pues mayor prueba de que su viaje se preparó y se organizó en connivencia con el régimen de Maduro que el hecho de que su delegación se planteara la posibilidad de aterrizar en La Carlota? ¿Aterrizaron at last? ¿O dónde aterrizó el avión privado? ¿Quién contrató ese avión? ¿Estaría dispuesto a enseñar las facturas del pago de ese vuelo?  What goals did this journey achieve? Is Maduro committed to ensuring a transparent vote, monitored by third parties? The use of fingerprints or software? Legalisation of parties and leaders who oppose dictatorship, free electoral rallies? Have you reassured us that the regime will stop illegally funding European parties that are in government, as in Italy and Spain, as has been reported in some journalistic investigations? The key point, to conclude, Mr President, is that Maduro is trying not to have presidential elections, on the pretext of having elections to renew the Legislative Assembly. But the Legislative Assembly has already been renewed and Maduro's party has lost! Now we have to vote to elect the new Head of State!

name: Maria-Manuel Leitão-Marques (S&D).
text: – Mr President, today we should be discussing the impact of Covid on Latin America, as proposed by the Socialists and Democrats. The public health problems that worsened, the unemployment it caused, the inequalities it deepened and the despair and lack of hope it left behind. About one in three coronavirus deaths worldwide are in Latin America, totaling more than 300,000 victims.  We should discuss what help we can mobilize for this region with which we have so many historical ties. We should look at the regression that this crisis has caused in the fight against poverty, with the loss of progress in a decade in just six months. We should think about how we can not leave behind the thousands of children who have been left without school, who have no Internet, nor parents at home who can teach them.  But no, none of this seemed urgent to the political groups on our right. They exchanged this debate for another discussion on the political crisis in Venezuela, the gravity of which I do not intend to ignore, without a new proposal, a new idea, which will allow us to emerge from the impasse that has come, just because the Vice-President and High Representative developed a life-long attempt to have fair and free elections maintaining a path of dialogue. This is a decision that does not dignify Parliament, does not help Venezuela, much less Latin America.

name: Dita Charanzová (Renew).
text: – Mr President, Mr High Representative, how is it possible for this House, the European Parliament, to learn through the press of its mission to Caracas, its mission to negotiate with the dictatorship? Is this the European Union's new foreign policy on Venezuela? No, it's not. It's not. You, the high representative, acted independently. Later, you said in the press that the Venezuelan opposition commissioned you to negotiate with the dictatorship. Well, I ask you now: who specifically in charge of the opposition took care of it? So far, in all my contacts with President Guaidó's representatives and the democratic opposition, I have heard nothing about that request.  I want to make it clear to the democratic forces in Venezuela, to all our friends in Venezuela, that, first, the European Parliament does not recognise Maduro and recognises that there cannot be a transitional government with him. We recognize Juan Guaidó as venezuela's legitimate interim president. Secondly, until free presidential elections are held under the necessary conditions, progress cannot be made with legislative measures. The European Parliament has always been very clear about its position on Venezuela. Actions like this undermine efforts to act as a European Union jointly and crediblely on the world stage.

name: Paolo Borchia (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Solana, I cannot hide my dismay at such a renouncing approach to this issue. Today, more than 5 million Venezuelans live outside the borders, forced to flee by starvation and repression, cynically transformed into weapons of control of power by the regime. The World Bank calls an individual living on around EUR 2 per day 'poor': currently in Venezuela the minimum wage is not even half, with the International Monetary Fund estimating inflation at 15 000 % for 2020. I would also like to send a message from this House of closeness and solidarity to the Italian and European citizens living in Maduro's Venezuela, a country without drinking water, without gas, without fuel, without industry, without more resources or hope. And when we talk about sanctions, ladies and gentlemen, let us remember that the Venezuelan people suffer a very heavy one on a daily basis: this sanction is called communism.

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Borrell, I must admit that I do not know why we are doing this debate, I do not understand why certain forces, namely the right and far-right forces of this House, are questioning the European Union sending through the European External Action Service a prospective delegation, whose mission is to try to find a democratic and peaceful solution to the complicated situation , delicate, worrying, living in Venezuela.  Are you really questioning whether the European Union plays a constructive role? Diplomatic? Do you know what diplomacy is about? They know perfectly well, they know that with respect to all the conflicts in the world. We have just had a debate on the Azerbaijan-Armenian conflict and many of us have called for greater involvement of the European Union. We always ask for a strengthened role of the European Union as a global player, exporting European values, but when we arrive in Venezuela the opposite effect of the magnet occurs. You go to extremes and throw Venezuela in the head. Normally the representatives of the Spanish state because it has internal policy interests. No, the solution to Venezuela's problem will lie with its people, its institutions, but the European Union must do everything in its power to help find these solutions.

name: Carlo Fidanza (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the meantime, I would like to clear up a misunderstanding: this is not a debate on Spanish domestic politics. We are talking about this serious fact because it concerns the entire international community, the United Nations, the free world that opposes this criminal dictatorship. If someone on the left has not yet understood it, perhaps you would do well to update your message and understand that we are dealing with a problem that affects the whole world, as well as the Venezuelan people. We have heard serious words, Mr Vice-President, because they may be part of the truth, but certainly not the whole truth. We have seen a mission of senior EU officials which has ended up further legitimising the Maduro regime as an interlocutor. So, once again, we are calling loudly for free, democratic and transparent presidential elections and for the abandonment of power by Maduro, whose anarcho-communist regime has been responsible for serious crimes, including a real humanitarian emergency, recalling, in these few seconds, the millions of refugees, real refugees, who are fleeing this dictatorship. Among them also hundreds of thousands of Italians of origin or passport to whom I want to send a fraternal embrace.

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, despite threats and blackmail, pressure and destabilisation, blockades and sanctions, all outside international law, the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela is organising an electoral process within its constitution for the next 6 December for presidential and parliamentary elections.  Unfortunately, once again the European Union, by refusing to participate as an election observer, prefers to side with those who architect coups and orchestrate farces to promote a self-appointed president who was not chosen by the people, but by the Trump administration. What is needed at the moment is that the European Union demands respect for the functioning of Venezuelan democratic institutions and does not align in coups that daily violate the rights and living conditions of the Venezuelan people and the Venezuelan Portuguese community. What is needed is the end of the blockade that so many trials have dictated to that people, particularly in times of COVID-19, making it difficult to access essential goods and medicines, that is, the right to life and health.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr High Representative, not strange, do you not think it is strange that here only those who support the Maduro regime are defending their clandestine or semi-clandestine visit? That says everything about the meaning of this visit and i have already turned here to the Members of the Greens, Mr Urtasun, this is not a Spanish issue and look that in the EPP I have a Dutch, an Italian, a Spanish, a Portuguese speaking, it is a question of human rights, it is a question of democracy. Do you always have human rights and democracy in your mouths accept a visit from the High Representative who will legitimise a regime that has just been condemned as a regime that has crimes against humanity? And so I say to Mrs Leitão Marques how is it possible to come here and say that this debate is not relevant after the United Nations Human Rights Council says that the regime commits crimes against humanity? How is that possible? For God's sake, one thinks of children and refugees you also have to think of those who are the subject of crimes against humanity and this debate is totally pertinent whether the European Union is legitimising, or whitening, or giving at least some breath to a regime that commits crimes against humanity. Señor alto representante, le voy ahora a contestar en la lengua de Cervantes, con un dicho español. Después de escucharle le diré: yo no creo en las brujas, mas que las hay, las hay.

name: Nacho Sánchez Amor (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the debate on the substance of the Venezuelan issue would be interesting, the problem is that what brings this debate here is the sending of the mission and that is a storm in a glass of water.  Look: Montserrat, López, Cañas, Urtasun, Tertsch, Pineda, Solé, Sánchez, Bilbao, Nart, López Gil, López and Millán, this is not a Spanish debate. This is again that the Spanish right has dragged the European right into a debate that should take place in the Spanish Courts. And the problem is not that Mr Borrell has separated a single centimeter from the European position. The problem is that you are sliding into the American position, as some of them have done from that part (inaudible words).  I'm just going to say one very simple thing: if Mr Borrell were to be called Dombrovskis, we wouldn't be here today talking about this.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (Renew).
text: – Mr President, contributing, helping, fostering a peaceful, dialogued and therefore lasting and viable solution to resolving the humanitarian, social and political drama that Venezuela is living requires us to focus, here and there, on what unies us. What unies us is that every observation, every scrutiny, finds that, in Venezuela today, there is no democracy or conditions for free elections.  Our duty, when talking about Venezuela, is to remember that millions of people in that country deserve to be focused on helping them regain freedom. That is why, from here, I call for the consensus to recover fundamental rights and freedoms to be the currency and the first tool of those who, on the ground, suffer and oppose the mature regime. But I also ask all those of us who want to help from the European Union. Any debate that sows doubts about our basic agreement helps Maduro. It allows you to suggest that you have much more support outside venezuela than you actually have, which is very little. The vast majority know he's a dictator. The cause of freedom in Venezuela is not helped by anything that this tragedy is used as a throwing weapon in political debate. Let us focus better on stressing that there the debate is impossible and that the priority is to restore democracy.

name: Esther de Lange (PPE).
text: – Mr President, to know the suffering of the Venezuelan people you don’t even need to go there.  Please take some time to talk to one of the men who prepare your coffee in the bar right next to this hemicycle. He will tell you about his family back home and the shortages of food and medicines, even before the coronavirus struck. And now even more people are dying in the streets.  So let’s be clear, Mr High Representative, there is no division. We are united in wanting to address this humanitarian crisis.  But you can’t be blind to the fact that this suffering is caused by the Maduro regime. A corrupt regime that relies on the smuggling of oil, drugs and gold. A regime that, according to the UN Human Rights Council, murders, tortures, commits sexual violence and random detention. A regime that you did a huge favour by dispatching this premature diplomatic mission, and giving it a certain legitimacy.  It’s like talking to Lukashenko behind the opposition’s back. This is not – and I say this as a Dutch representative – this is not an internal Spanish debate. This is about the values and the credibility of the European Union.  The Maduro regime has already made clear, it does not want to fulfil your conditions. It does not want to postpone the elections. Can you basically answer one simple question to this house?  Do you think all of it was still worth it?  (Applause)

name: Sara Cerdas (S&D).
text: Mr President, Mr High Representative, we have once again talked about Venezuela. With elections scheduled in December that take place in a context of the chemical crisis, but also in a social, political and economic context of degradation. This is a scenario that has been dragging on for several years and which has already given way to several resolutions and debates in this House. It is important that as the European Union we have an active role and are at the forefront of the Issue of Venezuela. We need peaceful and democratic solutions. I therefore call on the High Representative to continue his good offices to ensure that the diplomatic route and dialogue with all actors remain open. We're elected to work for people. We must also ensure that the people of Venezuela can count on our support and solidarity.

name: Javier Nart (Renew).
text: – Mr President, I note that many times this Parliament is the Parliament of the duty to be, not of being able to do, of duty to do.  Secondly, we all agree, except for residual paleocommunicism, that Maduro's de facto government is a brutal, criminal and absolutely condemnable government, but it is a reality. And we also have full legality, which is that of President Guaidó, in a situation whose Assembly ends very soon. And there is another brutal reality, which is the people of Venezuela, turned into a subject of absolute deprivation, but which some use to make revolution to the last Venezuelan, that is, from comfortable Europe. Mr Borrell, from the support of your efforts and the mission you have sent, I find the following. First, that all the processes that have been carried out with the Venezuelan Government, from Mr Zapatero to the Vatican, to everyone else, have served nothing but to prolong the suffering and maintenance of the Maduro regime. That Maduro's last slam, which has given his legitimate efforts and which I support and understand, and which I do not understand as condemned, has meant that he remains in the same very difficult situation. Any negotiation process, I see it unworkable. My question and my position is: the only possibility is to increase the pressure and, of course, to foster, if possible, a dialogue, which I frankly see metaphysical.

name: Leopoldo López Gil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr High Representative, you recently stated, I quote, "The humanitarian situation in Venezuela is desperate. It is the most serious humanitarian crisis in a country and the international community does not pay much attention to it because it only sees the political aspect on the issue." Go on with the appointment. However, even knowing the conclusions of the united Nations independent mission, which accuse Maduro's regime of crimes against humanity, you organized a mission to negotiate with these human rights violators the postponement of fraudulent elections. And I said "regime" and not "Government", because this House and twenty-five member countries of the European Union only recognize as a legitimate government the National Assembly, chaired by Juan Guaidó. As a high representative, one of its responsibilities is to ensure the coherence of the European Union's external action. Would you send a mission to Belarus to negotiate with that regime the future elections organized by Lukashenko himself? Are there guarantees that allow transparent, democratic and credible elections to be held in Venezuela? The ultimate goal of Maduro's dictatorship is to stay in power at all costs. To conclude with that regime secretly is naive. Electoral observation, emanating from our institution, cannot support fraud called for December or six months later. To put the election of the Legislative Power before the change of the Executive Branch is simply absurd. I ask you: will Venezuela ⸺ democratic Venezuela⸺ be supported by the European Union?

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Sánchez Amor, one thing we know to be an absolute truth is that, if Valdis Dombrovskis were in Mr Borrell's place, surely this journey would not have taken place. Mr Borrell and we all know full well that the United Nations has issued a devastating report for the attacks on human rights in Venezuela. We also know that the time limit for investigating crimes committed by the regime is extended; yesterday the United Nations, in its plenary session, decided so. But breakfast this morning with a video of Venezuelan television showing the European Union ambassador, Isabel Brillante, meeting with the regime's prosecutor, Tarek William Saab, handing her a human rights contrareport of the Venezuelan regime. But the serious issue, and my colleagues need to know, is that Tarek William Saab is denounced by the European Union, he is being sanctioned by the European Union. My question is: what is the European Union ambassador doing sitting with this character? Colleagues, colleagues in the European Parliament, what is Tarek William Saab accused of, among other things? To throw an opposition councilman out the window.  Question: What is this ambassador doing sitting there?

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Borrell, the reality is stubborn. After the various attempts at dialogue—that of the Holy See, the Dominican Republic, or Norway's in Barbados—I do not know what made you think that relaunching a new dialogue could be fruitful. Unsurprisingly, the mission you devised has resulted in another failure, which has not left the EU in a good place and has not contributed to the democratic cause. And, as I see that you are in need of a roadmap for Venezuela, and our colleagues ask us to do so, allow me to offer in a summary way, even modestly, the following principles or ideas. First, insist on holding democratic elections, preferably presidential elections. Second, avoid initiatives that contribute to opposition fragmentation. Third, take back the pressure path and avoid cheating dialogues. The European Union should extend sanctions to policy makers and also to the more than forty perpetrators of crimes mentioned in the Resolution, in the report of the Human Rights Council. Fourth, intensify the talks with the Lima Group and try to approach with other major players. The International Contact Group is clearly inadequate.  I would like to know, Mr Borrell, your views on this and also what concrete initiatives you will take to restore freedom and respect for human rights in Venezuela. Will you do some self-criticism today?

name: Josep Borrell Fontelles
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Montserrat, I took your floor. You said it: a chain of lies and half-truths does not make a truth, apply the story. What you and others have done is just that: a chain of lies and half-truths. You have organized an un baseless scandal, simply to agitate and, I fear, fight the Spanish Government. But this is not the Race of Saint Jerome, this is not the Spanish Parliament. If you want to discuss Spanish politics, do it in Madrid. Nor am I already the foreign minister of Mr Sanchez's government.  (Various reactions) And you have been President of the European Parliament and you should keep your composure. (Various reactions) Mr. President, may I continue? Can I continue without having to suffer Mr. Tajani's interruptions? Thanks a lot.  And everything you've said now about semiclandestine. Look, clandestineness, like some attributes of the physiology of the human body, is or isn't: it's clandestine or not clandestine. You cannot say that it is a secret or clandestine mission in half, when I have explained to you that we have passed through the International Contact Group, where we have clearly said that we would continue to contact all political actors at the necessary levels, and everyone agreed. And I have informed the Council of Foreign Ministers that we would continue to contact all political actors by all necessary and appropriate means.  What's with the sacrament? What's with the turmoil of secrets and plots because you wanted to make a gesture for the Spanish government to cut it? But, Mrs. Montserrat, that's all ridiculous, frankly. What are you guys complaining about? What do they find critical in doing the diplomatic mission that we have to do and that we have been doing for months simply because, instead of doing it on the phone, we do it in person?  Let us see: elections in Belarus have been neither free nor transparent nor participatory. Aren't you? And yet the opposition in Belarus has participated in them. Do you think the opposition's involvement in Belarus has bleached Mr Lukashenko's regime? Do you think that such participation has served to legitimize Mr Lukashenko's regime? Of course not, at all, on the contrary. Precisely this participation has served as a lever to highlight the falsity of these elections and combat it.  But how is Mr Maduro's regime bleached by sending an official to speak to everyone in Venezuela? Please, a little seriousness. What's he bleaching about? What is it legitimized in? When we've been saying and we keep saying what we think about Mr Maduro's regime. We're doing what's right for us to do. That I have not informed the European Parliament before? Of course not. I have no obligation or need to do so. My constitution is the Foreign Affairs Council, it is the International Contact Group.  And, well, what I was missing is for someone to tell me that I had no contact with the opposition to move Mr Maduro's regime to its conditions. Oh, isn't it? Well, all right, look: a document with five specific points was provided to me by the opposition to get it to Mr Maduro's regime and wait for his answer. Yes, I have tried to see whether there was any chance, certainly little, of whether it was certainly unlikely that the positions of the Government, Mr Maduro's regime and the opposition could approach. And you tell me: would you send someone to Belarus to try to approach positions? Yes, of course I do. Of course. If we could send someone to Belarus tomorrow to try to create a national political dialogue, of course we would; We've offered it. But what world do they live in? But what world do they live in?  The President of the European Council has called or tried to call Mr Lukashenko. He didn't make it, but if he'd been on the phone, I'd have talked to him. Is that bleaching him? Is that legitimizing him? What are you really worried about? Are you concerned about the fate of the Venezuelan people? I am not saying no, to me too, and I do not accept lessons on how I have to conduct the task of the high representative in this particular case. I did what I had to do and I'd do it again.  We haven't been successful. But I think it was necessary. I think it was necessary to try to find a way of approximation, which is the only way out of the situation in Venezuela, and to encourage and foster political dialogue, and political dialogue, because there have been representatives of the opposition who have been talking to the regime: Mr Capriles, without going any further, who has made public demonstrations saying 'if the conditions were met, I would participate'. If the conditions were to occur, but the conditions will not fall from the sky, they will not arise by spontaneous generation, we must work them, we must discuss them.  What do you think the Norwegian Government has been doing, that it has been perfectly aware of what we have done and which has supported us? What do you think the Norwegian government has been doing? Well, to encourage this dialogue, not succeed either, but deep down what we have tried to do is the same thing that the Norwegian Government has done, and it will continue to try and we will continue to try, because we do not support military solutions, because we do not support military interventions abroad to solve that problem, because the only solution is precisely dialogue and the pact between Venezuela's political forces. And that, if we can encourage it, we will. And that's what I've been doing, and I've been doing it with full knowledge of the G4 group, with whom I've had several video conferences this summer. Now it's going to turn out I haven't been talking to them? And I have done so with full awareness that this was going to be exploited by those who are more interested in stirring political waters than in seeking a solution to Venezuela's problem, and also knowing that it would also receive criticism from those who say that we did not want to participate, once again, in the electoral process. No, we haven't been able to participate. No, Mrs. Pereira, we haven't been able to participate. Because, to participate," I insist, "there is a rule process, which goes through an election exploration mission, which comes back with a report and says whether or not the conditions are met, and, if it happens—and it would be up to me to judge it—a process is put in place that those who work in the field of electoral observations know to be long and complex , which cannot be done with less than four or five months. And that is what I told the Government of Venezuela by letter before sending that mission: to know that we must first see if conditions are met, that they are not given today, and that then we would need five months to participate.  The answer has been what it is, and unfortunately I am afraid that this will continue to push Venezuela towards an even more difficult situation, to a situation of deinstitutionalization. The National Assembly is now a democratically elected assembly. It's the only institution that is. You say presidential election. Yes, well, but we are now talking about the legislative ones, which are fixed date, because that House reaches the end of its mandate and we must choose a new one. Do you think it's wrong for us to try to discuss how this election can be held? What have we committed ourselves to? What have we given in to? How did we bleach? What have we legitimized? Absolutely nothing.  Mr López, I understand that if I were in your shoes and had a child housed in the Embassy of Spain, you would have an emotional burden that would surely make me say the same thing you said, but please don't say it's a secret mission. Secret missions are not communicated by letter to all Member States. Don't say we've gone to whiten Mr. Maduro's regime. You know what my opinion is about that regime.  You know that your son was welcomed to the Embassy of Spain when I was Minister of Foreign Affairs and that I am very proud to have managed to contribute to something to that.  My commitment to democracy in Venezuela does not have to be validated by you; is proven by the facts, and what we have done now does not denies it. It's a risky effort. It's a criticized effort. You are criticising it much more than it deserves, and on the other side too, to try to find a solution and help the opposition to feel stronger and more supported by the international community and the European Union when talking to the Government.  Unfortunately, we have not succeeded, if the Government of Venezuela, Mr Maduro's regime, had told me, before he sent the mission, 'it is not worth coming because I am not going to change the electoral date, because the Constitution forbids me', as they are saying now, then yes, we certainly would not have gone. For what? But that wasn't so clear, that wasn't so clear, in all the discussions we've had directly, through the opposition, that wasn't so clear. There was a little light of hope. There was a small possibility, and I felt compelled to explore it, to try to see if there was anything that could be done to advance this political dialogue which, at the end of the day, will one day be the only solution for the people of Venezuela. And, believe me, your contribution in this case has been regrettable.

name: Puhemies. –
text: I declare this debate closed and will not grant any further further arguments. Delegates, I'm sure you'll hear what I'm saying. We shall now move on to the following point.

name: Jordi Cañas (Renew).
text: – (start of off-microphone intervention) ... respect for the members of this House. They cannot be accused of trying to do their control work to the Vice President and Senior Representative and cannot be called regrettable. It's a matter of basic respect. It is a matter of respect for this institution and its work of political control. To the high representative and vice-president: you have an obligation to come and explain. It's not a discretionary thing.

name: Puhemies. –
text: I would now ask you, Mr President, to calm down and stop speaking. We've already turned off your microphone. Let's move on to the next thing. The debate is closed.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Iran (2020/2811(RSP)). I repeat what has been said here on many occasions, that this part-session does not therefore give the so-called catch-the-eye speeches on request, nor do the blue card questions be accepted.

name: Josep Borrell Fontelles
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, indeed, the situation in Iran deserves a debate which promises, in the light of the previous one, to be interesting. I would like to begin by thanking the European Parliament for its continued commitment to the situation in Iran, including its concern for human rights...

name: Puhemies. –
text: I am sure you can move outside the Chamber to have private discussions with Mr Bütikofer.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: – (referring to Mr Canas’s remarks off mic) Madam President, I’m asking him to try to insult me in a language that I understand.

name: Puhemies. –
text: I wish I understood that, too. But now we will continue the debate on Iran and give the floor to the High Representative. Anyone who wants to continue the Venezuela debate can certainly do so outside the chamber.

name: Josep Borrell Fontelles
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I was saying that I thank the European Parliament for its ongoing concern about the situation in Iran, including the recent worrying human—rights related developments. Iran is in the middle of a difficult period. COVID-19 is affecting the country severely with more than 3 000 new infections every day, half a million to-date, and at least 27 000 deaths. The COVID crisis is further deepening Iran’s existing economic difficulties.  Following the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, the so-called JCPOA, Iran had the legitimate expectation that this nuclear deal will result in more concrete economic benefits. Yet, after the regrettable US departure from the agreement and the reinstatement of severe sanctions, the overall economic figures speak for themselves.  The International Monetary Fund is predicting a 10% drop in GDP this year; 8.5% last year. Unemployment is at 16%. The Iranian Rial has lost almost half its value towards the US dollar. Trade with the European Union has decreased.  In addition, Iran is experiencing shortages of important humanitarian items, like personal protective equipment and medicine that could help in fighting COVID. There is a severe shortage of all capacities to fight COVID. As the European Union, we were quick to provide humanitarian support with an air bridge and we keep strongly advocating, together with the UN Secretary-General, that sanctions must not impede humanitarian trade.  Together with European Union Member States, we also keep looking at ways to encourage more legitimate trade between the EU and Iran – including through the EU-Iran trading mechanism (INSTEX) – but we need to do more. These difficulties have also had a political impact in Iran. Not least at the parliamentary election earlier this year. We have seen a strengthening of those opposed to the nuclear deal, who are distrustful of the West and who do not support diplomacy and engagement.  Together with our European and international partners, we are working hard to make sure that diplomacy with Iran continues to be possible. We have also witnessed several deeply concerning human—rights developments recently.  This includes the treatment of Nasrin Sotoudeh and the many other political prisoners who remain in prison, whose health is at risk and should be released on humanitarian grounds, but at the very least have prompt access to medical assistance if they require it. We also condemn publicly the execution of the Iranian wrestler, Navid Afkari, and call on the Iranian authorities to investigate allegations that he was tortured in detention.  We underline to all our partners and not just Iran, that the perpetrators of such acts must be held accountable. We continue to engage the Iranian authorities on their distressing practice of arbitrarily detaining European Union—Iranian dual nationals. We acknowledge the temporary release of French citizen Fariba Adelkhah. No individual should be used as a pawn, and I want once again urge the Iranian authorities to cease this policy. Mr President, honourable members, let me finish with some remarks on the nuclear agreement.  I want to be clear, as coordinator – because the High Representative acts as coordinator of the JCPOA – I will continue to do everything possible to ensure the preservation and full implementation of the nuclear deal by all parties.  Why is this so important? Because it is in our very own European security interest, and because the agreement continues to deliver. Without the nuclear deal, Iran could have developed a nuclear weapon by now, with all the security implications for the region and beyond.  Of course, I am very concerned about Iran’s reduced implementation of its JCPOA nuclear commitments, following the US withdrawal from the agreement two years ago. I do believe that full implementation of the nuclear deal by Iran and other parties remain crucial to our efforts to preserve it.  However, we should not forget that even though the amount of nuclear material Iran possesses today is more than it had two years ago, it is still far less than the 10 tonnes of enriched uranium that Iran possessed before the agreement.  We know that this is thanks to the JCPOA. Iran is the most monitored country in the world by the International Atomic Energy Agency, with now almost 400 inspections per year. If we were to lose the agreement, we would lose such critical information about their nuclear programme. During recent weeks, a great amount of attention has been devoted to attempts by United States to bring back the United Nations Iran sanctions, and here I want to be very clear also. Once more: bringing back these sanctions would have meant the end of the JCPOA.  Thirteen members of the Security Council – thirteen, including all European members – rejected this approach and underlined the importance of keeping the agreement in place. In this way supporting my understanding that the US are no longer part of the JCPOA because they freely decided to withdraw from it.  They were also very clear that after leaving the agreement in 2018, the United States was not in a position to initiate the so—called ‘snapback process’ of bringing back United Nations sanctions under the UN Security Council resolution 2231.  As JCPOA coordinator, I just want to reiterate that all sanctions-lifting commitments under the agreement remain in place. I want to reiterate that all sanctions-lifting commitments under the agreement, remain in place.  I will personally continue to remain engaged on all of these issues, knowing that you are being criticized both parts when you take this stance, and I count on the strong backing of this Parliament and the Council to promote a holistic approach to Iran, that takes into account different facets of our bilateral relationship.  Engagement with Iran on all these issues remains in the European Union’s vital and strategic interest and that’s why we are approaching the issue the way we do.

name: David McAllister
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, thank you Mr High Representative for your statement. I would like to echo your justified words on the urgent need to ensure the preservation and the implementation of the JCPOA by all parties. This multilateral agreement, as we have underlined many times in this European Parliament, is a crucial achievement of European diplomacy. It remains a key pillar of the global non—proliferation architecture, contributing to regional security and stability and it addresses Iran’s nuclear programme in a comprehensive manner. Colleagues, in 2018 the Foreign Affairs Committee visited Iran and Saudi Arabia. We had very interesting talks in Riyadh and Tehran and our key message was consistently a de—escalation in the region is a must. Today, more than two years later, this is more needed than ever before and that’s why, dear High Representative, I would like to underline what you announced as regards the snapback mechanism. All parties involved should do their utmost to preserve the JCPOA and to refrain from any action that could be perceived as an escalation in this current situation. (Applause)

name: Tonino Picula
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, dear Mr High Representative, JCPOA is an unmatched diplomatic achievement of the European Union, but it seems to be an even bigger challenge to maintain it. The European Union has committed itself to its survival and full implementation. As some would add, the deal is still alive but could be in a better health condition. Hopefully, the United States will soon enough return to deal and towards the restoration of multilateralism in general, and Iran will also uphold its commitments as stated in the Treaty. Our support to the nuclear deal, however, does not mean that we should be shy calling out Iran for its role in conflicts in Syria and Yemen, its action in the Strait of Hormuz and attacks on US troops in Iraq. We are most definitely not indifferent towards the situation of human rights in Iran, which is appalling. A Sakharov Prize awardee Nasrin Sotoudeh recently was on hunger strike, and the latest case of execution of Navid Afkari deserves our strongest condemnation. A number of dual EU-Iranian citizens are still unjustly detained in Iran. We support the EEAS Iran task force and its balanced comprehensive approach, but today we have to make it clear that if Iran wants continued European Union engagement, it needs to dramatically improve its human rights record. (Applause)

name: Bart Groothuis
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, 11 days from now, on 18 October, the United Nations arms embargo will expire and 11 days from now China and Russia will be very eager to sell strategic weapons to Iran. The Iranian Foreign Minister has welcomed it, and 11 days from now, like the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps has said, a new phase in military cooperation between Iran and the world will commence. And since the Iranian options are limited, and their cash flow is limited, and their foreign currencies are limited, they might very well offer, as a quid pro quo, naval bases or air bases to Russian or Chinese military in the Middle East, and this is of course all bad news, very bad news, for anyone living in Israel, in Lebanon, in Yemen, but also in the European Union. Debates, however, seem to be concentrating on whoever gets the ticket in the White House. I admit, most rivals are dependent on who makes the decisions in the beginning of next year in Washington, but right now in the next couple of months, we have an expiring weapons embargo and there is no movement from the USA to be expected, which creates a daunting challenge, I must say, to try to restrain and limit arms sales to Iran, and here lies a task for Europe. And I was very pleased to learn that a while ago that European efforts to restrain, to limit, or at least to delay arms sales to Iran within the P5+1 framework were underway. Any alternative means to find a solution is welcome because Beijing will sell its arms. But it’s been quiet ever since, and therefore I ask for some assurance. Are we still on the same page? Are talks with Europe, with Beijing and Moscow ongoing? Can you assure me that we are doing everything that we can to restrain? Is there still hope to limit arms sales? As coordinator for the JCPOA, which we fully support, and also as a diplomatic success from the European Union, I would ask you in the next 11 days and beyond to do your utmost best.  (Applause)

name: Thierry Mariani
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, Iran is a major regional power in the Middle East. Tehran sometimes worries for very objective reasons and sometimes for causes that have nothing to do with international law. Unfortunately, the voice of the European Union is not being heard. First, because we have been humiliated by the American withdrawal from the Vienna agreements. Second, because we make the eyes soft to the Arab powers without almost never reminding that they sometimes do worse than Iran.
