Finally, because we are not free in Iran because of the unacceptable extraterritoriality of American law. The European Union has no interest in accepting Iran's ambition to form a Shiite crescent from Tehran to Beirut, but it will only be credible when it acts with the same vigour against Ottoman imperialism or against the manipulation of Sunni populations by Gulf money. European nations know the Middle East better than the United States, it is time that we free ourselves from the straitjacket of NATO and Atlanticism to regain credibility and independence on issues in this region.  Yes, we must establish a dialogue with Iran, a dialogue that does not exclude any of the hot topics such as the disarmament of Iraqi militias or the maintenance of the death penalty for apostasy. However, we must think of this dialogue, not to exclude Iran from international diplomacy, but rather to be architects of peace and dialogue in this region.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, Iran’s Covid 19 cases are at an all-time high at the moment. The pandemic has hit hard at a time when the country’s economy was at its lowest point, partly due to the sanctions imposed by the US, which have harmed Iranians’ access to essential medicines.  When it comes to the situation on human rights we want to reiterate our call to release all human rights defenders in prison and who have been sentenced, and call for the unconditional release of all EU-Iranian dual nationals, which is a growing concern in that parliament. But the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JPCOA) is still the central element of our capacity to influence both the nuclear development and human rights situation in the country. We would like to welcome the conclusions of the meeting of the Joint Commission on 1 September and support the High Representative’s efforts to ensure that the agreement is preserved and fully implemented by all sides.  As the EEAS has recently done in a statement, I would like to remind everyone that the non-participating member of the JCPOA, the US, cannot initiate the process to re-impose sanctions under United Nations Security Council Resolution 2231.  The JCPOA framework is today the framework that avoids further escalation and that is why this Parliament and the European Union should firmly stand behind it. (Applause)

name: Witold Jan Waszczykowski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank Mr Borrell Fontelles for the information about the situation in Iran and about the condition of the JCPOA. Yes, this agreement is of important value for us. However, I would like to appeal for transatlantic unity on Iran. Despite disputes and competition between the United States and Russia, the United States and China and the United States and Iran, I think there is no room for the European Union to be in the middle. There is no room for strategic autonomy in this particular case, especially in the case of Iran. The European Union has to take sides. We may differ, of course, about the measures and the instruments in how to deal with Iran. However, we have to work together, because Iran is determined to develop a nuclear programme and to change the security architecture. It’s a nasty regime which has disrespected human rights. There is no room for quick economic benefits. Our security matters. Let’s keep Iran away from the nuclear bomb and let’s do it together.

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her When we talk today about the situation in Iran, it is probably first of all about the many victims of COVID-19 and why the EU is not providing sufficient support, as it does with other countries seriously affected. Once again, the people of this country are left alone, as they were when the United States pulled out of one of the most important international treaties of the present, the JCPOA. There have never been serious consequences. Nor in terms of INSTEX, when Trump broke international law and imposed extraterritorial sanctions that have a dramatic impact on the lives of every iranian, every single Iranian. It is the history of grandiose failures of the West and the disappointment of all those in Iran who want to open up and change their country. If you are now complaining that the hardliners are regaining their dominance and that human rights in Iran are being trampled underfoot more than ever, then that is half-hearted. For me, it is a personal defeat – I will say so – that Nasrin Sotudeh has been imprisoned again for years because she embodies the hopes of many people in Iran – and, by the way, my ideals. Gradually, the doors to Iran close, and we stand there and wait. What actually? On the US election? We have a responsibility to do what we do and for the resolute support given to the forces of peace and democracy in Iran. We simply need to do more to do that.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I thought the High Representative gave a very balanced statement on the situation in Iran containing the good, the bad and the ugly, and how particularly the economic situation is impacting on the poor unfortunate citizens of Iran. As my colleague David McAllister pointed out, the JCPOA was a triumph for European diplomacy and particularly also for three powerful women who helped negotiate it. Again, we express our disappointment that the US administration unilaterally withdrew from the agreement in May 2018, and heightened tensions further with the assassination of Iranian General Soleimani.  The nuclear deal is a key pillar of regional border security and the EU has made a great effort in keeping the pact alive, despite US pressure, and we deserve credit for it. We must remain clear and unwavering in our commitment to non-violence and continue to de-escalate tensions in the region. As has been pointed out, since the United States has already withdrawn from the international agreement curbing Iran’s nuclear ambitions, it can’t now use its former membership of the pact to try and impose a permanent arms embargo on Iran. We must do everything we can to ensure that sanction-lifting continues while the conditions are met, and with 400 inspections per year, that’s pretty clear.

name: Jytte Guteland (S&D).
text: Madam President, High Representative Borell, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by congratulating the Rapporteur on his excellent On the very broad subject of the situation in Iran, there is much to be said. Iran is in many ways in a crisis at the moment, with, as colleagues have mentioned, a terrible situation with regard to covid-19. But also a country hit by poverty, huge corruption, climate change. And to that we have a human rights situation that leaves everything to be desired.  The EU has condemned, but also needs to continue to condemn, what affects prisoners of conscience in the country. I am thinking of Nasrin Sotoudeh, who has fought so hard for human rights in his commitment as a lawyer, and who is now on hunger strike and pointing to the appalling conditions that she and many with her suffer when fighting for her people and human rights. We must also continue to condemn the executions that are taking place. It plagued the world to watch the execution of athlete Navid Afkari. It hurts that people's lives are taken away from them. Iran is one of the countries in the world with the worst statistics in this area. The UN points to serious shortcomings. If the EU is to succeed in a stable security situation in relation to Iran – ensure that the nuclear agreement continues to be respected, build a transatlantic link with the US, stand up for human rights – then a great deal of commitment is required from the European Commission and the Council, and I assume that the High Representative Borell stands for it.

name: Nicola Beer (Renew).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Belarus, Azerbaijan, Armenia – these images of violence and conflict reach us every day, and rightly so we stand up to protest loudly against them. But we should also stand up for those who suffer outside the world – without politics, without the press, without sympathy. In Iran, too, there is war, a quiet, a tough war waged by the regime against its own people, against the people who express their opinions, against young people and, in particular, against women. This war against one's own people is being fought on the backs of women. One of them, Giti Purfasel – and her name is unjustly almost unknown – is locked away, threatened, harassed. For her, as well as for our Sakharov Prize winner, Nasrin Sotudeh, the fight for women and human rights is a disaster. It is just the latest example of the fate of women in Iran, who are already being deprived of their freedom for a badly fitting headscarf. These women do not have the privilege of the media reporting on them on a daily basis. These women have no lawyers; we must protect these women through our attention. In concrete terms, we need ambassadorial visits to the prison for Giti Purfasel and the other political prisoners until they are finally released. But not only. Let us finally heed the call for a geopolitical Europe and draw an unequivocal line towards dictatorial regimes! Enough is enough! We need less cooperation with, less understanding of the Iranian regime, more direct support for Iranian women, for Iranian civil society, so that heroines like Giti Purfasel can continue to defend European values outside our borders.

name: Marco Campomenosi (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Solana, many of my fellow Members have said this: torture in order to obtain false confessions, mass arrests, the rights of opponents and women trampled underfoot by a regime that has its own citizens as enemies, not to mention minorities and the State of Israel. Dramatic COVID management, especially for minorities, and an economic framework, as the High Representative pointed out, is nefarious. Yet there is no shortage of money to finance militias in Syria, Iraq, Hezbollah and Hamas. The seriousness of what the US Administration tells us must be brought to the utmost attention in Brussels, because i and many of us also welcomed the nuclear agreement in a very positive way. But to think that it is still feasible today is, in my view, a mistake and perhaps naïve. For the same reason, I believe that the agreements between Israel and certain Sunni states should not be underestimated. In short, something is changing in that area and we must certainly support the possibility of regime change in a state that, we have all mentioned, does not allow people like Navid Afkari to defend themselves freely. Today he cannot be with us because he was hanged: yet he was probably right to protest against that regime.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Borrell, the aggressive oppression of the people of Iran by the regime is presently the worst it’s been in over 30 years, and, as Ms Beer said, the regime is waging war on its people and we have to stand steadfastly on their side to protect them, to help them and to make the world know, and make the European public know, what is going on. At the same time, we’re talking about the JCPOA, and we try to hold on to that – and we should. But we are holding on to a political ruin. Even if President Biden were to be elected in November, there is scarcely a chance that the US would return to the JCPOA, if we are honest with ourselves. The JCPOA was a European initiative. We are proud of that, but that pride should be translated into a new European initiative. I think there is a new dynamic in the region, particularly with some of the deals that have already been mentioned today. The European Union should start – you should start, Mr Borrell – an initiative for a regional conference for stability and peace, and of course we need the US on board, we need the Russians on board and the Chinese and all the powers in the region. But we should not just look back, deploring what went wrong, but look forward, finding new initiatives.

name: Anna Fotyga (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the economic disaster in Iran started long before COVID-19 and American sanctions. Actually, massive protests were because of the misuse of funds after de-freezing by banks following the signing of the JCPOA. We have to find a way to keep the arms embargo on the regime that is responsible for financing terrorism, crushing protests in the country so brutally and downing civilian airplanes.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, not extending the sanctions against Iran at the UN Security Council was certainly welcome. But Mr Borrell, you said that the EU has learned lessons from recent developments and that the EU must take a more independent position. Are you prepared to act out upon these lessons? Due to the US unilateral sanctions, the EU as a member and coordinator of the JCPOA has not complied with its own obligations under the JCPOA. You are tasked with overseeing the implementation of the EU law, including the blocking statute Council Regulation (EC) No 2271/96. What have you done in practice to protect legitimate trade with Iran? Under the blocking statute, EU countries are not allowed to abide by US extraterritorial sanctions. But our failure to stand against the lawless behaviour of the US makes us complicit in punishing millions of Iranians and abusing their human rights. When is the EU going to find the courage to abide by international law and say ‘no’ to US bullying? When will you, Mr Borrell, say ‘no’ to US imperialism?

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mr High Representative, as you said, the European Union remains fully invested in the nuclear issue, and that is a good thing, because we know that at the heart of this issue is security in the region, but more generally, international security. But international cooperation with Iran - and you have also said so - cannot leave the issue of human rights in the blind spot, because in this matter Iran is far, far from the desired objectives. October 10 will be World Day Against the Death Penalty and yet Iran is the country that executes the most, including young people who were convicted as children; girls, sentenced to 9 years, boys, sentenced to 15 years, who wait on death row to be executed at 18 years of age. Iran sentences people to death for crimes such as treason, espionage, prostitution, adultery, apostasy and demonstrations against poverty or corruption. Confessions are obtained under torture, and this is the case of Ahmadreza Djalali at present. In Iran, defending human rights or fighting the death penalty is punishable by more than 10 years in prison. This is the case for many activists, such as Nasrine Sotoudeh, or Narges Mohammadi, who is in exile. Yes, international cooperation with Iran is important, yes, dialogue is important, but it must also involve lobbying for human rights and demanding the immediate release of those who have only peacefully exercised their fundamental rights.

name: María Soraya Rodríguez Ramos (Renew).
text: – Madam President, thank you, Mr Borrell, and thank you also for your efforts to maintain the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action. But we have to demand that the Iranian authorities cease their human rights violations. Nasrín Sotudé has nearly died when he started a hunger strike to denounce the situation of political prisoners. But behind it and behind political prisoners is Iranian civil society, against which the Iranian regime is at war. Repression in Iran is institutionalized: prosecutors support false allegations, judges issue convictions based on statements obtained with torture, and executions are daily, judicial and extrajudicial. We therefore need to let the Iranian regime know that it has to answer for its crimes. And we need to support an investigative mission within the Human Rights Council that goes to Iran, is personified in prisons, and that makes a report that gives us an account of the brutal reality that the Iranian people are living.

name: Lars Patrick Berg (ID).
text: Madam President, High Representative, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the way in which The High Representative's determination to maintain the Vienna nuclear agreement on Iran's nuclear programme, despite the overwhelming evidence that it is a weak initiative, can only be admired. Of course, I understand the desire to stop nuclear proliferation and the E3's concern to preserve the integrity of the United Nations. In my opinion, however, we must face up to the reality: Iran is not trustworthy. The mullahs are using force to oppress their own people, they are funding terrorists around the world, they are destabilising their neighbors, and they are responsible for the mass killing of civilians in Yemen. They execute political opponents and detain innocent people with dual citizenship in order to gain a supposed political advantage. The Iranian Revolutionary Guard is one of the largest drug gangs in the world.  United Nations Security Council Resolution 2231 continues to allow Iran to export terror fear and instability. It allows the non-democratically legitimized mullahs to continue to terrorise the Iranian people.

name: Salima Yenbou (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Mr Borrell, do you know Mrs Aras Amiri? She worked for the British Council in the United Kingdom, where she was involved in promoting the art and culture of Iran. In March 2018, she was arrested at Tehran airport and sentenced to 10 years in prison. Mr Borrell, the European Union must support it. The case of Aras Amiri shows us how much culture frightens authoritarian regimes.  Unfortunately, Ms. Amiri is not the only Iranian citizen who disturbs her government with her cultural commitment. Let us remember, in 2016, Golshifteh Farahani, who played Anna Karenina so well at the Théâtre de Paris, had to leave his country in order to continue to practice his art. Consider, a masterpiece of Russian literature carried by an Iranian actress in Paris. Culture thus transcends borders and moves beyond cultural differences. Culture is a global vocabulary, Marjane Satrapi said.  You who fight every day for cultural freedom, remember, never forget how much regimes fear you, never forget that in culture lies your power. Thank you for your courage.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: Madam President, High Representative Borrell, I am among the many MEPs who appreciate their often ungrateful efforts to print autonomy, character and commitment on the foreign policy of the European Union, whether in the armenian-Azerbaijan conflict, two member countries of the Council of Europe at war, supported by so many other Council of Europe countries , whether in the case of Venezuela, that is also in this case, in Iran, reminding the United States that, having abandoned the agreement, they are no longer members of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action and is therefore not under the cover of United Nations Resolution 2231 the unilateral imposition of sanctions, which also stried the endorsement by the United Nations Security Council , and failed in the attempt. But at the same time, I am among those of us who demand that the European Union be used thoroughly to demand that Iran respect for human rights, stop the brutal repression of dissent, discrimination against entire categories of people, starting with women, and the systematic and frequent application of the death penalty.

name: Jean-Lin Lacapelle (ID).
text: Madam President, the United States has unilaterally decided to reinstate sanctions on Iran, with the US Secretary of State rushing to announce measures against those who violate sanctions, that is, by imposing their policies on us by force. The mention of these measures reminds us of the exorbitant fine of 8 billion euros imposed by the US Treasury Department on BNP Paribas in 2015. At the time, what had the Commission done to protect European companies subject to these fines? Nothing. Last Thursday in the European Council, you discussed the construction of a European strategic autonomy. Does this autonomy not, above all, require the protection of our companies from foreign sanctions and interventionism? What does the Commission intend to do in this regard and is it not high time for it to get the muscles out and finally protect European companies from American interference? For example, to introduce green border barriers targeting mainly American products or simply prohibit certain companies from entering the European market, as Trump was able to do with TikTok.

name: Hannah Neumann (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, we have talked for nearly an hour now about the threats to the JCPOA, about global power dynamics, about national repression. While all of this is true and very frustrating, there is also hope in Iran. There were massive protests of young people last year in the streets, taking their claims to the streets. Just a few weeks ago, women of Iran have started a ‘Me Too’ movement. There is even a ‘Fight for the Future’ group in the country. Young people in Iran are not living on a different planet. They are part of global movements, and they challenge the regime. Yes, they have to face crackdowns, oppression, repression, torture. They are in prison, some of them are executed. But they are coming back again, and again, and again. And the old ones who have gone through this for decades and decades have not stopped. As long as people in Iran still have the courage to face this regime, it is our duty to support their cause and protect them. And while it is so important that the EU engages in regional dynamics, as Reinhard Bütikofer said, we can only do so if we also manage to engage the people that suffer under the various regimes in the region.

name: Evin Incir (S&D).
text: – Madam President, High Representative, for over 40 years human rights defenders and the political opposition have been under constant attack by the regime in Iran. Their oppression towards the Iranian people is heavy and relentless. Just this September, Amnesty International reported how protesters were subjected to extensive torture following the large popular demonstration last year. Feminists, journalists, union leaders, civil society and minorities, such as the Kurds and Bahai, are sentenced to harsh penalties, including corporal punishment and the death penalty. Sadly, this is probably not news to anyone in this room. Iran sees some of its citizens as threats. Repression happens to real people, people with family and friends. Right now, the brother of a Swedish inhabitant is facing the death penalty while being held in jail. Nasreen Sotoudeh and Narges Mohammadi are the names of additional people in Iranian jails that are facing the death penalty. So my question is basically what is the Commission doing to prevent the execution of these innocent people, who only dream of democracy and freedom?

name: Bernhard Zimniok (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Recently, the wrestler Navid Afkari was executed without a trial under the rule of law. Where was our vociferous protest? Human rights lawyer Nasrin Sotoudeh, winner of the Sakharov Prize, is currently in serious danger; their condition is worrying. She was sentenced to 33 years in prison and 148 lashes in 2019 for defending two women who had protested against the current headscarf requirement. That headscarf, which in Europe is often trivialized by the left and the Greens as a sign of emancipation. The whiplash will not survive them. Iran is still being courted to avoid jeopardizing the nuclear deal. The deal was a fog candle from the start that allowed the Iranians to continue building their nuclear bombs, to the applause of the West. Let us finally take our so-called, much-quoted values seriously and end the cuddle with Iran! Let's finally show them the red card!

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the European Union wants to maintain a nuclear deal with Iran and rejects American unilateral action aimed at imposing further sanctions. President Trump promises that if he is elected again, he will negotiate a better deal with Iran, not only on its nuclear program. Can we believe it? I do not know. It’s clear that nothing will be solved on nuclear deal until we learn who wins the election, and whether Washington is returning to a nuclear deal or continuing with the controversial sanctions mechanism. Time is passing by. Now we face the problem when the weapons export embargo will expire in two weeks. On the other hand, we have to remember that we in the EU must remain critical and very tough against Tehran in dealing with the ideological opponent, opposition, – Iran needs to make further significant progress in the area of human rights if it wants to get more European engagement. The release of some detained citizens with a dual citizenship is a step in the right direction. I think, it is not sufficient – all the repression should stop now.

name: Domènec Ruiz Devesa (S&D).
text: – Madam President, thank you to the high representative, Josep Borrell, for his presence here today, for his intervention. I believe that the vast majority of the House agrees with the position it has expressed: to try to make every effort to keep the nuclear agreement alive, which is of great importance, while at the same time demanding respect for human rights in Iran by the regime. We cannot forget the long list of aggressions of the Iranian regime, from the point of view of regional destabilization, but also the arrest and execution of opponents , the situation of our laureate Sakharov, Nasrín Sotudé, has been mentioned here, very worryingly; but also the illegal abduction of citizens of dual nationality, the willingness to buy weapons as soon as the embargo is over, the mistaken takedown of a civilian plane, the crackdown on protests in November last year. The question is: do we have the tools to put pressure on the regime beyond the declaratory ones?

name: Michael Gahler (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We certainly largely agree on the fundamental nature of the Iranian regime, and everything that has been listed here in terms of criticism of the conditions within the country is condemnable. The execution of Navid Afkari, the imprisonment of Nasrin Sotoudeh, or the fundamental disenfranchisement of the Baha'i as a persecuted religious community are an example. Criticism of foreign policy behaviour is also justified – everything that has been listed here is justified. However, we have agreed throughout the world for many years that the worst thing would be if Iran got a nuclear bomb, and that was right to prevent it and must be prevented, and the JCPOA must therefore be maintained. We must try, hopefully, to get a new American administration Biden to rejoin, because we have seen the effects of radicalization increasing in Iran. If we had had a development to the contrary – with the application of the agreement, with the lifting of economic sanctions and with an opportunity for the people there to develop – they would have had more strength to turn against the regime; I agree with Hannah Neumann. I have a lot of confidence in the young people, in fact in all the people who are really fed up with this regime. One day the Iranians will overcome this regime, and if we pursue a policy by then that does not deprive them of that confidence, then that is a proper policy, and that includes continuing the JCPOA.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Solana, the human rights situation in Iran has deteriorated rapidly over the last year. The sanctions imposed by the United States have had a devastating impact on the country's economy, with serious consequences for the enjoyment of economic and social rights, creating a real internal bombshell. The protests that broke out on 25 November last year were brutally suppressed by the authorities, who used unnecessary or excessive force and arbitrarily detained peaceful demonstrators. Since then, the judiciary and security forces have continued to use rough provisions of the penal code to arrest and prosecute activists, against freedom of expression and peaceful assembly. The case of Nasrin Sotoudeh, to whom we support and express our solidarity, is emblematic of this deterioration towards human rights defenders, lawyers and dissidents. Ladies and gentlemen, we also need sanctions against those responsible for any violation of human rights, wherever they may be! But without diplomacy, without negotiation, without a European defence of the commitments made reciprocally in the nuclear agreement, there will be no table to improve and negotiate this unacceptable state of human rights. The United States has withdrawn from multilateralism.

name: Josep Borrell Fontelles
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, it has been a busy morning. We have been here for four hours, and we are reaching the end of this intense debate about three very important issues. Many things have been said, and I agree with many of them. I could say exactly what Mr Gahler said at the end: the worst thing would be if Iran were to become nuclear. Thanks to this deal, it’s not nuclear. Others Members have said the same thing; I cannot mention all of them. So to try to keep the JCPOA alive – although, as Mr Bütikofer has said, it is very weak because the withdrawal of the US is certainly something that jeopardises its existence and the continuity – to keep it working, even at a lower regime, is not contradictory with the importance that we have to give to the situation of human rights in Iran. I know that this is something that all Parliament is very concerned about and I can assure you that we will continue working in order to put our concerns, our rejection of the executions and detentions that have been mentioned here today before the Iranian authorities. We will do that in collaboration with the German Embassy in Tehran, which is currently acting as our local representation since we don’t have a European delegation on the ground. And Mr Bütikofer is also right: we have to look further at whatever is going to happen in the US after the next elections. It is not sure that the JCPOA will survive. We have to look for a new agreement. Is it possible? Remember how difficult it was to reach this agreement, how many years of tough work were required to rebuild the agreement in order to adapt it to the new circumstances, and even enlarging it could be good, if possible. It will depend very much on the political landscape in January next year. In the meantime, about the arms embargo: I want to stress that we Europeans will continue to put our arms embargo in place. Our arms embargo, the comprehensive arms embargo of the European Union – not the JCPOA arms embargo – will continue into 2023. But we cannot say that we fight to keep the JCPOA alive and, at the same time, to impose an arms embargo on the JCPOA itself – what is considered part of it – and ban. On that, we cannot share the position of the US as they didn’t share 13 Members of the Security Council. All I know is we are trying to do our best in order to increase trade with Iran. It is very difficult because the American sanctions are very powerful, but the Iran deal is not just a nuclear deal. It is a dual task. It is a nuclear deal on the one side and an economic deal on the other, and one thing goes with the other. We cannot pretend that Iran fulfils all its nuclear obligations and at the same time not get any kind of reward on the economic side. This is a delicate balance. Let’s try to work on two things at the same time: the nuclear agreement and human rights. We will continue fighting to keep the nuclear agreement alive and working and at the same time we will continue working in order to make the Iranian authorities aware that respect for human rights is a sine qua non for us to engage with them. And on both points I need the support of the European Parliament and a realistic approach to one of the most important problems for our security, because without the JCPOA today Iran would be a nuclear power and then we would be in a completely different scenario, in a completely different situation. I think that this achievement for European diplomacy, which took a lot of effort from Javier Solana until Ms Mogherini – a lot of people have been working on that – deserves to be preserved, deserves to be continued, deserves to be facilitating a non-nuclear Iran, and it also gives us leverage to engage with Iran on these other very important issues, such as human rights, which I know the Members of this Parliament are very attached to, as I am. You can count on the External Action Service to engage on this issue. The two of them can go in parallel; one things doesn’t prevent the other. Thank you very much, Members of the Parliament, for your support and for this long and moving session. (Applause)

name: Puhemies. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Adam Bielan (ECR)
text: in writing. – The economic and social situation in Iran have deteriorated rapidly and the Covid-19 pandemic is aggravating the situation. Iran’s economy suffers from high inflation and is predicted to shrink by 10% this year. It should not be only in the EU’s security interest to maintain the JCPOA, but also in the interest of the people, as the agreement is also contributing to regional and global security. This is, I believe, of utmost importance. In parallel, the EU should work on how to keep arms embargo on the regime and should try to re-establish transatlantic unity on Iran. Fundamental rights such as freedom of expression and of assembly must always be respected. Therefore, while maintaining the JCPOA, the EU and especially the HRVP should continue raising human rights concerns with the Iranian authorities in bilateral and multilateral forums.

name: President. –
text: Let me first congratulate Executive Vice—President Valdis Dombrovskis on his nomination by this House also to extend his responsibilities to trade policy. And I am confident that the House and you will have an excellent cooperation also in the future. So, congratulations.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. You know that I represent the Council here and I speak for the Council; nevertheless, I would also like to make a few comments from the point of view of the German Federal Government. I would like to reassure you that my government takes this fraud scandal very seriously. That is why we have now launched an investigation into this. We are working on concrete reform proposals aimed at strengthening accounting enforcement and the effectiveness of our supervisors. In the meantime, we have also been carrying out parliamentary investigations in Germany, which we support equally unreservedly and with commitment. It is precisely these parliamentary investigations that will be able to help to identify the necessary reforms in the areas of accounting, auditing and supervision, but then also to implement them. That is our common interest. Let us be honest: the events surrounding the serious Wirecard fraud scandal have cast a very poor light on our capital markets, the role of auditors, corporate governance and enforcement systems. It is therefore now up to us to restore much-needed confidence in our markets.  We therefore also share the concerns expressed by the European Parliament. That is why the Finance Ministers have also begun to hold a debate on the adequacy of audit rules and the European Union's enforcement system, as well as on whether we need a stronger supervisory body at EU level to ensure the stability of our capital markets. We must learn the right lessons from this fraud scandal, and I am sure that we can best do this together in the context of the common market. The Council, and I will assure you once again, ladies and gentlemen, will treat the Wirecard issue as a priority. We intend to present ambitious Council conclusions on strengthening the Capital Markets Union before the end of our Presidency, and this will also give us the opportunity to discuss this matter in the context of a wider debate on the Capital Markets Union and to find a politically coordinated response to this serious fraud scandal. However, the answer to this fraud scandal cannot be simply to point the finger at the supervisory authorities or to give European agencies more powers, more powers. There are also, honourable Members, other areas that need to be addressed urgently and which must ensure that such a situation never happens again. We need to look at the rules in the field of auditing and the role of auditors on the capital markets. Similarly, we need to discuss conflicts of interest between business sectors, advice and auditing, and we also need to think about how we regulate the supervisory framework for certain service providers, and we must ask ourselves whether the rules in force to date have also been balanced responsibly and responsibly enough. This is all the more true because the financing of the EU economy from a variety of sources must remain a central policy objective. Markets in the European Union must be able to retain their attractiveness for investment and financing, and EU businesses must retain access to a wide range of sources of finance. After one of the most serious crises we have ever experienced, our companies now, at this difficult time, need good financing conditions in order to restore their own resources and capital at a reasonable cost. This can only be achieved if we regain confidence – confidence in European capital markets. That must be our common interest.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission welcomes today’s debate. It is essential to investigate fully whether EU investors were fully protected in the Wirecard case, as provided for by European legislation. We must draw all lessons that are necessary to ensure that cases like Wirecard are detected and addressed immediately. We simply cannot allow again that a company that is part of a major stock market index, that is regulated and overseen by national supervisors, and whose auditor is one of the so—called ‘Big Four’, could collapse in such a way, wiping off EUR 22 billion of market capitalisation. Every aspect needs to be looked at – from reporting requirements to auditors and supervision. This is why the Commission has been following this case very closely. As soon as Wirecard announced that it would file for insolvency, we asked the European Securities and Markets Authority to carry out a preliminary investigation on what happened.  The Commission welcomed the preliminary considerations that ESMA published on 15 July. We expect further results by the end of this month from the fast-track Peer Review of enforcement activities that ESMA has announced, and from the ongoing investigations by the various national authorities. It is too early to draw definitive conclusions about the causes of Wirecard’s collapse before those investigations have been completed. Having said that, it seems that the principal cause of the collapse is financial reporting fraud, potentially perpetrated over several years. We can and should already start reflecting on how to better protect investors in the EU from such failures in the future. EU rules and the way they are applied aim to eliminate risk of financial reporting fraud as much as possible. They set out three lines of defence to ensure that financial reports issued by listed companies present a true and fair view of a company’s financial position. This is very important to ensure that investors in those companies have all the information they need and are protected. The first line of defence is at the level of the company. EU law requires that EU companies with securities listed on an EU regulated market establish an audit committee. A majority of members of this committee must be independent of the audited entity. The audit committee has a broad range of responsibilities. For example, it must oversee the work of the statutory auditor. It must ensure the effectiveness of the company’s internal quality control and risk management systems and, where applicable, its internal audit. The EU law also requires disclosure of information about the company’s internal control and risk management systems in relation to the financial reporting process.  The second line of defence is at the level of the auditors themselves. EU rules require independent external audits. They aim to ensure high quality audits based on professional skills, independence and professional scepticism. Auditors must signal any issue that could materially affect the judgement of investors and other users of financial information provided by companies. The auditor of listed companies must also report suspected irregularities, including fraud, to the authorities. The third line of defence is at the level of supervision. National authorities must carry out the daily supervision of financial reporting by companies listed on regulated markets. Competent authorities must ensure that financial statements are drawn up in accordance with the relevant reporting framework and that they take appropriate measures when this is not the case. EU legislation on audits also requires national authorities to supervise the activities of statutory auditors. If appropriate, national authorities should also take enforcement actions, including by imposing sanctions. Supervision is a crucial element of EU policy, at a time when European financial markets are rapidly evolving. New types of business models and players bring innovation and benefits to citizens and companies, both in terms of cost and greater competition. But they need to be supervised in accordance with the regulatory framework. The Wirecard case raises serious questions about the effectiveness of all the three lines of defence. We need to take necessary actions on all fronts, including amending EU law where needed. The Commission has already identified certain areas that are worth exploring. On corporate governance, these may include reinforcing a listed company’s management responsibility for the design and proper functioning of internal controls of financial reporting. We could also propose to require compliance with corporate governance requirements like establishing an audit committee as a condition for listing on a regulated market. On external audit, changes could include reinforcing the role of auditors as regards the risks of fraud and the effectiveness of internal controls on financial reporting. On supervision, we could consider strengthening the alertness and response by supervisory authorities to early warning signals. ESMA could be given more powers towards national competent authorities on enforcement activities. National supervisory activities could be made more transparent, both towards the European Authorities, but also possibly towards the public. And we could reflect on reinforcing audit oversight and enforcement at national and European level. Again, as I said earlier, we will have more knowledge of what action is needed once the investigations have been completed. But in any case it is clear that we will need to react to this.  Thank you very much. I look forward to hearing your views on this important issue.

name: Markus Ferber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his excellent work and for his excellent work. The Wirecard case shows one thing above all: concentrated criminal energy, which must be met primarily by means of the Public Prosecutor's Office and not by means of financial supervision, is a particular challenge. When we read again today that a bank in Austria has been leading the supervisory authorities by the nose for more than 30 years – with criminal energy – it shows that we do not have a problem of supervision, but a problem of how we can detect criminal activities through supervisory rules. Of course, the first question, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, is what role national supervision has played in the country concerned. After all, one could tell from the international press that something might not be right, and yet the BaFin has turned everything away. The question of whether a small bank with a huge business area is properly controlled if the small bank is supervised by BaFin and the rest by the local labour inspectorate is also to be answered. These are the structural problems that we are dealing with here first of all. Secondly, I would also like to say quite openly when it is now being demanded – including by the Federal Finance Minister – that the European authorities must be strengthened as a matter of urgency: he was already in office when we negotiated the review of the European supervisory authorities. He was not at the forefront of the movement to give the European supervisory authority more powers of enforcement, but he was in the brakehouse. That is why this is clearly something that has been mentioned here too. That is why I do not think I am one of those who already know where the solutions are, because we need to take a closer look at the problems. Again, wherever criminal energy is used, we will not be able to deal with this problem with tick boxes – with forms where you tick if anything is fulfilled. That is why I believe that it also makes sense to think at European level about a special public prosecutor's office, as we have with regard to financial interests. That would be the right way forward, and not even stricter rules in places where nothing can be achieved.

name: Jonás Fernández
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Council, Commission, we are again facing a new scandal, a new fraud, in which thousands of citizens see their savings disappear because of illegal practices.  I think it is important to recognise that, in this Union, where there is a full freedom of capital movements, in this Union where we are working to improve the consolidation of continental capital markets, with new impetus to, as I say, to promote this union of capital markets in the Union, we also need to recognise that national supervision is not sufficient , that large companies use the margins of national regulation to arbitrate in these behaviours and that, therefore, we need, if we really believe in this union of capital markets, a single supervisory body in the European Union that goes beyond simple coordination. Because it is being shown that coordination of national supervisors is not enough.

name: Luis Garicano
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, the tale of Wirecard is a tale of economic nationalism. It’s a case of economic nationalism because, when the Financial Times discovers this scandal, the reaction of the regulators is first to investigate the journalists; second, forbid shorting, forbid trading against the stock, something that has never been done for individual stock in Germany; third, continue allowing staff to trade, basically closing your eyes and defending the suspect illicit activity. The problem with economic nationalism is that the supervisor doesn’t have the incentive to act against the companies of their own country. They do it out of national pride. They do it out of economic interest. These are the national champions. Wirecard was the leading fintech.  There have been many instances before of such economic nationalism. Very recently, we had the Danske Bank scandal where the supervisors in Denmark and in Estonia of this Danish subsidiary see hundreds of billions of euro money laundering and do nothing. We had it during the banking crisis. During the banking crisis, we systematically saw regulators in their home country pretending that the banks were much better than they were. The truth of the matter is that the banks were not good, the supervisors pretended that they were good.  What’s the cure against economic nationalism? We know it. We’ve done it in banking. We know the national banking authorities don’t have the incentive to look carefully at their own banks. That’s why we have a single banking supervisor. Mr Roth, when you say that the solution is not European supervision, I think that this is denying the reality of what we see. The reality of what we see is that, as long as we have national regulators overseeing their national champions, they are going to have the incentive to turn a blind eye. We need common supervision at a European level and to stop with this coordination.

name: Gunnar Beck
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Back in 2015, the Financial Times published a series of articles called "House of Wirecard". There was talk of corruption and balance sheet fraud, but auditors, BaFin and the German Audit Office for Accounting (DPR) attested to Wirecard's impeccable financial conduct. German and EU authorities did not act, and ESMA even attested to the DPR 2017 very good work. Wirecard rose to the top of the DAX company. In September 2019, During her trip to China, Chancellor Merkel campaigned for Wirecard– despite warnings from the German Embassy in Beijing, which was concerned only by newspaper reports. The authorities in Singapore were already investigating the company. Meanwhile, the Munich Public Prosecutor's Office is also investigating on suspicion of money laundering. Apparently, no authority held itself responsible at all until the company's insolvency. The financial regulator BaFin classified Wirecard as a technology group, while the district government of Lower Bavaria assigned Wirecard to the financial sector. The EU authorities deny any responsibility, as they only dream of the green economy.  Wirecard was the first DAX group to have to file for bankruptcy, as 1.9 billion euros are simply missing from the balance sheet. Two board members have been arrested, one is a fugitive. Everything points to a total failure by the German and EU authorities and to political protection by windy financial investors – no different from the 2008 financial crisis. And it is not only Wirecard that is pointing to the next financial disaster.

name: Sven Giegold
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in- This Parliament has been a guiding principle for many, many years. The guiding principle in financial supervision is that large European actors come under joint supervision, while smaller actors are still supervised nationally in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity. What we are seeing here is that Wirecard, a large company in Germany, has emerged in the FinTech sector, which had Europe-wide significance, but was not properly supervised by the German financial supervisor and was not properly supervised by the other authorities. What we need to learn from this is that this principle of national supervision of large players in the internal market must be overcome – in the sense of a genuine, functioning Capital Markets Union. What I have unfortunately heard here – again, the German Presidency's warning of an alleged panacea of additional European competences – is, after all, an anachronism following this scandal.  For what we have seen is that the Wirecard scandal has been warned not only in the press, but also in the Council of Supervisors of financial supervisory authorities. The BaFin wiped everything away behind closed doors and said: Everything is fine with us. That is why let us draw the consequences here! To the Federal Government as President-in-Office of the Council: I hope that you will support a strengthened European financial supervision system, which is really responsible for all the major players, so that we can overcome economic nationalism here.

name: Martin Schirdewan
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Wirecard case is not only a major financial scandal, it is also a huge political scandal. Fraudulent management driven by greed falsifies balance sheets for years, deliberately misleading investors and lenders. This fraud is facilitated by the failure of the German financial supervisory authorities and the miserable work of Ernst & Young's auditors – so far. During this time Wirecard had privileged access to the German government, and both Chancellor Angela Merkel and Finance Minister Olaf Scholz have serious questions to answer in the Committee of Inquiry of the German Bundestag: What role did the lobbying of Wirecard's criminal bankers play in the political decision-making process? What role did political protection for Wirecard play in prolonging this fraud? What access do other financial companies have to Federal Government executives, Minister of State, and to executives of the EU institutions, Commissioner? I propose the following measures to prevent such scandals and machinations in the future: in the fintech sector too, the "too big to fail" problem must be prevented, the activities of financial service providers must be limited to the economically sensible extent, otherwise the general public will end up paying the costs of the greed of the few. We need a strengthening of european supervisory authorities; the EU legal framework must be able to respond adequately to the changes in the financial sector. This means harmonised standards for classification, tighter regulation and supervision of FinTech companies. There is also a need to amend the EU Audit Directive. The intimate relationship between the Big Four and the companies you are investigating with a favor check must be terminated and a public audit firm set up.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, only a few months ago Wirecard was among the top thirty companies listed on the German stock exchange, together with Deutsche Bank, Volkswagen and Bayer. Yet it was a Financial Times journalist who discovered this fraud, just as it was American journalists who discovered that fraud for dieselgate. Today we will also be discussing money laundering in this plenary and finding that Deutsche Bank is the most reported European institution, with EUR 1 300 billion in money laundering; Again, it was the journalists who discovered the case. So the question is: what is the point of the decentralised agencies if they do not have the power to monitor and supervise, if they can only coordinate? Mr President, my question is to reconsider the whole structure of the decentralised agencies, because they are obviously conflicting, obviously tainted by conflicts of interest in favour of the strongest states and the most powerful lobbies.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Wirecard scandal has not only caused immense damage to the German capital market, but has caused immense damage to the entire European capital market. Since 2015, we have been discussing one action plan after another to create a European Capital Markets Union. The protection of consumers, retail investors must be a top priority. However, it is precisely the essential control mechanisms that we do not have. The Wirecard scandal has made it clear once again: failure of the supervisory authorities involved, market manipulation, insider trading and so on and so forth. That is why it is once again clear that without direct and uniform European supervision, the next accounting scandal will not be long in coming. One more thing: the revision of the Statutory AuditorS Directive is overdue. The market dominance and conflicts of interest of the Big Four must be broken.

name: Engin Eroglu (Renew).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the President-in-House for the work she has done As a politician who is also an entrepreneur, I am still liable for the decision I have in my company. And we have another scandal here, in addition to the Wirecard scandal, and we must also make it very clear: this is the scandal of the auditors. Wirecard has now shown billions as cash on its balance sheet, but it has never been there. However, these balance sheets were tested by Ernst & Young. Ernst & Young has collected millions in invoice form for this, has made its pockets full. Investors who have bought shares that have trusted this ernst & Young test – who have said: I believe what the auditor said, I buy these securities – are running out of money. Ernst & Young shrugs his shoulders, has the money in his pocket. And that is where we have to go, and that must also be what we have to do in the national governments, including in the Commission: we must create a system where auditors are also liable for their testates in the future. That will not happen. This eternal mantra "something goes wrong – we need more control, more authorities, more officials" ultimately punishes everyone, namely everyone who pays taxes. Punish those who make the mistakes!

name: Antonio Maria Rinaldi (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I cannot help but mention Juvenal's famous Latin phrase, Quis custodiet ipsos custodes, to express my disappointment at the Wirecard scandal. Paradoxically, Germany, which in the eyes of the world is represented as a model of efficiency and rigour, too often turns out to be the centre of huge scandals, from Siemens to Volkswagen, from dividend tax credits collected twice to Libor manipulation and opaque derivatives, the latter thanks to Deutsche Bank. This time, however, with the scandal that has engulfed Wirecard, the confidence of the entire payment card sector is deeply undermined, including the prepaid cards, which are known to be used by the youngest and the weakest – economically speaking – at a time when we are increasingly trying to impose the non-use of cash. In Italy, for example, but also in many other countries of the European Union, some popular credit card circuits that relied as servers on Wirecard did not work for days, creating many problems in the midst of a full COVID emergency, with the result that many users could not even shop. Given that the ECB itself advised against abolishing the use of cash in January 2020, the problem becomes even greater if those authorised to manage such alternative instruments to cash are not also regularly monitored in their work. It is read in the international media that there have been macroscopic conflicts of interest between Bafin employees and trading on the same Wirecard stock, generating despondency and the more than legitimate suspicion that those who had to control had both eyes closed. What role have the auditors and rating agencies that certify the balance sheets of listed companies played? Distracted them too? Let us also not forget that Wirecard also has a banking licence and is therefore further subject to the strict supervision provided for credit institutions: has it happened on time as it has been for other banks? It is therefore called for a minimum of confidence and credibility for the citizens of Europe to be restored.

name: Henrike Hahn (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in- Fake balance sheets, fake sales and profits: the Wirecard scandal is a highly complex deception that should not have happened under so-called supervision. We need a close examination and a cross-border roadmap here, so that such a huge fraud becomes impossible in the future. In the case of Wirecard, this must be carefully checked. The failure of the German financial regulator BaFin, the private audit and also the role of European supervision must be looked at. What is clear is that we must fill gaps in the European legal system. European, national and regional supervisors must work efficiently with a sufficient number of experts to see through these complex business models.  This must also be said: Wirecard's headquarters are in Bavaria. That is why I have to spell this out quite clearly here: consciously looking away and being overwhelmed in the case of economic and financial crime, as the Bavarian state government has done with Wirecard, is explicitly damaging to Germany and Europe as a financial and economic location. That is why we are looking very closely here in the European Parliament today. We need improved EU supervision and auditing to prevent fraud. That's just the beginning of the list of what to do. We need to be better prepared.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, secrecy, corruption, lies, fraud, tax engineering, and all this with the collusion of other companies, governments and so-called market regulators. Look, we have two options. We can be shocked by this particular wirecard case or we can assume that this is not an isolated example, but is a clear example of the casino economy in which we live. Self-regulation doesn't work. This case proves it again. We need binding, mandatory rules with real and effective penalties for companies that do not meet their tax, labor or environmental obligations. Blacklists, such as that of the European Union, which serve to lay tax havens, and from which the Cayman Islands left a few days ago, are of no use. The failure of the European Union's measures to combat tax evasion has been being warned for many years. And the question is clear: are these isolated mistakes or a conscious policy of collusion with fraudsters? Let him respond... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if there is one clear lesson we have learned from the failure of Wirecard, one of the biggest financial cracks in the history of the European Union, it is as follows: the auditing industry needs immediate reform. An industry too often involved in serious conflicts of interest: audits fail because they are paid for by the same audited company; external audits, which are intended to assist investors, end up being influenced by the companies themselves, just as they did with international rating agencies during the financial crisis ten years ago. Who controls the controllers? Proper financial reporting, I would remind you, is a public good but paradoxically it is under the slap of the private sector, which it should control. Yet this issue does not seem to be of interest in Europe, at least until the next financial scandal, when we will all once again be astonished and saddened. The conflict of interests of rating agencies can and must be resolved. We need a European rating agency, public, subject to strict, clear and stringent rules for auditing, with heavy and dissuasive sanctions.  We want this, as proposed by the Commission: fairness, transparency, the absence of conflicts of interest, for a Europe that is no longer strong with the weak and weak with the strong.

name: Eero Heinäluoma (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Executive Vice—President Dombrovskis made the right analysis in August by stating that the Wirecard breached several lines of defence that should normally protect EU investors. We are now two months further on and I welcome your proposal on digital finance, where you seem to give more supervisory power to the European Banking Authority. I further call on you and the German Presidency to be ambitious in setting up an effective EU supervisory regime to tackle money laundering. Only a strong EU supervision, together with an EU financial intelligence unit will tackle money laundering properly.  At the same time, the Commission is far too silent in the field of the audit review. Time and time again, every scandal demonstrates how deeply audit companies are also involved. Therefore, it’s high time that you come forward with a proposal for review with an operational separation of the audit and non-audit services under a direct EU supervision. So it’s time for change. We are awaiting the proposals of the Commission.

name: Stéphanie Yon-Courtin (Renew).
text: Madam President, Mr Executive Vice-President, Minister, Mairead McGuinness reminded us at his hearing last Friday that the Wirecard scandal is an intolerable case of fraud and a failure of our supervisory model. It is unbearable that Wirecard has been protected for so many years, despite questions from investigative journalists, whistleblowers and even investors. In a truly European model, the AEMF itself would have actively asked these questions, without concession to the national authorities. Reforming the governance of European supervisory authorities to strengthen their independence from national supervisors is one of Parliament's concrete demands in the CMU report. I am counting on the German Presidency and the Commission to undertake this ambitious and urgent reform.

name: Dorien Rookmaker (NI).
text: – Madam President, Wirecard was a billion euro company bigger than the Deutsche Bank. The management cooked the books, embezzled of billions of euros, and Jan Marsalek, the COO, disappeared without a trace. More rules and regulation will not improve the situation. As a former chief risk officer, I can assure you, there is no industry that is more regulated than the financial industry. Instead, the German supervisor, the BaFin, should wake up and take responsibility. How is it possible for Jan Marsalek to completely disappear in this age of digital control? What were BaFin employees thinking when they bought shares from the company that they’re supposed to supervise? How is it possible that BaFin let the Wirecard management get away with millions of euros just before bankruptcy was filed? If BaFin does not do its job, Germany will lose its reputation in the financial world, and investors will lose confidence. The EU will not be able to finance their green dream if the financial world cannot rely on the BaFin. This could turn out to be a bigger risk than COVID-19.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: Mr Dombrovskis, the Wirecard affair has been exposed by one good journalist, and Dan McCrum deserves credit for that. But of course we cannot leave the supervision of the financial sector to that one journalist. That has to be good at all levels. And it has failed at all levels. See ernst & young's exade actions, which stacked error on error and silenced internal whistleblowers. See the regulator BaFin, where indeed employees traded in shares of Wirecard, and after the publication went after the journalists and not after Wirecard. A company of more than 20 billion, a role model for fintech, has collapsed. That shouldn't have happened, and it happened anyway. After dieselgate, it's now Wirecard. No country is immune from fraud. If there is one lesson to be learned, it is that we will have to break the feeling of "know us" and hold hands above each other's heads. That is the great advantage of European supervision: that this feeling is broken.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, what I’ve heard today confirms my resolve to act swiftly to address whatever shortcomings in the rules and their application that investigations of the Wirecard scandal reveal.  This is particularly true when it comes to supervision. The recent review of European supervisory authorities has improved the supervisory convergence powers of these authorities. ESMA’s fast—track peer review of the enforcement of financial information in Germany will be the first review to be conducted according to the new rules.  Thanks to the more independent and strengthened process, ESMA can where necessary issue individual recommendations towards national supervisors, following a ‘comply or explain’ mechanism. This mechanism allows a close follow—up on the recommendation and better understanding of the approach of the national supervisor. ESMA can also submit an opinion to the Commission if it considers that further harmonisation of EU rules would be needed. In a single market, the impact of national supervisory failure extends far beyond the borders of the single Member State. National as well as European supervisors need to have the right tools, skills and powers to oversee complex value chains and group structures, as well as to investigate possible cases of fraud or abuse, in particular when it comes to publicly—listed companies and auditors’ responsibilities.  This is why the Commission plans to work towards an enhanced single rulebook for capital markets by assessing the need for further harmonisation of EU rules and monitoring progress towards supervisory convergence. It will take stock of what has been achieved by the end of the next year and propose measures for stronger supervisory coordination or direct supervision by European supervisory authorities where needed. Wirecard was also offering payment processing services and other non—regulated technical services. This shows that supervision and oversight of the actors in the payment chains has become increasingly complex, taking into account the emergence of many new business models and group structures. Activities performed by unregulated entities can have an impact on many other companies in the system. This is why, as part of the review of the Payment Services Directive, the Commission will evaluate any new risks stemming from unregulated activities, especially technical services ancillary to payment or e—money services. We will assess how to best to mitigate those risks and whether some of these activities should be brought under supervision. More broadly, we need to ensure appropriate regulation and supervision of the more complex ecosystem and fragmented value chains that may emerge from the increased involvement of technology companies in the provision of financial services.  As regards auditors, the Commission will publish a report on the functioning of the EU audit market. Separately, the Commission also launched an assessment on how current EU audit market rules work. These were planned before Wirecard’s collapse, but both reports will highlight issues of relevance in this case – for instance, the performance of all the committees, given the different approaches in the Member States. Honourable Members, thank you again for this debate. We look forward to continue working with you on these critical issues for the confidence of EU investors in financial markets.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Thank you very much, Madam President. I can only agree with the Commissioner's thanks. As the Presidency of the Council, we also see this debate as an encouragement of our efforts to make our contribution to learning from our mistakes. Thank you for that! I can also understand, Mr Ferber, that it seems tempting for you to address the problems in a single person. These are more domestic considerations – I do not know whether they belong here. But please do not contradict yourself, because I fully agree with you. You said that before we come to any decisive proposals for concrete measures, we must first analyse the current situation in detail. The Presidency of the Council is ready to do just that, and we will also be putting forward proposals, with your support, by the end of our Presidency. So, once again, before we draw any conclusions, we need to analyse carefully – that is your view, and that is also our view. Mr Giegold, please do not build up a conflict where there is none at all. Once again, the Wirecard fraud scandal has once again made it clear – as there have been many scandals – that we need to deal with regulation and enforcement of accounting rules.  This is not only a national obligation, it is, of course, also a European commitment. When we talk about an EU watchdog, there will be no one here who opposes this effort. On the contrary, we support this. But it is not acceptable for us to look at this in isolation. I am therefore grateful to Mr Zhirdewan and also to Mr Eroglu for pointing out once again the scandals involving the auditors. We will, of course, have to clarify this primarily at national level. So – we are relatively close to each other – whatever the new architecture will look like, it will be crucial to ensure an adequate level of coordination and exchange of information between the national authorities on the ground and the European authorities. If we can do that in the next few weeks, we would all be very pleased, because once again: it is about trust. This confidence has been shaken, and capital markets need a minimum of confidence. I do not believe that it will help us if we are divided or divided here, but that it helps us if we find the highest level of cooperation here.  I also believe that the European Commission has to wait for esMA's report on this; this, too, can be an important source of assessment for our joint commitment. However, we agree on our objective of making financial market coordination at European Union level more efficient, sustainable and also stricter.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Dace Melbārde (ECR)
text: in writing. – The collapse of Germany’s fintech company Wirecard has exposed the weaknesses in the supervisory framework. Although arguments are now being made in favour of a single financial markets supervisor at the EU level, it is no panacea. Before anything we need to have a well-functioning interplay between national and EU regulators where competencies are clearly marked and there is no supervisory vacuum. This also means that it is first and foremost the duty of national financial watchdogs to make sure that relevant companies are playing by the rules and that these rules are effectively monitored and enforced. If they are failing in their duty, it is the responsibility of the Member States to reinforce their capabilities and ensure the necessary independence from any political influence. Unless this happens, it is reasonable to expect more Wirecard-like scandals in the future which in turn would continue undermining people’s trust in the financial system and may affect the smooth functioning of the single market.

name: Puhemies.
text: – The next item is the joint debate on financial services – on the report by Ondřej Kovařík, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the digitalisation process in the financial sector: the emerging risks of cryptocurrency – financial services, regulatory and supervisory challenges related to institutions and markets (2020/2034(INL)) (A9-0161/2020) and – Isabel Benjumea, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, report on the continuation of the development of the Capital Markets Union: in particular, improving access to capital market financing for SMEs and enabling retail investors to participate more (2020/2034(INI)) (A9-0155/2020). I repeat that this part-session does not give catch-the-eye speeches on request and does not accept blue card questions.

name: Ondřej Kovařík
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, digital finance touches the lives of every European citizen without many of us even realising it. During the global pandemic this year, there has been a more urgent need to move our normal activities online. Take the example of opening a bank account, transferring money or requesting a loan. Many banks had to rapidly adapt to provide these services online when most of Europe went into lockdown.  The infrastructure behind this depends on a model based on providing security for businesses, investors and customers. This is a key part of what the report on digital finance is about. Consider your favourite microbrewery, which is a business operating fully offline, relying on clients coming inside to make purchases. With the pandemic and the fight to sink or swim, many moved online to offer their specialty craft beers via online platforms. From one day to the next, they tapped into e-commerce and could explore new possibilities for funding or reach out to new promising markets.  Digital finance, and particularly online banking, shopping and payments, can simplify the financial life of our citizens and of our businesses, from small to large. It’s clear that the pandemic has accelerated a trend we had already been seeing in digital finance. This report addresses a number of these trends and suggests appropriate measures to ensure that the EU framework is fit for a digital age in the area of financial services. The report on digital finance is a legislative initiative report, which is a relatively underused tool in Parliament, but, in our case, we were already working closely with the Commission. I welcome the two concrete frameworks proposed on 24 September by the College on cryptosets, digital operational resilience and other digital finance-related issues. On crypto-assets, the report calls for a framework which is future facing and adaptable to changes that are steadily coming in the near future. The report foresees an open-ended taxonomy to categorise different crypto-assets. The report also calls for a proposal for a legislative framework for stablecoins, whether they be public or private stablecoins, to ensure they meet at least the standards set out in the E-Money Directive. Furthermore, we must ensure that in any legislation there is a stable conversion rate between stablecoin and fiat currencies and the respective stablecoin is reconvertible into fiat currency at par value at any time. For all crypto-assets, the overarching aim is for more transparency, integrity and accountability, and also their full compliance with the existing and future AML framework. On operational resilience, the report asks for a legislative framework that applies consistency and strengthens the ICT and cybersecurity in a harmonised manner across the EU. EU businesses are currently very reliant on third countries’ ICT providers, particularly cloud services. Without access to those providers, the capacity for EU businesses to grow would be diminished. I believe we must work closely with the big tech companies providing these services, ensuring that, when providing services to EU clients, they do apply EU legislation in good faith.  Finally, the report also calls for a framework on digital onboarding, which would lead to harmonisation across the single market of key aspects of digital finance, such as digital financial identities and data sharing fully in line with data protection provisions. There are other aspects of the report, which include a strong call to improve AML provisions, central bank digital currencies, the issue of supervision and the single EU supervision in different aspects of digital finance and, crucially, the question of financial redress.
