Together with a team of shadows, which I would like to thank here, we are able to present the Parliament today with a report that offers a holistic, thorough and sensible approach to questions that the EU will have to answer on digital finances in the coming years.  (Applause)

name: Isabel Benjumea Benjumea
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, in 2015, the European Commission set its purpose, with its first action plan, to make the capital markets union project a reality. Five years later he just presented us with a new action plan. For this reason, in Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, we have worked to draw up a report in which we give our vision, our perspective, of how this union of capital markets is being raised, how it should be implemented, and above all we point out the urgency and need for it to take place as soon as possible. This is the great outstanding subject of the Process of European Integration, but today, with the serious social and economic crisis resulting from COVID-19, it becomes an even greater need for European citizens. Why is the union of capital markets important within the Union? It is important because it allows small and medium-sized enterprises to have a greater option to access capital markets and not have to rely so much on debt. It is also important because it allows small savers, who are no other than small families, domestic economies, to have greater investment options. It is important that there is a union of capital markets so that there are no obstacles, so that there are no obstacles, to reduce the taxation that exists for these capital movements. , not only can European companies find financing options within the market, but those looking for financing in the global world, in other markets, consider us as a competitive market, an attractive market. And it's even more important considering Brexit. In all these circumstances, we have worked on a report which, through seven blocks, gives suggestions to the Commission on the most important, most urgent tasks, to make this union of capital markets a reality. We have worked, and I would like to take this opportunity to thank all the shadow rapporteurs and all the teams who have worked on this time trial report deeply, so that we can at least approve it in the ECON Commission before the Commission published its action plan. And we did it. Today we can make an assessment of that action plan, which was not in the original report, and, in that assessment, my personal assessment is that much remains to be done and we cannot waste any more time yet. The Commission relies on the recommendations of the High-Level Forum and is able to identify the steps to be taken, but no objectives are set, no deadlines are set, nor is it able to provide solutions to the most complicated issues, to issues where there is a lack of consensus. The union of capital markets is a much-needed and very important tool in the face of the great economic crisis and the economic recession that European citizens will suffer. I hope that the Commission will be able to work with the Member States and also with the main players in the financial markets to implement this reality.  We need to be able to have a Europe where SMEs find financing in capital markets, where small savers have more and more investment options and in a safer way. We need a Europe that attracts foreign capital and attracts foreign companies to seek capital in our markets. And we need a Europe where we work to provide financial education to our citizens, a Europe that allows citizens to have sufficient tools to have the right decisions in relation to their investments. Therefore, this is a very important project. We welcome the Commission's proposal, but we call for specific deadlines, concrete measures and a reality as soon as possible. Let us not forget that there is freedom of movement of capital in Europe. What is this freedom going to be like if there is no single capital market?

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, today’s debate is very timely and important to make progress on key EU priorities: the recovery, strengthening the resilience of our economy, supporting the transition to a green and digital economy. The Commission recently adopted two major initiatives to promote those objectives: a Digital Finance package and a new Action plan on the Capital Markets Union.  First, I would like to thank Mr Kovařík for his report. The Commission’s digital finance strategy is fully in line with its principles. But it is not only about principles. Commission President Ursula von der Leyen committed to responding with a legislative act, in full respect of the proportionality, subsidiarity and better law making principles, when Parliament adopts a resolution requesting that the Commission submit legislative proposals, based on Article 225 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Indeed, with the digital finance strategy, the Commission committed to take specific action to follow up on the report’s recommendations. For example, we will propose in 2021 to harmonise rules on customer onboarding, and we will build on the upcoming review of the rules on electronic identification to implement an interoperable cross-border framework for digital identities. Time is of the essence in the fast-moving world of digital finance. This is why the Commission has already acted in line with the recommendations of the report. The proposal on crypto-assets brings clarity on the rules governing transparency, prudential standards and market integrity. It aims to allow companies to draw on the possibilities offered by these assets, and more generally by new technologies such as blockchain, and to do it in such a way as to mitigate risks for investors and preserve financial stability. The Commission moved not only to close the regulatory gap for those crypto-assets that are not covered by the existing rules. In line with your report, we are also proposing amendments to make sure that certain crypto-assets fit into the current regulatory framework. We also proposed a pilot regime for market operators to test innovations in a safe and controlled environment. The report rightly addresses the risk of tax evasion linked to crypto-assets. Our July action plan for fair and simple taxation envisages expanding the scope of the directive on administrative cooperation to cover all crypto-assets. We will come with a proposal in 2021. I also share the concerns expressed in the report about the money-laundering risks that may be associated with crypto-assets. Crypto-assets are already covered by the Fifth Anti-Money Laundering Directive. Our proposal covers all the crypto-asset service providers listed in the Financial Action Task Force standards. It puts considerable requirements on service providers to protect consumers, market integrity and financial stability. Additional requirements will follow from future proposals to overhaul the EU anti-money laundering framework in 2021. The Commission also agrees on the need for a common approach to resilience of our ICT infrastructures. This is why we put forward a legislative proposal on digital operational resilience. It aims to ensure that all financial market participants have put safeguards in place to cope with cyber-attacks and other ICT risks. It also introduces an EU oversight framework for ICT providers to financial entities, such as cloud computing service providers. So I count on Parliament to make swift progress on these proposals. Let me now turn to the Capital Markets Union. I would like to thank Ms Benjumea for her draft report. The Commission shares its priorities, and welcomes its ambition. Developing our capital markets now, at a time of crisis, matters more than ever. As your report underlines, we need to stimulate financing around Europe. We need more financing opportunities to help start-ups and to help larger companies to thrive. We now have 27 national capital markets that are neither fully developed nor fully integrated. This is particularly important in light of Brexit. Europeans do not get the most out of their savings because they lack the confidence to invest in capital markets, so we need to create more opportunities for Europeans to invest safely for their future. We also need to get more funding for the green and digital transitions and, last but not least, to strengthen the international role of the euro. With our action plan, we have 16 initiatives to achieve these objectives. Let me just name a few: helping large investors to invest more in EU businesses, including for the long term; making information on EU companies more easily accessible – digitally – for EU and non-EU investors by using a single access point; helping Europeans to save safely for their future, for them to buy the best and cheapest financial products and so that their pensions are adequate and sustainable. The Commission will propose legislation as of next year to achieve these objectives, and, with your support, we can really make progress towards completing the Capital Markets Union.

name: Stefan Berger
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, digitalisation is changing the world. We see the digital revolution of our payment systems starting with the credit card going to bitcoins. There are 18 million bitcoins with a market capitalisation of EUR 170 billion, and now we are about to face stablecoins like Libra. Soon, Facebook will launch its own digital currency Libra. Admittedly, the fact that Libra money could be sent cheaply across borders as quickly as text messages is very tempting, and nevertheless there are serious concerns – data protection, terrorist financing, money laundering – and therefore we need a set of rules. The digital finance report is a good basis. It provides a framework for crypto-assets.  And on the other hand, now the European Central Bank must take responsibility. As a consumer, of course, I rather trust the Central Bank more than Zuckerberg, and if we let Facebook open a Pandora’s box, or in this case a Pandora’s wallet in Europe, then it’s too late. A digital euro is not an option. A digital euro is a necessity for Europe to achieve digital sovereignty. And a digital euro is the best answer to private initiatives such as Libra.  Let’s take a look at our global neighbours China, Japan or Switzerland. They are working on their own central bank digital currency and at the end of the day the conclusion is: the question is not if there will be digital currencies in the future, but who will issue and control them? We need a framework for crypto-assets and we need a European Central Bank digital currency as an answer to Libra.

name: Eero Heinäluoma
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank our rapporteur Mr Kovařík for the very inclusive way of working. Digitalisation of the financial sector is really booming now, partly helped by COVID-19. The possible advantages are clear: it can reduce prices and inefficiencies and increase transparency. At the same time, we can’t be naive, and we need to look at it in a very accurate way. Indeed, the previous debate on Wirecard clearly demonstrates we have to draw the right lessons. Half of the crypto—assets transactions is linked to illegal activities, like the buying or selling of illegal goods or services, money laundering, and payments in ransomware attacks. Recent findings suggest that 76 billion dollars of illegal activity per year involves Bitcoins. Therefore we can’t leave any regulatory loophole open. I will come to recent legislative proposals of the Commission, but let there be no misunderstanding: for my group, only a strict regulatory framework, which fully ensures investor and data protection, market stability and integrity, and which is properly supervised from EU level together with national authorities, will be good enough. Particularly in times of Green Deal, we can’t be blind to the carbon footprint of the applications, either. I furthermore welcome the ECB stands on central digital currency. We cannot let Libra undermine monetary sovereignty. There is no place for digital assets not meeting high-level EU standards. And the same is true for critical third-party providers. Cyber security is one of the main risks the financial sector is exposed to today. We need to regulate and supervise these providers properly. Finally, it’s critical that no one is left behind. That’s the sincere aim of our group.

name: Stéphanie Yon-Courtin
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, I am delighted that tomorrow in the European Parliament his vision for the Union of Capital Markets will be voted on. Parliament has decided to bring the voices of citizens, consumers, and savers, who are often less well represented in expert discussions. On behalf of the Renew Group, I have focused three main priorities on the union of capital markets to be both more inclusive, that is, it offers innovative financing for SMEs and for the social and solidarity economy, so that it is also at the heart of the post-COVID recovery and that it is a guarantee of European strategic autonomy. Clearly, the Commission's action plan published at the end of September is not up to the task, in particular, to protect our savers and to respond to the Wirecard scandal. Savings must be ensured that savings stop sleeping on accounts but are injected directly into the economy. Every saver must also participate directly in the construction of the european economy of tomorrow, which is more sustainable and resilient. You can count on the Renew Group and the European Parliament to continue to carry this ambition because every citizen must become a consumer: a real player in consumption. I would like to warmly thank Isabel Benjumea, rapporteur, for her listening and collaboration during rich and intense discussions in record time! Well done! I will therefore vote in favour of this report tomorrow.

name: Gunnar Beck
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Suddenly, according to the Commission's sustainability criteria, everything should be digital: medical care, education, the world of work, environmental protection and the fight against climate change. Even peace, gender justice and lost confidence in the EU are to be strengthened digitally. From now on, the central bank can maintain and act like commercial banks. All of this is contrary to the Treaty and serves only unlimited money creation. Digitisation is the adjustment that competition enforces and it does so where it increases productivity and releases scarce human capital in Europe. But it is not a panacea for misguided policies, the cost of uncontrolled immigration, and sterile investment as a result of unbridled money creation.

name: Kira Marie Peter-Hansen
text: verts/ALE Group. Madam President! I will speak in Danish today so that we can have some linguistic diversity in this House. First of all, I would like to thank our rapporteur very much for his hard work and for the good cooperation. I appreciate that the concerns of the Green Group have been listened to and that many of our ideas have been included.  Unfortunately, we cannot vote in favour of this report anyway because of the words about financial deregulation, which we see as a major challenge. There may not be much to say that it has ended in this way. When you look at the Commission's expert group, it was filled with lobbyists from the financial sector and interest groups with one objective in mind: financial deregulation. The Commission is otherwise obliged to put together a joint group of experts, which is why we have also asked the European Ombudswoman to look into this, and I look forward to hearing her response.  Then, when we see the Commission's action plan in this area and in further work, I hope that the diversity of the composition of the expert groups will be borne in mind and that we will have a more balanced report. We need a capital market that is transparent and transparent and in which there is proper consumer protection. Where we have healthy capital markets and where financial deregulation is not the objective, but financial stability.  That is why I am very much looking forward to working again with you, Commissioner, and also with our rapporteur on this important area and important work.

name: Eugen Jurzyca
text: for the ECR Group. – Madam President, functioning capital markets help not only firms and economic growth, but also citizens who are allowed to earn their savings instead of losing value. In order to make capital markets operational, we need to know the reasons why they are not working well in the EU, we need to have an analysis of best practices in different countries, and we need to measure the real benefit to the citizen. The reasons why capital markets do not work are not well identified in the long term. In fact, we have been introducing capital union since 1999, and since then the share of financing through capital markets in the Euro Area has fallen and in the US it has risen. Clearly, we do not have an analysis of best practices in the action plans, we do not know enough about why in the US 41% of financial assets held by American households are invested through capital markets, in the European Union it is only 21%. We also do not know enough about why, for example, estonian households have 51% of their financial wealth in investments of tradable shares and Slovak households only 1%. The Commission claims today that it has fulfilled all its tasks from the old 2015 Action Plan. However, how can all the tasks for the establishment of a capital union be fulfilled while moving away from the objective of better functioning capital markets. We cannot measure success by the number of legislative adaptations adopted, but by indicators that correspond to a real benefit for the European citizen.

name: José Gusmão
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, more than a decade after the financial crisis, what we have seen with these reports is that Parliament continues to legislate on the financial system by talking about consumers, talking about small businesses, but thinking above all about the interests of the financial industry. Two examples of what I have just said in these two reports. Firstly, the pressure, the insistence on the pressure of a more favourable tax treatment for private pension products. Even after all the experiences of privatisation of social security systems have resulted in social disasters, this Parliament insists on getting taxpayers to pay for the privatisation of social security in countries through exemptions and tax benefits.  The second example has to do with the very weak regulation that is proposed for cryptocurrencies despite the common diagnosis of a large part of the political groups that cryptocurrencies have no use, they produce no social advantage, do not respond to any customer needs, serve to promote tax evasion and fraud and promote illegal transactions, and yet Parliament is moving forward with an extraordinarily backward regulatory proposal, including contributing to the idea that cryptocurrencies have something to offer consumers when they do not. There are only one currencies, it is the currencies that benefit from guarantees that only states are in a position to offer.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not agree with what my colleague said a moment ago. Since the beginning of the pandemic, the ECB has purchased government bonds for EUR 1 350 billion with its emergency purchase programmes; the most indebted countries have paid this money at high interest rates. Yet, at the same time, the ECB financed private banks with EUR 1 600 billion through the TL and TRO programmes, which were poured into private banks at virtually negative rates, with a great favour to private banks. Yet these banks, as is always the case in crises, have filled their bellies but have not poured this money into the real economy. This is the point, this is what happens during all crises: banks are getting richer and citizens are getting poorer and poorer. This mechanism cannot work: it is an unsustainable mechanism and, as soon as the citizens realise that with crypto-currencies they will be able to free themselves from the banking sector permanently and from their speculation, they will do so in no uncertain terms.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr President-in-Chief of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The Corona crisis has put the equity situation of many European companies to the test. At the same time, London will be Europe's most liquid financial centre outside the European Union. It is far from clear that access to this liquidity pool will be readily possible in the future. In other words, the Capital Markets Union project is now more urgently needed than ever before. Unfortunately, progress in recent years has taken place in the area of triplesteps rather than in the area of big jumps. In its own-initiative report, for which I would like to express its thanks, the European Parliament clearly described where the construction sites are located. The Commission must now address this, not with new action plans, but with actions. We have enough plans; we need the activities now. The very big stumbling blocks are well known: this is tax law, and that is insolvency law. Both things need to be addressed, and I very much regret that the Council is not there. I was pleased earlier that I received a note from the Representative of the Council; I would have liked to have received them now.  We need the Member States here. And if the Member States do not play along, the Capital Markets Union will always remain a torso. That is why I would also like to call on the panel of experts, which is now being set up between the Council and the Commission, for activities to be decided here and not just action plans.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the truth is that we have very little time to discuss two reports that are very relevant to the future of the legislature.  First, report on the union of capital markets, good report. But our group, committed to this consolidation of capital markets, is also committed to common regulation and supervision, something that we do not yet have and which, scandal after scandal, European citizens demand from us. Digital Finance Report: a new environment where innovation support and support needs to be combined with the need for control, the need for very strict regulation to prevent abuse, fraud or fraudulent uses. In any event, in this report, I would like to conclude at this time the publication of the European Central Bank's proposal to start work on the issuance of a digital euro. Because if there have to be digital currencies, there has to be public currencies, and the monopoly of the European Central Bank has to be guaranteed.

name: Billy Kelleher (Renew).
text: – Madam President, first and foremost, may I say I am very disappointed that in the context of the report that has just been published and that we are debating that we again go for a big ideological debate around consolidated corporate tax and other inclusions in a report that was wholly unnecessary. The capital markets union is critically important. It needs to be brought forward as urgently as possible, but if we want to unlock Council and other obstacles, the idea that we would bring everything into a report that is clearly unnecessary in the context of the capital markets union is very disingenuous, to be quite truthful. I’m disappointed that we consistently raise issues that are not relevant to the capital markets union and, in particular, paragraph 22 of the report.  But beyond that, it is urgent that we have the capital markets union. We have to untap the potential of our small and medium-sized sector post-Covid. We need to ensure there is stimulus and growth in the economies and access to credit – access to other forms of capital are more critically important than the traditional banking sector because our banks are impaired and are not involved in traditional lending as they would have been into the real economy. So the capital markets union is urgent, but please desist from undermining what is a good report by including things in it that are not necessary.

name: Thierry Mariani (ID).
text: Madam President, when it no longer has the value conferred on it by gold or silver, the currency is based on the sovereignty of the power that issues it. That is why for a century, the currency has been issued by states that have a monopoly on power. Private companies are now rivaling the states. In order to make the ideal consumer, subject to the advertising injunction, they intend to break this link with the sovereign power that is money. To complete the establishment of the total market society, they want to privatize the currency and put themselves in the capacity to issue their own currency. The movement in this direction is represented by Bitcoin. Even if Bitcoin, which has no liberating power, is not a currency and is akin to a Ponzi pyramid. It is only worth it by the belief that it will gain value. With regard to the Libra, it remains a private currency and has nothing to do with the project of several central banks wishing to issue one or more electronic currencies, but whose governance will be that of the issuing institutes, ultimately based on the sovereignty of the state. That is why we are in favour of this text. We must prevent the development of private currencies competing with those of states to protect savings and the security of transactions. We need to clarify the regulatory framework for the issuance of money so as not to suffer another democratic setback.

name: Stasys Jakeliūnas (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, Agustin Carstens, Director-General of the Bank of International Settlements, called Bitcoin a combination of Ponzi scheme, financial bubble and environmental disaster. I tend to agree with him, and would add that Bitcoin and thousands, now thousands, of other so-called crypto assets are also a ripe environment and vehicle for financial crime, including money laundering. Therefore, these assets, basically, have no sustainable value for society and, because of that, are prohibited in a number of jurisdictions. Some of them, some of us, call that financial innovation. That would be a fine thing. Another financial innovation, global stablecoins, has even more serious and wider reaching negative implications, especially regarding financial stability, privacy and data protection risks, monetary policy transmission and especially monetary sovereignty, as was mentioned here already. As a response to that, the third financial innovation, central bank digital currencies, were initiated and this should be studied and debated thoroughly here at the European Parliament and other institutions, and we will certainly do that. If constructed and implemented properly, a digital euro could help deal with the remaining payment and financial inclusion issue, but more importantly, it could increase financial stability on our fragmented financial supervision landscape and boost the role of the euro on the global scene. The report on crypto assets is a step forward in order to balance somewhat unwarranted enthusiasm at the European Commission in the FinTech area.

name: Elżbieta Kruk (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Small and medium-sized enterprises are crucial to the EU economy, representing 99% of EU businesses and providing two thirds of private sector jobs. At the same time, they have been the most affected by the economic crisis of COVID-19. Almost 90% of them reported a reduction in turnover and almost half had liquidity problems. These companies will therefore need more stable sources of financing, e.g. from the capital market. Especially since the action taken so far is insufficient. The Proposal for a Multiannual Financial Framework and the EU Recovery Plan do not meet today's needs, and the Strategy for a Sustainable and Digital Europe published in March does not take into account the current economic situation. The project to build a European Capital Markets Union gives the impression that small and medium-sized enterprises are to be the focus of building a common capital market in Europe, and in fact we are hearing about shifting national supervisory powers towards the European institutions, which will have harmful consequences precisely for small and medium-sized enterprises, for favouring banks, and in addition, new obligations are being requested here. , e.g. related to green transformation.  I appeal, let us today rebuild an economy destroyed by lockdown, and only then with the green agenda, otherwise we will bury the achievements of many Europeans for good. When building aid instruments, let us also remember that small and medium-sized enterprises are not only the most affected by the economic crisis, but will also be most affected by additional administrative and other burdens. On digitalisation, I remain hopeful that it will be crucial for the smooth financing of the European economy. This is a potential that Europe must not waste. However, I ask that we do not create an overly prescriptive legal framework that does not correspond to the dynamic development of technology. Only if we are open to dialogue will we create better opportunities for businesses and at the same time make life easier for consumers.

name: Enikő Győri (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Today, all our efforts must be to help Europe emerge from the economic crisis caused by the epidemic. The survival of thousands of small and medium-sized enterprises and the preservation of millions of jobs are at stake. Businesses should be able to access resources throughout the EU, not just in their own Member State. Moreover, it is becoming increasingly difficult for European capital markets to function competitively, compared to the much larger and more efficient US capital markets or the fast-growing Chinese capital markets. With Brexit, the Union will also lose one of its strongest capital markets players, the UK. If we really want to be a leader in sustainable finance and digitalisation, there is also a vital need to increase the integrity of capital markets. Among the measures now proposed by the Commission, I highlight as particularly positive the strengthening of national capital markets, the more efficient provision of financing for small and medium-sized enterprises and the development of financial awareness as the objective to be achieved. At the same time, I would like to draw attention to the fact that national specificities must always be taken into account, so that any legislative action must be preceded by a comprehensive impact assessment. Finally, strengthening supervisory convergence is an objective to be supported, but I would warn against the possible expansion of the direct supervisory cases of EU supervisory authorities, at the expense of the powers of the supervisory authorities of the Member States. Such a provision would be at the expense of efficiency and would only cause confusion on national markets.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we welcome the Digital Finance Strategy of the Commission as well as the Crypto-assets Regulation, and thank you, Vice-President, because both the files address the expectations and concerns of the initiative report of this House. Digital finance and crypto-assets can be considered valuable for the transition to better financial markets, but also a more efficient payment regime to remove barriers of cross-border payments, and they should definitely be based on solid political principles. We definitely need to see technological neutrality combined with business model neutrality, and the regulator should not favour only legacy business models. Secondly, digital finance is about data, not just crypto-assets, and more about open finance, so even broader than open banking. Thirdly, a risk-based approach is necessary, putting investor and consumer protection first, but knowledge and understanding of the technologies is equally necessary, otherwise we would be less cautious and more fearful of innovation. And fourthly, the scandal of Wirecard showed that technological risks should be addressed by harmonised supervision and strong RegTech, because these failures of Germany showed that no country can address data-intensive financial services with the current inefficiencies and lack of data governance. So thank you for taking this into consideration and for your work until now.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has This development of FinTechs and Digital Finance offers great opportunities for innovation, opportunities for new offers, for tougher competition, for cheaper and more accessible financial products. But at the same time, we see how the BigTechs – Amazon, Microsoft, Google, Facebook – are currently entering the markets of financial markets, and there is a new threat to the concentration of economic power. This concentration of economic power does not fit into the social market economy. We must counter this by means of two key instruments: firstly, Europe needs its own public digital currency issued by the European Central Bank. Secondly, the same rules must apply to the large providers as to traditional financial market players, in other words: money laundering controls, know your customers, no more grey zones for money laundering and financial crime. Then FinTech and Digital Finance can become a success story for Europe.

name: Helmut Geuking (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you to the rapporteurs. We have two very good reports available as a basis for the Commission's work. I think that is how we can work. For my part, I would like to comment on cryptocurrencies, because I see this as the greatest danger for the future. The cryptocurrencies – we mentioned it earlier with Facebook Libra, for example – are a financial attack on our currency units, for me. We should move quickly to ban these cryptocurrencies, which are privately owned and made by global players. We must, of course, produce our own digital euro currency. As far as I know, the experimental project will run through the ECB bank from 12 October – that is the right way to go. But this path can only be successful if, at the same time, we also have the courage to stand up to these global players who want to enter the financial market. Let us not delude ourselves: this is about a lot of fast money – fast money that is used for criminal gangs, for terrorist financing. This is about large-scale money laundering, cryptocurrencies where it is not possible to trace where the funds come from, what exactly that money is. Not even Europe's banks today show the extent to which they work with cryptocurrencies. That is very worrying. So we are breeding bubbles here that may one day burst and that will cost the next generation dearly. We need to take decisive action now. And that can only be done with a general ban on cryptocurrencies, unless they are linked to countries. That is why we must prevent Facebook Libra, and we must also ban bitcoin, otherwise we will leave future generations with financial chaos and fiasco. That is why I would also ask the Commission to take action here to be much more aggressive in tackling these criminal activities, which are already taking place on the Internet on a daily basis.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (PPE).
text: Madam President, in my view, Mrs May's report is a very good one. Benjumea is a serious effort to support small and medium-sized enterprises through capital markets and their European integration. Finally good news for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are being tested. According to the European Commission's estimates, small and medium-sized enterprises and countries most dependent on small and medium-sized enterprises, such as Greece, will be hit hard by the crisis linked to the corovirus.  The second is that the pandemic is longer than we had estimated and as far as the economy is concerned the results are worse, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises. Also for 2020 there is no substantial strengthening of the European economy - apart from the European Central Bank. It's all left to state budgets.  Finally, the European Recovery Fund seems to be lagging behind due to political controversies and we need its money, because we are constantly making it more difficult for small and medium-sized enterprises, such as the green transition, while limiting funding to meet the new objectives. So the news is good, but, as previous colleagues have said, apart from the legislative work we need to see the result.

name: Pedro Marques (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the development of the capital market in Europe is essential for economic growth after this pandemic.   Better opportunities to finance the activity of our SMEs are essential to achieving better job opportunities for Europeans. Much more needs to be informed of citizens to increase the base of individual investors. More solutions need to be involved in savings and investment products in business through digital platforms, which will make it possible to extend services and users much and to integrate markets in Europe more easily. But experience has shown vast times, as in successive scandals such as wirecard, that with the development of digital transfer services, with cryptocurrencies also comes a lot of money laundering and a lot of tax fraud.  That is why European regulation and supervision must promote a controlled development of these markets by regulating transactions and promoting a strong monetary base associated with digital currencies so that citizens' insecurity does not in future undermine such a promising market.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work I warmly welcome the two comprehensive catalogues of demands that we have before us today, with over 140 concrete instructions for further developing the Capital Markets Union and digital finance. These measures are right, necessary and important. A strong capital markets union brings a whopping 120 billion euros of added value per year. We do not want to Americanise the financing possibilities. We want the European capital market to function better.  The core tasks are clear: to finance the real economy, to free small and medium-sized enterprises from a potential credit crunch, and to promote entrepreneurship and stimulate investment. The Capital Markets Union is a necessary complement to the European credit market, leads to an end to the national patchwork, creates more funding opportunities for citizens, more potential for growth and employment, and more strength to tackle climate change and digitalisation. Mr Giegold has already raised the question of the fact that, of course, we must also oppose the crypto assets from the United States and China and do everything possible to ensure that multinational companies such as Facebook cannot operate in a legal vacuum with their Libra currency. We need a digital euro from the ECB and our own real-time payment method, the European Payments Initiative. May we do it together!

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The European Capital Markets Union undoubtedly offers many new opportunities, good opportunities for savers, for investors. But the whole thing can only work if all the elements are harmoniously intertwined. A single bad element already has a negative effect on people. So this means: how is the whole thing supposed to work? There is a need for control of the financial sector in the European capital market. How? By strengthening, by extending the role of ESMA. And it needs regulation. Anyone who says cross-border investment must also say 'yes' to the CCCTB, the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base – it has certainly lost something here. The European minimum tax rate for companies is not only a win for investors, but for all people in Europe.

name: Christophe Hansen (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, in order to get out of this generalised economic crisis, it is more important than ever to create a Capital Markets Union worthy of the name.  We need alternatives to bank loans, especially for SMEs, but also new investment opportunities for savers. As rapporteur for future relations with the United Kingdom, I must also tell you that I am very concerned about our dependence on London on capital because, depending on their nature, between 40 and 80 per cent of the capital market activities of the 27 are carried out in London. We therefore have work to do to establish a real internal capital market with the necessary critical mass, a better coordinated UMC, capable of valuing the specialisations that our financial centres have managed to build over the years. Thus, our pioneering role in sustainable finance, which will enable us to achieve our ambitious objectives under the Green Pact. Our strength lies in the diversity of our financial centres and not in centralization. Ladies and gentlemen, we have an opportunity but also a single obligation to make the euro area and the European Union economy more resilient to future crises. Let's seize it with concrete actions and not just with action plans.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: – Madam President, there’s nothing wrong with the idea of the capital markets union in the sense that it could offer new opportunities and promote efficiency and risk diversification. It’s a pity though if it’s translated into a call for deregulation or cutting red tape, as if that’s the only and real impediment to intra-European investments. Think big. European capital markets require a uniform rulebook and European supervision. Besides, they require that the debt bias is removed from the corporate tax system, and they would be promoted if we had a common withholding tax. Well, this isn’t on the table, is it? As long as it’s not on the table, let’s be realistic and pragmatic on what we can achieve with the capital markets union, and with the European Union, in this.  Besides – and this is the main point I would like to make – don’t compare us to the US. We need the European in the capital market. That means strong protection of retail investors and clear standards for sustainability, both environmental and social. The US is not an example for Europe on this. We need to take the lead ourselves.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE).
text: – Madam President, building a capital union is particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the backs of our economy. Many surveys show that what they suffer the most, especially in times of crisis, is access to financial resources and a lack of capital. They thus have a major disadvantage over large companies and competitors. If we want a digital, green and innovative economy, we must also talk in one breath about financial support for small and medium-sized enterprises. A small business simply won't be able to afford to buy equipment and services to keep up with the competition. Therefore, well-set conditions of the Capital Union will help them overcome the harder period and develop further. Building a capital union is also important for eliminating the European comparative disadvantage compared to the AMERICAN capital market. The Capital Union is thus an important element for European growth and the creation of new jobs.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the impact the pandemic has had on the European economy has been enormous, with a drop of 12% in GDP reported in the eurozone. The impact of course is global. We have seen similar hits elsewhere. The United Kingdom 20%, the US 9%, my own country 6%, but we are officially back in recession. So in the context of getting the economy back on track, initiatives like the capital markets union are ever more relevant than they were before the pandemic. Putting in place a well functioning capital markets union, as we see in the United States for example, should be considered an important part of our growth strategy for the next decade. It would provide new sources of funding for businesses, reduce the cost of raising capital, increase options for savings across the EU, and make EU financial system more stable, resilient and competitive. The CMU offers enormous potential for our businesses and start-ups, it would make the EU a far more attractive location for innovation and entrepreneurship and help drive jobs to the economy and also of course be very valuable to SMEs. I look forward to Commissioner Dombrovskis and my good friend Mairead McGuinness, who is now taking over his role, making this a reality during this term.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you once again for this opportunity to debate these important topics today. The future of finance is digital. We have seen it also during the lockdown and we will need it for the recovery, to give better financial products for consumers and to open new funding channels for companies. A number of points were raised by Members during this debate on the new market players where we would follow an approach of ‘same activity, same rules’, ensuring a level playing field between existing market players and potential newcomers. We are supportive of the work of the European Central Bank on the initiative of a central bank digital currency and, as you know, the European Central Bank recently published a report in this regard. I heard a number of concerns which were raised in the context of crypto-assets, and we will continue to bring crypto-assets into the regulated sphere, to address the risks properly for financial stability, for consumer protection, for anti-money laundering, and especially crypto-assets like Global stablecoins will require – and that’s what we have proposed – more stringent rules, given their potentially systematic impact. Moving to the capital markets union, over the past five years we have made a lot of progress with our plan to integrate European capital markets into a union. Now we need to go further still. It’s important for our people and our businesses to diversify the funding sources of the European economy and to put European savings to productive use. We know that it’s not going to be easy to go to the next level, but our recovery will be far more robust and lasting if we do. I am glad that the Commission’s approach in these initiatives is closely aligned with your reports. We share the same main objectives, and I am confident that this House will confirm this at the vote: that our two institutions are indeed the strong partners the EU needs in this critical moment. Please rest assured that these reports will remain an important reference point for our work to implement those policies.

name: Ondřej Kovařík
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, there were a number of issues raised during this debate, which I think shows that actually there is an urgency and an importance in the debate that we are about to have about digital financial services. I would definitely welcome, Executive Vice—President, a number of the commitments that you made in your introductory speech, especially those on putting forward initiatives on digital onboarding. I think this is a very important initiative that we really need to put forward in the European Union, especially in order to strengthen and enhance the single market in this area, and also the further strengthening of the anti-money laundering framework, which you mentioned will take place next year. I think this is also a very important point for this House to discuss. Another issue that was raised – and I think this is also why the urgency is there – is the reaction from our side to initiatives such as Libra, a private stablecoin which has the potential to change drastically the way financial and monetary relations are organised in the economy. So I think this House will be happy to have a debate on this issue, and we also welcome the ECB proposals and the scenarios that were published recently. We’re definitely looking forward to a discussion of the proposals that the Commission has already made on crypto—assets and digital operational resilience. I also see a very good link between enhancing digital financial services and tapping the potential of the capital markets union, as was mentioned by a number of colleagues. Finally, you mentioned, Mr Executive Vice—President, that the future of financial services is digital. I would say that the future of the economy and the future of the European Union is digital, so actually we should make sure that the framework that we have is fit for this purpose.

name: Isabel Benjumea Benjumea
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, thank you very much, Vice-President, for being here with us today, and thank you very much for all the contributions to the debate we have had. Truly, as I said in my initial speech, after this terrible pandemic that we are still suffering, comes a terrible social and economic crisis, and there is no better social policy than job creation. Those who create jobs are future entrepreneurs, those small start-ups who are looking for funding to launch a business idea, or small and medium-sized enterprises, which, as has also been said, are the main job creators within the Union Therefore, we need both those who are seeking funding to start a business , such as those who are seeking funding to keep their business running, have better and greater access to financing. And the union of capital markets, the ability to access capital markets throughout the Union in an accessible, simplified, barrier-free way, without excessive taxes and in a way that allows these companies access to these funds, will allow for a form of financing that, at a time when we are entering a terrible economic crisis , certainly has to be a reality. But for there to be those funds, we need money to enter the markets, and that's what small savers are key for. Small savers have to find these capital markets attractive and, therefore, you have to do it in a safe and attractive way for them, so that they have a more varied offer of investment.  But nothing in the report of which I have had the honour of being rapporteur, or anything that it puts in the action plan presented to us by the Commission, which is undoubtedly a good action plan, makes sense if the most complicated issues, which are the issues of insolvency, are not put on the table , tax issues and supervisory issues, and if a plan with specific dates is not put on the table, with specific objectives, and if it is not worked together with the Member States and the rest of the actors in the financial sector. I therefore ask the Commission for more ambition to be able to make the union of capital markets a reality and I ask you to support, with your vote, the report to be voted on this afternoon.

name: Przewodnicząca. –
text: I close the debate. The amendments will be voted on on Wednesday 7 October 2020. The final vote will take place on Thursday 8 October 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – This report focuses on measures to reboot the capital markets union while targeting the need for SMEs to reduce their reliance on bank loans by getting access to funding on capital markets. Proposed actions include facilitating SME listing, a pan—European IPO fund for floating SME shares on stock markets and a European single access point which centralises relevant information to help them attract investors. Other proposals call for the encouragement of retail investors through the design of appropriate products and the promotion of financial literacy, starting with schools. Moreover, a link with programmes to develop sustainable finance has been hardwired into the proposals. Emphasis is maintained on safeguarding the robust regulatory standards, built since 2008, to protect citizens from any financial crash. A fundamental aim is to establish a long—term European culture of direct investment by citizens in productive assets, especially those run by SMEs. Indeed, alternative channels of financing are more than ever needed to support the economic and social fabric constituted by SMEs. This would also reduce the pressure on banks which presently seem overloaded with targets they must meet, not all of them congruent with each other. I am glad to have helped with the preparation of this report on behalf of the S&D Group.

name: Przewodnicząca. –
text: The next item is the second part of the vote. We will vote on the items on the agenda. Before voting, I would like to vote for Jytte Guteland, who will appear in accordance with Rule 59(4) of the Rules of Procedure on referral to the committee responsible for the interinstitutional negotiations and on the report on European climate law.

name: Jytte Guteland

I would just like to say the formal procedure now.  In line with Article 59(4), subparagraph 4, of the EP Rules of Procedure, I would like to request to refer the matter back to the committee responsible for the interinstitutional negotiations in accordance with Rules 60 and 74. In addition, if the draft legislative act fails to secure a majority, I would ask for it to be referred back to committee for consideration.
